The UPS must include the platform feature ""Power module sleep mode"".Detailed requirements for this feature can be found under the Feature Brick platform requirements.Sleep mode also needed to reduce leading power factor on input at low load levels by opening PM relay's to isolate AC filter capsSleep mode would not be designed in Jedi product.

PROPOSE TO REJECT AND PROVIDE DETAILED REQUIREMENTS UNDER THE PLATFORM PROJECTWhen sleep mode is enabled, a number of power modules shall kept in on state to allow for sudden increase in load.The number of power modules shall be set- able - 0, 1, 2 or 3Background info:When power modules are turned off, they require 2-3 seconds to restart.

Requirement: Sleep mode instantaneous load step warning
Description: PROPOSE TO REJECT AND PROVIDE DETAILED REQUIREMENTS UNDER THE PLATFORM PROJECTWhen sleep mode is enabled, the system shall issue a warning to inform that ability to respond to an instantaneous load is reduced.
Refer child requirements

The UPS must include at bypass backfeed protection to ensure that no power is fed back to the bypass input terminals from the UPS output in the case where no bypass voltage source is present and a bypass static switch thyristor short-circuit.An external contactor or breaker would be suggested to install, which would be tuned on manually or external controller whereas it would be turned off by the IO control signal from UPS in Jedi design.There's no status feedback to UPS, so the de-active control IO would not be changed after bypass backfeed protection is triggered until the SBS MCU and IM MCU re-boot.

The detection of bypass backfeed would be executed by SBS controller, and de-actived by IO signal from IM controller in Jedi product.If the bypass input voltage is detected as within tolerance on all three phases there is no need to do bypass backfeed protection. Only if the bypass input voltage is below limit, or a phase is missing, the bypass backfeed protection must be active.The voltage across the SCRs of the static bypass switch must monitored by means of voltage measurements on both sides of the SCRs.- If a voltage difference can be measured, the SCRs are not shorted.- If a low voltage or no voltage is measured, the SCR is potentially shorted, except if UPS is in static bypass operation.{Image: F3F7E6D3-BA07-4467-B679-EC1809A5C242.bmp}It will not be possible to detect if all three SCRs are shorted using the above method, as the bypass voltage will be seen as within tolerance.

Requirement: Bypass backfeed protection behavior using a external contavtor or break
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Wants to ensure that no power is fed back into the bypass grid.Pre conditionsUPS has been properly installed.The bypass backfeed protection is done via a external contactor or breaker, which can be opened by the UPS automatically.Post conditionsNo power is accidentally fed back into the bypass grid.Main success scenario 1. Bypass input voltage is within tolerance on all three phases (refer to product spec).  2. Bypass backfeed contactor is turned on.  3. The bypass input voltage is below 50% or up 15% of the nominal system voltage on all three phases  4. Bypass backfeed contactor turns off after a given delay (refer to product spec) isolating the bypass grid from the UPS. Alternative scenariosScenario 1:NAScenario 2: 1. Bypass backfeed contactor is on. 2. One or two SCR(s) has/have been detected as shorted  3. Bypass backfeed contactor turns off after a given delay (refer to product spec) isolating the bypass grid from the UPS.Scenario 3:1. Bypass backfeed contactor is on.2. The bypass input voltage is above 15% of the nominal system voltage on one or more phases3. Bypass backfeed contactor turns off after a given delay (refer to product spec) isolating the bypass grid from the UPS. Scenario 4:NA Special requirementsNA  Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

The current status (open/closed) of the bypass backfeed contactor/breaker must be available to the user in the event log.Which would not be included in the Jedi project. for there is no status feedback signal from hardware design.

The UPS must monitor the bypass backfeed contactor and notify the user via an alarm and an event in the event log, if the contactor is not opened or closed correctly (closed when supposed to open and vice versa).There is no monitoring IO feedback in Jedi design.So there is no related status in the eventlog.

Description: The alarm posted, and the IO control signal status, to open the contactor or breaker,  must be persistent, meaning it cannot be cleared unless the controller detecting it (the SBCS & IM in JEDI) is rebooted.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The bypass backfeed protection trip has been activated.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The bypass backfeed protection trip has been de-activated

The current status (open/closed) of the mains backfeed contactor must be available to the user in the event log.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contactor has been opened.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contactor has been closed.
Market Requirements:Jedi shall be equipped with EPO (dry contacts)

The UPS must be able to detect if EPO is activated and react accordingly:- by tripping the required breakers (handled by EPO hardware circuit).- by either turning off the inverter or transfering to static bypass depending on the configuration done by the user.The user must be notified of EPO activation/deactivation via an alarm and an event in the event log.

Primary Actor(s)- User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser : Transfer UPS system to emergency off.Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power.Post conditionsAll power sources is disconnected and the UPS is either off operation or forced static bypass operation depending on the system configuration setting: "Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting.Main success scenario 1. UPS not in off operation and not in maintenance bypass  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. UPS enters forced static bypass Operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled) and stays in forced static bypass operation as long as EPO is active  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.  5. User deactivates EPO button  6. UPS stays in forced static bypass operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. UPS not in off operation and not in maintenance bypass  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. UPS enters off operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is disabled) and stays here as long as EPO is active.  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.  5. User deactivates EPO button  6. UPS stays in off operationScenario 2: 1. The UPS is in off operation and does not supply the load  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. The UPS stays in off operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled) and stays in off operation as long as EPO is active.  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.Scenario 3: 1. The UPS is in maintenance bypass operation  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. The UPS stays in maintenance bypass operation (no matter if "Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled or disabled)  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers. Scenario 4: 1. UPS not in off operation and not in maintenance bypass  2. User pushes the EPO button.  3. UPS enters off operation ("Transfer to static bypass on EPO" setting is enabled but no bypass is available), and stays in off operation as long as EPO is active  4. EPO hardware circuit will trip all required breakers.  5. User deactivates EPO button  6. UPS stays in off operationSpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issues
The user must be notified of EPO activation/deactivation via an alarm and an event in the event log.

The FSE shall be able to configure the product so that the load is transferred automatically (as soon as it is possible) to the inverter without any human effort. By default, the product shall transfer the load to the inverter following a command (from the display or UPS Tuner). This also applies when going out of the Maintenance Bypass position.

An inverter autostart mode must be available in the UPS. The UPS must have the possibility to start automatically when input voltage returns,  after a shutdown due to drained battery. The function will turn on the output voltage of the UPS.The function can be enabled or disabled by the user, and is only possible in a single UPS system and not available in a parallel UPS system. It is however allowed for parallel frequency converters with no energy storage connected.If the input voltage fails and the system has to run battery untill the battery is drained, the UPS will switch to bypass if bypass is available (in a dual mains system). When input voltage is reestablished, the UPS will switch to normal operation. This functionality can NOT be disabled.If instead the bypass input was not available, the UPS turns off the output voltage when the battery is drained. In this case the user has two possibilities when the input voltage returns.1.      If autostart function is disabled, the output voltage will stay off, until the user commands the UPS to start.2.      If autostart is enabled, the UPS will turn on the output voltage.The conditions for the UPS to automatically turn on the output are:1.      Autostart is enabled2.      When input voltage returns, the event prior to this must have been shutdown due to drained battery.3.      If the UPS went to bypass after running on battery, and the bypass input disappeared afterwards, the UPS will start automatically.

Requirement: Auto start on inverter must be user configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to enable and disable the auto start on inverter feature via a setting.
In the GVL product ""drained battery"" in the Auto start definition is defined asEither:Low DC shutdown activated.or:High current on battery terminals AND low DC warning activated.

Primary Actor(s)-          UPS-          UserStakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants supply for his load after shutdownPre conditionsUPS has been properly installed and shutdown due to depleted battery after a power outage and the load has been without power.Post conditionsUPS delivers a correct output voltage.Main success scenario 1. Mains 1 voltage is restored after outage.  2. Auto start is enabled.  3. UPS checks for Mains 1 availability, and if it’s within voltage/freq. quality limits.  4. Mains 1 is determined as available.  5. After 10 seconds UPS goes into normal operationAlternative scenarios For a parallel system (only valid if all UPS units in the parallel system are configured as frequency coverters without energy storage)   Scenario 1: 1. Mains 1 voltage is restored after outage.   2. Auto start is enabled. Mains 1 is determined as available.   3. UPS checks for Mains 1 availability, and if it’s within voltage/freq. quality limits.  4. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  5. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  6. After 10 seconds UPS goes into normal operation and the parallel system enters inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. Mains 1 voltage is restored after outage.   2. Auto start is enabled. Mains 1 is determined as available.   3. UPS checks for Mains 1 availability, and if it’s within voltage/freq. quality limits.  4. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  5. The minimum number of UPS units are not available.  6. The system stays off. System indicates that not enough UPS units are available.  7. Another UPS requests auto start on inverter.  8. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  9. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load.  10. After 10 seconds both UPS units enter normal operation and the parallel system enters inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

The Power Module fans must be controlled at suitable speed, so that the Power Module is adequately cooled while the energy consumption and noise of the fans are kept low. The speed must be determined based on the load on the Power Module and the ambient temperature.

The static bypass switch fans must be controlled at suitable speed, so that the static bypass switch is adequately cooled while the energy consumption and noise of the fans are kept low. The speed must be determined based on the output current and the ambient temperature.
The UPS must monitor its fans and report to the user if a fan is inoperable or not working correctly via an alarm and an event in the event log.

Power ratings not covered by the N+1 must be fault tolerant and continue operating with the remaining power module
An alarm is set when operating as fault tolerant to indicate reduced capacity

The UPS must include fault tolerance on power module level.This means, that a power module must be isolated from the rest of the UPS system and shut down should it be required, for example due to a surveillance detected fault. The remaining power module must then continue in inverter operation and supply conditioned power to the load, if the conditions allow it.

The behavior of the UPS, in case of a power module shutdown, must depend on the output load on the UPS, and whether or not the fault leading to the shutdown of a power module causes an output voltage waveform fault on the UPS. If a fault in a power module leads to an output voltage waveform fault, the UPS must always transfer to forced static bypass. The given power module must then be isolated and shut down. If the load can be supplied by the remaining power module, the UPS must return to inverter operation after a couple of seconds. If not, the UPS must remain in forced static bypass. If the power module fault does not result in an output voltage waveform fault, the UPS must stay in inverter operation if the load can be supplied by the remaining power module. If not, the UPS must eventually transfer to forced static bypass, when the overload timer has timed out.

If one or more power modules become inoperable, the remaining power module(s) must dynamically increase their power rating if possible, so that the UPS is still able to deliver as much power as possible.This is possible if the UPS is a firmware derated version.For example, a 60kW UPS with two 50kW power modules is able to deliver 30kW per power module under nominal conditions, but if one power module becomes inoperable the power delivered by the remaining power module can be increased, so that the UPS is still able to deliver 50kW.Any difference in supported battery voltage ranges of the different power modules must be taken into account when increasing the power.

If one or more power modules become inoperable, the remaining power module(s) must dynamically increase their available charge power if possible, so that the UPS is still able to deliver as much charge power as possible.Under nominal conditions the power modules will share the charge power, but if a power module becomes inoperable, the remaining power module(s) must increase the available charge power to compensate for the charge power lost because of the inoperable power module.

If the UPS is in a state where power module fault tolerance is active (a power module is shut down and the remaining power module is supplying the load from inverter), the user must be notified about this via alarms and events in the event log. Details about which power module is inoperable and the cause must be available.

The calculation of the output load percentage must be based on the power available from the operational power modules in the UPS.This means that if a power module becomes inoperable, the total available UPS power must be adjusted down according to the power lost due to the inoperable power module.

It must be possible for the UPS to operate in inverter operation with one power module in normal operation while another is in battery operation. In this case the UPS operation mode must be shown as battery operation.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: Power module is operable.Event instance indicates which power module
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Replace power module or contact Schneider ElectricDescription: Power module is inoperable.Event instance indicates which power module

The UPS must support power module redundancy (N+1) together with scalability.The power module redundancy option must be controlled via a setting available in display and UPS Tuner. If a scalable UPS is configured for N+1 all power modules present in the UPS must still be used for power, but if the load on the UPS is above what can be supplied by N number of power modules, a power module redundancy alarm must be posted. Scalability with N+1 – examples:- If a scalable UPS with 3 power modules (available power rating is 150 kW) is configured for N+1, the available power rating must still be 150 kW. - If the output load on a scalable N+1 UPS with 3 power modules (available power rating is 150 kW) increases above 100 kW a power module redundancy lost alarm must be posted but the UPS must continue in inverter operation (no overload). - If a power module becomes inoperable in a scalable N+1 UPS with 4 power modules, the available power rating must be decreased from 200 kW to 150 kW, and if the output load is above 100 kW, a power module redundancy lost alarm must be posted but the UPS must continue in inverter operation (no overload). - If a power module is removed from a scalable N+1 UPS with 3 power modules, the available power rating must be decreased from 150 kW to 100 kW, and if the output load is above 50 kW, a power module redundancy lost alarm must be posted but the UPS must continue in inverter operation (no overload).
It must be possible for the user to configure if the UPS has power module redundancy (N+1) or not (N+0) via the display and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Notify user via alarm is power module redundancy is lost
Description: If the power module redundancy is lost the user must be notified via an alarm.The redundancy can be lost either because a power module becomes inoperable, or because the output load increases above what the N number of power modules can supply.
Setting for configuring the number of redundant power modules in the UPS (internal redundancy).Range: N+0, N+1.Default value: N+0.

Requirement: Media Measurements Accuracy ( Current, Voltage & Frequency)
Description: The Measurements available on Display / NMC and Others Communication media must be into the following Accuracy  :less than Offset +/-5A   &  Reading +/-3% for Current measurements (all windows)less than Offset +/-0.5V   &  Reading +/-1% for Voltage measurements (all windows)less than +/- 0.3 Hz  for Frequency measurements (all windows)
SH Reason why: The customer compare the Display measurement to his multi-meter and don't link big differences

Description: ECO mode allows the UPS to be configured to use requested static bypass operation (load supplied though bypass) as the preferred operation mode when circumstances allow it, either always or none.

It must be possible to configure if the ECO Mode feature is available for the customer or not.  Only if there is a specific wish from the customer to use ECO Mode, it can be made available by the FSR via this configuration.

Requirement: Disable high efficiency mode via input contact
Description: It must be possible to disable high efficiency mode via a configurable input contact.If this input contact is activated, the UPS is prevented from entering high efficiency mode or will exit any active high efficiency mode.

Requirement: Prevent transfer to high efficiency mode if battery test is running
Description: To avoid that the UPS system automatically to high efficiency mode while the UPS is in the middle of a battery test ('battery runtime calibration test' or 'battery self-test'), any transfers to high efficiency mode must be temporarily disabled while the battery test is running.

Requirement: Notified operation mode change to high efficiency mode
Description: The user must be notified via the HMI and UPS Tuner if the UPS is about to change to high efficiency mode.If the UPS is configured to use high efficiency mode but is awaiting a timeout before it will transfer to high efficiency mode, the user must be made aware that UPS is about to transfer to high efficiency mode.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to minimize power loss in the system by using static bypass as the preferred operation mode.Pre conditionsECO mode is enabled.Post conditionsMain success scenario 1. The UPS has been in inverter operation for at least 30 seconds.  2. The UPS checks that Mains 2 is within tolerance and that bypass is available.  3. The UPS  checks that ECO mode is allowed*.  4. The UPS changes to requested static bypass operation and indicates it is due to ECO mode.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 2: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. ECO mode is disabled or no longer allowed*.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 3: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as always allowed*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. When the UPS has been in inverter operation for at least 30 seconds it will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 4:(not in Jedi) 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as only allowed at a specific time and day of the week*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. The UPS will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode when it reaches the next calendar time interval where ECO mode is allowed*.Scenario 5: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation (not output overload).    3. The UPS changes to forced static bypass operation and stays there as long as the fault is present.Scenario 6: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The UPS output is overloaded.    3. The UPS changes to inverter operation and overload timer starts counting.Scenario 7: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains input becomes out of tolerance but the bypass input is still within tolerance.    3. The UPS stays in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 8: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation (not output overload).  3. The UPS changes to forced static bypass operation  4. The severe fault is no longer present.  5. UPS transfers to inverter operation.  6. After 10 minutes the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 9: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available.  3. The UPS changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available  5. After 10 minutes the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO modeScenario 10: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 1 and Mains 2 become out of tolerance.  3. The UPS changes to inverter operation (battery operation) immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available  5. After 30 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 11: 1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. EPO is activated  3. The UPS changes to off operation  4. EPO is deactivated  5. The user pushes the inverter on button.    6. The UPS changes to inverter operation  7. After 30 seconds the UPS returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Special requirements*ECO mode allowed: It can be configured when it is allowed to enter ECO mode. ECO mode can be set as never allowed, always allowed, or only allowed at a specific time and day of the week (calender time interval).It is required that the battery is operational to be able to enter ECO Mode or ECOnversion.The following battery related conditions can prevent the UPS from entering ECO Mode and ECOnversion...- Battery voltage below shutdown level- Battery voltage below warning level- Battery voltage collapse- Invalid battery configuration- Battery capacity is below acceptable level (the nominal available battery capacity is below the minimum level according to the current UPS output load)- External battery monitor fault (only if an external battery monitor is present)- Battery room ventilation fault- Flywheel inoperable (only if flywheel is present)- Modular battery fuse blown (only if modular batteries are present)- No batteries connected- Battery boost SCR not closedTechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to minimize power loss in the system by using static bypass as the preferred operation mode.Pre conditionsECO mode is enabled.Post conditionsMain success scenario 1. The parallel master UPS has been in inverter operation for at least 30 seconds.  2. The parallel master UPS checks that Mains 2 is within tolerance and that bypass is available.  3. The parallel master UPS checks that ECO mode is allowed* both for itself and for all parallel slave UPS units.  4. The system changes to requested static bypass operation and indicates it is due to ECO mode.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available on one or more parallel UPS units.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 2: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. ECO mode is disabled or no longer allowed* on one or more of the parallel UPS units.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.Scenario 3: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as always allowed*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button on one parallel UPS.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. When the parallel system has been in inverter operation for at least 30 seconds it will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 4: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode and ECO mode is set as only allowed at a specific time and day of the week*.  2. The user pushes the inverter on button on one parallel UPS.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. The parallel system will return to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode when it reaches the next calendar time interval where ECO mode is allowed*.Scenario 5a: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. One parallel UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation.    3. The remaining parallel UPS units can carry the load.  4. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately and the UPS with a severe fault transfers to static bypass standby.Scenario 5b: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. One parallel UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation.    3. The remaining parallel UPS units cannot carry the load.  4. The parallel system changes to forced static bypass operation and stays there as long as the fault is present.Scenario 6: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. The parallel system output is overloaded.    3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation and overload timer starts counting.Scenario 7: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains input becomes out of tolerance on one or more parallel UPS units  but the bypass input is still within tolerance on all parallel UPS units.    3. The parallel system stays in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 8: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. One parallel UPS has a severe fault that requires it to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. The remaining parallel UPS units cannot carry the load.  4. The parallel system changes to forced static bypass operation and stays there as long as the fault is present.  5. The severe fault is no longer present.  6. The parallel system transfers to inverter operation.  7. After 10 minutes the parallel system returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Scenario 9: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance or bypass is no longer available on one or more parallel UPS units.  3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available on all parallel UPS units.  5. After 10 minutes the parallel system returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO modeScenario 10: 1. The parallel system is in requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.  2. Mains 1 and Mains 2 become out of tolerance on one or more parallel UPS units.  3. The parallel system changes to inverter operation immediately.  4. Mains 2 becomes within tolerance and bypass is available on all parallel UPS units.   5. After 30 seconds the parallel system returns to requested static bypass operation due to ECO mode.Special requirements*ECO mode allowed: It can be configured when it is allowed to enter ECO mode. ECO mode can be set as never allowed, always allowed, or only allowed at a specific time and day of the week (calender time interval).It is required that the battery is operational to be able to enter ECO Mode or ECOnversion.The following battery related conditions can prevent the UPS from entering ECO Mode and ECOnversion...- Battery voltage below shutdown level- Battery voltage below warning level- Battery voltage collapse- Invalid battery configuration- Battery capacity is below acceptable level (the nominal available battery capacity is below the minimum level according to the current UPS output load)- External battery monitor fault (only if an external battery monitor is present)- Battery room ventilation fault- Flywheel inoperable (only if flywheel is present)- Modular battery fuse blown (only if modular batteries are present)- No batteries connected- Battery boost SCR not closedTechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

As scalable selling points: 100, 150, 200, 250kWAs redundant selling points: 50 (N+1), 100 (N+1), 150 (N+1), 200 (N+1), 250 (N+1) kWFor MVO, 250kW 5+0 config, leave space & connection for the 6th PM. - In a scalable UPS only one power module must be expected to always be present, meaning no alarms must be shown even if there are less than 2 power modules present in the UPS (below 100 kW). - The nominal power rating of the UPS must decide the maximum allowed number of power modules to be present. The nominal power rating must always be fixed at 300kW, so maximum allowed number of power modules must always be 6. - Any number of power modules between the minimum allowed number and the maximum allowed number must be optional in a scalable UPS. - As long as the number of present power modules in the UPS, no matter their physical location, is equal to or above 1 and equal to or below 6, no alarms for incorrect number of power modules must be shown.- If an optional power module is removed (not present) from the scalable UPS, no alarms must be shown for the removed power module. If communication is lost to an optional power module that is present it must still be alarmed. Only if an optional power module is removed physically no alarms must be shown. - As soon as a power module is detected as present, any alarms related to this power module must be shown to the user. - If no power modules are detected present in a scalable UPS, it must be alarmed to the user that no power modules are available in the UPS.

Requirement: Power rating shown to the user in a scalable UPS
Description: In a scalable UPS, the UPS power rating shown to the user in display, UPS Tuner and NMC, must not be a fixed value based on the nominal UPS power rating. Instead, the shown UPS power rating must be updated dynamically depending on the actual number of power modules populated in the UPS.

Requirement: UPS power rating shown in display top bar
Description: The top bar of the display screens shows 'Galaxy PX' and the power rating of the UPS.As the power rating of a scalable UPS is dynamic, the shown power rating in the display must also change dynamically depending on the number of power modules present in the UPS.
List of supported UPS power frame types:Valid model numbers are:GVM2GFRM100K300D
List of supported UPS power module types:Valid model numbers are0G-PM50KD - Power Module 50KW

Requirement: Prevent startup at illegal power configuration
Description: If an illegal UPS power configuration is detected during power-up, the UPS must warn the user via an alarm and an event in the event log, and it must not be possible to turn on the UPS (UPS must stay in off operation).Child requirements list the illegal configurations to be checked.
The UPS must check, that the power frame type/size is correct according to the given UPS standard power configuration. If it is not correct an alarm and event must be posted.

Requirement: Warn about limitations in current power configuration
Description: If a limitation, due to the present UPS power configuration, is detected, the UPS must warn the user via an alarm and an event in the event log. It must still possible to turn on the UPS, but the functionality will be limited depending on the given configuration.Child requirements list the power configurations to be checked.

If no power module(s) are detected present in the UPS, the user must be warned via an alarm and an event in the event log.  Power module(s) must be indicated as inoperable and any operation modes requirering the power module(s) must be unavailable.

The UPS must check, that the power module type(s) present in the UPS is/are correct according to the given UPS standard power configuration. If it is not correct an alarm and event must be posted.If an unsupported module type (power module) is inserted/detected while the UPS is powered and running, it must not force the UPS to shut down or turn off, but the UPS must still warn the user via an alarm and an event in the event log. The unsupported module must not become operable.

When an UPS is supplied by a generator source on the input, the strength of the source during a load step (e.g. the UPS changing from battery to normal operation) can vary.If the source is not able to handle the speed of the load change, then the source frequency will decrease risking that the UPS returns to battery operation caused by low input frequency.In order to avoid this, the UPS must ramp in the input current over a certain time, when going from battery to normal operation.

If the configured input ramp-in time is not long enough to support the given generator source, an adaptive input ramp-in feature must step into action.The adaptive current ramp-in checks for the following scenario during ramp-in…Input frequency is dropping below 45Hz.If the scenario is present, the PFC input ramp-in time must automatically be changed to the value of 40 seconds and the ramp-in must be completed at this speed. After this, the ramp-in time must automatically be reset to the configured value.If the user configurable ramp-in time is set to a value above 40 seconds, the adaptive ramp-in must be disabled (the adaptive ramp-in time is set to the same value as the configured ramp-in time).

Setting for the input ramp-in timeRange: 1 second to 300 seconds.Default value: 10 seconds.  Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:If the UPS energy storage is not set to batteries (if supported by the specific product), the input ramp-in time must always be 1 second and not configurable .
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input ramp-in time - setting has been changed.

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input ramp-in has been completed.
The setting for the ramp-in time must automatically be kept the same for all UPS units in a parallel system.

Overload to be handle by the UPS into Normal Mode & Battery Mode
100% continous110% for 1hour125% for 10 minutes150% for 1 minute250%  for 20ms
The UPS must be able to handle an overload on the output, so that it can operate on inverter at a certain overload for a given time before it transfers to static bypass or turns off.
The UPS must support the following overload intervals:>100% to <110%>110% to <125%?125% to <150%>150% The allowed overload time for each inteval will be different.

When in output overload, the UPS must increment a timer. When this timer runs out, the UPS must either transfer to static bypass or turn inverter off and drop the load, depending on the circumstances.The timeout value of the overload timer will be different for each of the overload intervals, and can also differ depending on the operation mode of the UPS (battery or normal operation). The exact overload timeout values are defined for each given UPS product.The overload timer must count down when an overload is removed (load < 100%), so that the UPS cannot be overloaded again for the full overload time, right after an overload has been removed.
The user must be notified via an alarm and an entry in the event log in case of an inverter overload.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if inverter overload is active
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if inverter overload is active.
The user must be warned if the UPS output load is getting close to an user configurable overload level via a warning alarm and a configurable output relay.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if output overload warning is active
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if output overload warning is active.
Behavior scenarios specific to single UPS.

Requirement: Overload Higher Than 150% - Bypass not available
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.     Pre conditionsUPS system in inverter on operation, Bypass not available Post conditionsOutput voltage is reduced or load is disconnected. Main success scenario1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 150%.3. UPS reports system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.6. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load significantly higher than 150%.3. UPS reports system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected. Alternative scenario 2 (principle sequence description if load changes while overloaded)1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 150%.3. UPS reports system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. The connected load is reduced to below 125% and above 100% when a percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 150% load has elapsed.6. The remaining overload time at is now calculated to be the remaining percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 125% load. 7. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the remaining overload time has elapsed.8. Load is disconnected after a certain time limit, if an output voltage fault is detected.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Overload Higher Than 150% - Bypass out of tolerance
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : To protect hardware from damage and overheat.     Pre conditionsUPS system in inverter on operation, Bypass out of tolerance (voltage and/or frequency out of tolerance, UPS is synchronized to Mains 2) Post conditionsOutput voltage is reduced or Forced static bypass operation overloaded. Main success scenario1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the overload time has elapsed.6. UPS into forced static bypass operation, if an output voltage fault is detected.Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load significant higher than 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. UPS immediately reduce load to 150% by reducing output voltage.5. UPS into forced static bypass operation, if an output voltage fault is detected. Alternative scenario 2 (principle sequence description if load changes while overloaded)1. UPS is in normal operation or battery operation2. UPS is overloaded, with load just above 150%.3. UPS report system overloaded.4. UPS reduces load to 150% by reducing output voltage. .5. The connected load is reduced to below 125% and above 100% when a percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 150% load has elapsed.6. The remaining overload time at is now calculated to be the remaining percentage of the total allowed overload time at max 125% load. 7. UPS reduces load to 100% by reducing output voltage, when the remaining overload time has elapsed.8. UPS into forced static bypass operation, if an output voltage fault is detected. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

It must be prevented that the UPS toggles in and out of forced static bypass operation continuously within a short time period. Therfore, if the UPS enters forced static bypass operation 10 times within 75 seconds, it must be locked in forced static bypass operation.The user must be able to unlock the system again by activating the on button (allowing the system to return to inverter operation)

Requirement: User must be notified if UPS is locked in bypass
Description: The user must be notified if the UPS has been locked in forced static bypass operation due to the bypass toggle handling.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The system is no longer locked in bypass operation.

Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: The system has toggled between inverter operation and bypass operation more than 10 times within 75 seconds. Please press inverter ON button to transfer back to normal operation.Description: The system is locked in bypass operation.

Requirement: Transfer to forced static bypass with bypass out of tolerance
Description: The UPS must be able to transfer to forced static bypass operation even if the bypass input is out of tolerance with regards to voltage and frequency, or if the inverter is not synchronized to the bypass input.compare with odin

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass with a break
Description: The UPS must be able to transfer to forced static bypass operation with a break in the output voltage if the inverter is not synchronized to the bypass input.

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass when bypass is out of tolerance must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if the UPS shall transfer to forced static bypass with bypass out of tolerance, or it shall instead turn off the output.This setting determines if the UPS is alowed to transfer to, and stay in forced static bypass operation, when bypass is out of tolerance, meaning that the RMS voltage is above or below the output tolerance set by the user

Requirement: Transfer break time to static bypass must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the break time when transferring to static bypass with a break.

Requirement: User initiated transfer to static bypass with break must be confirmed
Description: If the transfer to static bypass with a break is requested by the user, a warning must be displayed to allow the user to confirm the transfer.

Setting to configure break duration in ms. when shifting to an asynchronous bypass.  Range: 8 to 1000 msDefault: 10 msRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance setting
Description: Setting to allow transfer to static bypass even if bypass is out of tolerance. Range Yes/noDefault value: Yes Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Confirm or abort using the displayDescription: Off button has been pushed while inverter is on and with no bypass available. User must confirm that the UPS turns off the power to the load or transfers to static bypass with a break.

Requirement: Bypass open transition time - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Bypass open transition time - setting has been changed

Requirement: Transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance - setting has been changed
The UPS must automatically transfer to forced static bypass (emergency bypass) should the core control of the UPS stop responding and/or reboot.
The UPS must transfer to emergency bypass within 5 ms. or faster after the core control has stopped responding.

Requirement: Emergency bypass not allowed in parallel system - wave2
Description: When the UPS is part of a parallel UPS system it must not be able to transfer to emergency bypass. All transfers in and out of static bypass must be controlled by the parallel master.

Requirement: UPS core control reboot - FW change is needed
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Behavior when watchdog is active.Pre conditionsThe UPS is either in off, normal or bypass operation and batteries are connected.Post conditionsUPS must supply conditioned power to load if possible.Main success scenario 1. UPS is in inverter operation or requested static bypass operation or ECO mode(the bypass input voltage is within configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases).  2. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding).  3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. UPS core control will try to restart.  5. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will return to inverter operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1a: 1. UPS is in inverter operation. 2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance) 3. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding). 4. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  5. UPS core control will try to restart.  6. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will return to inverter operation.Scenario 1b: 1. UPS is in inverter operation. 2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to not allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance) 3. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding). 4. UPS is transferred to off operation.  5. UPS core control will try to restart.  6. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will stay in off operation.Scenario 2: 1. UPS is in forced static bypass operation.  2. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding).   3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. UPS core control will try to restart.  5. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will return to inverter operation if possible else it will return to forced static bypass operation. Scenario 3: 1. UPS is in off operation.  2. Watchdog is triggered on UPS core control (controller not responding)  3. UPS stays in off operation  and does not transfer to emergency static bypass operation.  4. UPS core control will try to restart.  5. If UPS core control restart is successful UPS will stay in off operation. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: UPS core control stops responding - FW change is needed
Description: Primary Actor(s) -          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              : Behavior when UPS core control stops responding.Pre conditionsThe UPS is either in off, normal or bypass operation and batteries are connected.Post conditionsUPS must supply conditioned power to load if possible.Main success scenario  1. UPS is in inverter operation or requested static bypass operation or ECO mode or ECOnversion mode (the bypass input voltage is within configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases).  2. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  5. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will return to inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1a: 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance)  3. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  4. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  5. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  6. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will return to inverter operation.Scenario 1b: 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. The bypass input voltage is below configured bypass voltage tolerance on all three phases (UPS configured to not allow transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance)  3. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  4. UPS stays in inverter operation, but SBS is transferred to off operation.  5. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  6. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will stay in inverter operation, SBS will transfer to ready state.Scenario 2: 1. UPS is in forced static bypass operation.  2. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  3. UPS is transferred to emergency static bypass operation.  4. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  5. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will return to inverter operation if possible else it will return to forced static bypass operation.Scenario 3: 1. UPS is in off operation.  2. UPS core control stops sending heartbeat request messages on UEP protocol to SBS for 150ms.  3. UPS stays in off operation and does not transfer to emergency static bypass operation.  4. SBS will timeout communication and start broadcast heartbeats to core control.  5. If UPS core control reestablish communication successful, UPS will stay in off operation.

Requirement: General status of static bypasss switch
Description: A general status of the static bypass switch must be available to the user as alarms and events. The status must be reported as either:- OK: The SBS is fully operational- Warning: The SBS is fully operational but needs a technical check.- Inoperable: The SBS is inoperable, meaning the UPS cannot transfer to static bypass.

Description: The UPS must report the current operation mode of the SBSC to the user via events in the event log.

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Description: Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: The static bypass switch needs a technical check but is still fully operational.

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Description: Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: Static bypass switch is inoperable. UPS is prevented from going into static bypass operation.

The SBS must be able to monitor the bypass input and the output, and detect if these are not within the defined tolerances. The following parameters must be monitored:- Voltage - RMS for each phase L1, L2 and L3 of  bypass input and output- Frequency of  bypass input and output- Voltage - DC on output.

Requirement: Out of tolerance detection must be logged
Description: The user must be notified via events in the event log and alarms in the alarm list, if a voltage is detected as being out of tolerance by the voltage quality detection.

Requirement: Static bypass switch DC voltage no longer detected on output
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Description: NADescription: Static bypass switch no longer detects a DC voltage on the output

DetectionHigh Threshold1Recovery ThresholdOn delayOff delayDC failure on output90V70 V5ms500ms 1 When system is configurated as 220Vp_n, 230Vp_n, 240Vp_n, 255Vp_n and 277Vp_n mode, the DC high threshold is 90V and the recovery is 70V.When system is 115Vp_n, 120p_n and 127Vp_n, the threshold is 70V and the recovery is 40V.

The UPS must check whether the SBS hardware and firmware are compatible with the rest of the UPS system, and the user must be notified via alarms/events if this is not the case.Furthermore, the SBSC firmware version must be stored in the UPS event log to improve debugging and diagnostics possibilities.

Requirement: Battery voltage & battery fuse rated voltage - ?HW

The choice above reflect the legacy from GalaxyVX where a 500Volt fuse is applied for up to 40 blocks/string (nominal 480Volt, Charge 588V)

UPS shall be able to monitor temperature in external battery cabinet4pcs Temperature Sensor shall be delivered with the UPS, with cable for adjacent battery cabinet.temperature sensor can be configure present or not
please refer to feature bricks WHAT36692 and children requirement

R&D: Same function as GVM/GVXMarket Requirements:YesWithout automatic battery test / calibrationmanual battery test / calibrationWish to avoid the battery discharge procedure to calibrate the autonometer
System shall have a means to disconnect batteries when battery is below 1.25V/cell  (?) in lead acid caseSystem shall disconnect from batteries when system is off for more than 2 weeks
Market Requirements:Yes
System shall be able to start on batteries without grid being available
Shall support Common Batteries for Parallel SystemCommon battery shall include both single and split string battery

Requirement: Simplified common battery in parallel system
Description: The UPS must support to operate with one common battery in a parallel system configuration, so that all the parallel UPS units share the same battery. For the simplified common battery feature:- The charge current, state of charge, remaning runtime and charger operation mode must be controlled, calculated and set individually by each parallel UPS as if they where running on individual batteries.- The system must not check that all relevant battery settings are the same on all parallel UPS units. It is up to the user to verify this manually.
It nust be possible for the user to configure if a common battery is used in the parallel system via UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery settings configurability with common battery
Description: When system is configured for common battery only the FSR must be able to configure the battery settings via UPS Tuner, except the general battery settings which must also be available to the customer via the display.

Requirement: Battery settings that must be identical on all parallel UPS units in a common battery configuration
Description: The following battery related settings must be configured identically on all parallel UPS units in a common battery configuration:Specific battery settings only available to FSR when UPS is configured for common battery:- Number of battery strings setting- Battery type setting- Number of batteries in series setting- Number of cells in battery setting- Battery block capacity setting- Battery midpoint present setting- Low battery shutdown level setting- Float charge voltage setting- Boost charge mode enable setting- Boost charge voltage setting- Boost charge time setting- Equalization charge voltage setting- Equalization charge time setting- Battery temperature reference setting- Charge current rate (CA rate) setting- Battery deep discharge allowed setting- Battery runtime calculation method setting- Battery runtime calculation value 1 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 2 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 3 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 4 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 5 setting- Battery runtime calculation value 6 setting- Automatic battery disconnect setting?- Battery temperature monitoring- Maximum allowed string discharge current setting? (Li-ion)- Energy storage internal surveillance enable setting? (Li-ion)- Input ramp-in time setting?General battery settings both available to FSR and customer when UPS is configured for common battery:- Number of battery cabinets setting- Battery cabinet SKU number setting- BB1 present setting- BB2 present setting- High battery temperature level setting- Low battery temperature level setting- Battery runtime low warning threshold setting- Auto boost charge mode setting- Auto cyclic charge mode setting- Scheduled battery self-test interval setting- Scheduled battery self-test time setting- Scheduled battery self-test day of week setting- Charge power setting- Maximum battery charge power level when on generator - setting

The user must configure the battery capacity in each parallel UPS units equal to the total capacity of the common battery.The system must then automatically calculate the actual battery capacity available to each UPS by dividing the total capacity of the common battery by the number of parallel UPS units configured as present.

Requirement: Common battery allowed for both 2-wire and 3-wire battery
Description: Common battery in parallel system must be allowed for a 3-wire battery configuration.2-wire battery configuration is better to have.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test must be disabled
Description: The battery runtime calibration test function must be disabled when simplified common battery in parallel system is enabled.The reason is that this test will not work correctly. Even if test is started on all parallel UPS units at the same time, one UPS might exit before another and start charging the battery. This will interfere with the test on the other UPS units.

Requirement: Common battery only allowed for classic battery solutions
Description: Only classic battery solutions are allowed to be used as common battery for a parallel system. Modular battery solutions are not supported.

Requirement: Battery types supported for common battery
Description: Only VRLA is supported for common battery in a parallel system in Jedi.

Requirement: Individual battery breaker for each UPS
Description: There must be one individual battery breaker for each UPS connected to the common battery.

Requirement: Individual battery temperature sensorfor each UPS
Description: There must be one individual battery temperature sensor for each UPS connected to the common battery.

The standard battery LCM (life cycle monitoring) feature must be handled individually on each parallel UPS with common battery. There is no synchonization of battery LCM data between UPS units in the simplified common battery feature.

The standard battery CBLCM (condition based life cycle monitoring) feature must be handled individually on each parallel UPS with common battery. There is no synchonization of battery CBLCM data between UPS units in the simplified common battery feature.

Setting to configure if a common battery is used in a parallel system.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: DisableRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Common battery - setting has been changed
Maximum charge voltage shall be 685Vdc when the block number is 48.
< 5% C20 (5 min backup time)
Enable independent ethernet port to support Advanced Lithium Ion BMSBMS Protocol to be decided in seperate projectLithium Iron Battery is not supported in Jedi

The user must be informed about the general battery status (OK or inoperable) via an event and an alarm.The conditions for activating the ""battery is not working correctly"" alarm should be the same as for indicating battery inoperable in the UPS mimic. Meaning one or more of the below conditions are true (depending on which features are available/enabled in the product):- Battery voltage out of tolerance (high and low)- Battery voltage collapse- Battery configuration invalid- Battery capacity is below minimum acceptable level- Battery room ventilation inoperable- External battery monitoring detected fault- Battery fuse blown or battery relay is not working correctly- Battery not connected
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery is working correctly.
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Please contact Schneider Electric.Description: A battery is not working correctly.

The user must be able to configure the UPS to support different battery configurations.The following parameters must be configurable by the user:- Battery type (VRLA, Ni-Cd, Li-Ion etc. depending on what is supported by the UPS).- Battery block capacity (Ah)*.- Number of cells in battery- Number of batteries in series- Number of battery strings*.*It must be possible to set this individually for each battery breaker present in the system. If the battery breaker is open (or set as not present), the total Ah connected through this given battery breaker can then be subtracted from the total Ah connected to the UPS.The UPS must notify the user, using alarms and the event log, if the battery configuration done is invalid.

Requirement: Support for battery without a midpoint
Description: It must be possible for the UPS to support battery without a midpiont.
Support 4 battery breaker boxes/kits for extended runtime and redundancy purposes
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery configuration is correct..

Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check and correct battery settings.Description: The configuration of the settings for number of batteries in series, number of cells in battery and nominal cell voltage does not match the battery voltage range of the UPS.

It must be possible for the FSR to configure the UPS to use a custom battery. In a custom battery setup, it must be possible to manually configure all the basic battery settings, which are automatically set in a SKU-based battery configuration (see list of these settings in the table in WHAT41061 - "Fixed basic battery settings for standard battery cabinet SKUs").In addition to the basic settings from the SKU-based battery configuration, the following settings must also be available for a custom battery configuration (also see the list of requirements traced to this requirement under the "Traceability" tab):{Image: F4C5183F-1C18-46B6-BD59-7EB1BD5C4BE2.bmp}

Requirement: Settings to be available for custom battery configuration
Description: Some battery settings must always be available for the user to configure, no matter if a SKU-based or custom battery configuration is selected:In Jedi. only custom battery is supported.{Image: BF62710A-257A-4BB1-BF7D-2FE5951D2BFC.bmp}(also see the list of requirements traced to this requirement under the "Traceability" tab).remove below setting:  we do not support auto cyclic in wave 1Auto boost charge mode settingAuto cyclic charge mode settingAuto cyclic charge mode floating time settingAuto cyclic charge mode resting time settingAuto cyclic charge mode minimum restingManual battery self-test time settingManual battery self-test modeManual battery self-test voltage setting

The UPS must validate that the entered combination of settings for a custom battery configuration is correct and supported by the UPS.If the configuration is not supported, the user must be notified via an alarm and an event in the event log, and the invalid settings must be indicated in the battery configuration screen(s).

Only 380V - 415VThe UPS must check that the battery configuration is within the minimum and maximum supported battery voltage of the UPS:Total battery voltage = number of batteries in series * number of cells in battery * cell charge voltage.(cell charge voltage must take into account float, boost and equalization charge mode) The allowed battery voltage range depends on the UPS system voltage and power rating as described in requirement.Acceptable battery configurations50kW (380-415V) output power25kW (200-220V) output powerSystem voltage configuration380V400V415V200V208V220VNominal output power50kW25kWNominal battery voltage supported384V-576V (32-48, 12V per block)384V-480V (32-40, 12V per block)Maximum charge voltage691V(2.4x6x48)  change with differrent blocks number600V?Minimum end-of-discharge voltage (100% load)460V(1.6x6x48) change with differrent blocks number307V
The UPS must monitor the voltage of the connected energy storage, and report to the user if it is out of tolerance using alarms and the event log.

The UPS must monitor the battery voltage, and detect if it arises above a defined high warning level and a defined high shutdown level.If the battery voltage arises above the warning level, the charger must be turned off, and not turned on again untill the battery voltage is below the warning level.It must be reported to the user, via alarms and events, both in the case where the battery voltage reaches the warning level and in case it reaches the shutdown level.
The battery high voltage warning level must be:Lead-acid:2.53 V/cell

If the energy storage is not available, for example due to a faulty battery or an open battery breaker, when the UPS transfers to battery operation, the UPS must be able to detect this fast enough to transfer to forced static bypass (if available) without dropping the load.To enable this, the UPS must monitor the battery voltage, and detect if it suddenly collapses (drops be low a defined level).It must be reported to the user, via alarms and events, if the battery voltage collapses.
The battery voltage collapse level must be at 0.55*nominal battery voltage.The battery voltage collapse clear condition level must be at 0.605*nominal battery voltage (corresponds to 10% hysteresis).

The low battery voltage shutdown level must be dynamic based on the CA discharge rate (except for NiCd batteries, where it must be at a fixed level).The low battery shutdown level must be based on the lowest value (configurable) at a discharge CA rate of 3 and above, and then dynamically increased as the discharge CA rate is lowered (as illustrated on the below figure):  {Image: 8F638D4C-B9AA-4C1A-8356-BA75AE22A9C6.bmp}In the figure above the value for low battery shutdown level has been set to 1.6V/cell. The low battery warning level must be calculated based on the low battery shutdown level with an offset of 0.1V/cell.

Requirement: User configurable low battery shutdown level
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the low battery shutdown level for the UPS.

Setting for low battery shutdown level setting in volt/cell. Lead-acid:Range:  1.60 - 1.75 volt/cellDefault: 1.60 volt/cellNiCd:Range: 0.5-1.1 V/cellDefault: 1.00V/cellLi-ion:Range 2.0-3.2 V/cellDefault:  3.0V/cell
