Information about if the batteries are currently being charged, discharged or are resting, must be available to the user as a status and as events in the event log.
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The load is drawing more power than the UPS can draw from the input, causing the UPS to draw power from the batteries
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS batteries are resting.
Status indicating if the battery is currently being charged or resting, discharged or is resting.Possible values: Charging, discharging, resting.

When the battery is either fully recharged or fully discharged, this information must be available to the user as events in the event log.- Batteries are fully charged when the estimated charge level is 98% or above.- Batteries are fully discharged when the estimated charge level is 4% or below.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Batteries are fully charged (the estimated charge level is 98% or above)
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Batteries are fully discharged (the estimated charge level is 4% or below)
Float charge is the basic charge function available on all types of batteries and automatically initiated by the charger.

It must be possible for the user to manually initiate float charge if the UPS is currently in boost or equalization charge mode.It must be logged in the event log if manual float charge is activated by the user.

Requirement: Float charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the float charge voltage.
Setting to configure the battery float charge. Range and default value depends on battery type: Lead-acid:Range: 2.23V to 2.30VDefault: 2.27V/cell
Activate float charge via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.This command aborts an ongoing boost or equalization charge.

Requirement: Float charge voltage - setting changed - not support
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Float charge voltage - setting has been changed

Requirement: Float charge activated by user- not support
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Float charge has been activated by user.
No matter the configuration, boost charging must only be allowed for lead-acid batteries.

Requirement: Boost charging allowed must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if boost charge mode is allowed or not.
It must be possible for the user to manually initiate (and abort) a single boost charge to be conducted.It must be logged in the event log if manual boost charge is activated or aborted by the user.

An automatic boost charge function must be available. The automatic boost charge must transfer the charger to boost charger mode after the system has been in battery operation. To avoid boost charging fully charged batteries, the boost charge mode must be exited 30 seconds after being initiated, if charger has not reached current limitation (only on automatic boost charge).It must be possible to enable and disable the automatic boost charge mode.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Requirement: Boost charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge voltage.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.

Requirement: Boost charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge time.It must be logged in the event log if the setting is changed by the user.
Enable/disable boost charge mode. This setting indicates if the UPS is allowed to enter boost charge.  Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable.
Setting to configure the battery boost charge voltage. Range and default value depends on battery type: Lead-acid:Range: 2.23V to 2.40VDefault: 2.38V/cell
Setting for the boost charge timeLead-acid:Range: 1 to 50 hoursDefault value: 8 hours

Enable/disable that the UPS automatically enters boost charge mode. Rnage: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable. Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Boost charge mode must be enabled.
Activate Boost Charge via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Indicates if it is allowed to activate Boost Charge. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Boost charge mode enable - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge mode enable - setting has been changed.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge voltage - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge time - setting has been changed

Requirement: Auto boost charge enable - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Auto boost charge enable - setting has been changed.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Boost charge has been activated by user.
The current charging mode of the charger must be available to the user as a status and in the UPS event log.
The current operational status of the charger must be available to the user.
The UPS must provide information to the user about the estimated charge level of the connected energy storage.
The UPS must provide information to the user about the estimated charge time left before the connected energy storage has reached 80% charge level.

The charger must limit the charge current according to the charging conditions.Parameters like - battery Ah rating- configured charge CA rating - configured UPS power rating- configured charger capacity- maximum UPS input current - ambient temperaturemust be taken into account when determining the charge current limit.When the charger enters and exits current limitation it must be logged in the UPS event log.
The charge current rate (CA rate) must be configurable by the user

It must be possible to charge the batteries when the UPS is in static bypass.The battery charge current must always be limited to 10% of system rating up to 90% load and 1% of system rating at 100% load, when the UPS is in static bypass (requested static bypass, ECO mode, ECOnversion mode)

The charge voltage reference must be decreased based on the battery temperature within a given temperature interval. When the battery temperature reaches a certain limit, the charger voltage must be decreased by a fixed number of mV pr. cell pr. degree C (number depends on the battery type and charge mode), until the battery temperature reaches 40 degrees C.{Image: 6A3A0E85-B3FD-41CD-BE54-D140034E7497.bmp}Charge voltage compensation must be implemented in all charge modes and reference voltage levels for lead-acid and NiCd batteries, but not Li-ion batteries.
The temperature compensated charge voltage level must be adjusted according to the battery type:Lead-acid: Float charge: -3.3 mV/cell pr. degree CBoost charge: -5.0 mV/cell pr. degree C

Requirement: User adjustable nominal battery temperature reference
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the nominal battery temperature, where the temperature compensation of the charge voltage must begin.{Image: 4B11A4A9-FBD2-400A-8F6C-FCAC0DEA9F7A.bmp}
Nominal temperature given by the battery suppliers for charging voltage. Lead-acid:Range:  0 - 40 degrees CDefault: 25 degrees C
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery temperature reference - setting has been changed

To prevent battery thermal runaway, the charger must turn off if the battery temperature reaches 45°C (45°C or above for 60 seconds), and must not turn on again before the battery temperature drops below 40°C. For Li-ion batteries the charger must turn off at 65°C (65°C or above for 60 seconds), and turn on again when the battery temperature is below 60°C.The levels are fixed and cannot be changed by the user.This feature must only be active when UPS is configured with battery as energy storage type - both for modular battery solution and classic battery solution (VRLA, open cell and Li-ion).

Requirement: Alarm user when the charger is turned off due to high battery temperature
Description: A warning alarm must be posted when the charger is turned off due to high battery temperature.

Requirement: Charger shutdown due to high battery temperature - cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: The charger shutdown due to a high battery temperature has been cleared.

Requirement: Charger shutdown due to high battery temperature
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check the battery temperature.Description: The charger has been shut down due to a high battery temperature.

Requirement: User notification of reduced charge power
Description: If the UPS reaches charge current limitation due to that the nominal charge power of the UPS has been reduced*, the user must be notified about this via an alarm and event in the event log.*The nominal charge power can be reduced either due to:- The "UPS running on generator" dry contact input is activated, hence the maximum charge power is lowered - The input current of the UPS has reached its maximum limit for example due to low mains, or due to a configured maximum allowed input current.
It must be possible for the user to configure the maximum charging power of the UPS as a percentage of the nominal UPS power rating, and a change of this setting must be logged in the event log.

Requirement: Reduce maximum battery charge limit to protect against thermal runaway
Description: To protect against thermal runaway, the charging function must reduce the maximum allowed charge current, when the batteries are fully charged."Fully charged" is defined as 1 hour after the charger has been in float charge, with no current limitation, and the state of charge is above 99%

Requirement: Removing the reduction of maximum charge current function
Description: The reduction of the maximum allowed charge current to protect against thermal runaway, must be removed again when the charge mode changes to anything else than float charge (discharging, boost charging, equalization charging etc.)....

Requirement: Maximum current threshold for thermal runaway protection
Description: The maximum allowed charge current must be reduced to:0.1C for lead acid batteries

Requirement: Battery float charge current exceeds expected value
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check batteryDescription: The battery float charge current exceeds the expected value and has been limited to avoid thermal runaway

Requirement: Battery float charge current no longer exceeds expected value
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery float charge current no longer exceeds the expected value
Setting for the charge current rate in CLead-acid:Range:  0.1 - 0.3Default: 0.25CNiCd:Range: 0.1 - 0.2Default: 0.2Li-ion:Range 0.1 - 1.0Default: 0.7
Setting for the maximum charge powerRange: 5%  to  60% in steps of 1%.Default: 20%.

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge current rate (CA rate) - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Charge power - setting has been changed
It must be possible to configure the UPS to discharge the batteries to an even lower voltage level than the normally recommended value (event though there is a risk of battery damage).

Requirement: Battery deep discharge allowed must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if battery deep discharge is allowed or not.

With battery deep discharge enabled, the low shutdown voltage must be set at the following fixed levels (dynamic shutdown voltage level is disabled) depending on the battery type:Lead-acid: 1.59 V/cellLi-ion: 2.45 V/cellExample for lead-acid battery:{Image: DDD6DBFC-79BC-4424-ACF3-6CD0125801F8.bmp}
It must be logged in the UPS event log if battery deep discharge allowed is enabled or disabled by the user.
Setting to enable and disable if battery deep discharge is allowedRange: Yes/noDefault value: No
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Deep discharge allowed - setting has been changed.

The UPS must monitor the output load and compare it to the nominal available battery capacity. If the current output load will result in a too high battery discharge current (discharge CA-rate) in battery operation, the user must be notified via an alarm.If the UPS is in battery operation, the actual measured battery discharge current must be used to calculate the discharge CA-rate.If the UPS is not in battery operation, the battery discharge CA-rate must be estimated using the current UPS output load and the lowest possible/allowed battery voltage (worst-case scenario where the UPS is in battery operation and the battery voltage is low).

Requirement: Battery capacity is within acceptable level
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The battery capacity is within the acceptable level according to the current UPS output load.

Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Change battery configuration and/or increase battery capacity.Description: The battery capacity is below the minimum level according to the current UPS output load. Risk of battery damage.

Requirement: Maximum battery discharge CA-rate - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Maximum battery discharge CA-rate - setting has been changed.
The maximum discharge CA-rate must be user configurable to take into account different types and brands of batteries.
Setting to configure the maximum battery discharge CA-rate allowed. An alarm is posted of this discharge CA-rate is above this threshold. Range: 1C - 10CDefault value: 6C

The UPS must provide a calculation of the estimated remaining runtime (remaining backup time) of the connected energy storage. The remaining runtime must be shown while operating in normal operation and battery operation, and shall be displayed real-time, even under changing load conditions.

Requirement: Support for different energy storage types
Description: The remaining runtime calculation must support different energy storage types, including different battery technologies and batteries from different vendors. Therefore, the parameters and method used for the runtime calculation must be configurable by the user.

The calculated remaining battery runtime must have an accuracy of +/- 5% for battery solutions (both modular and classic) which are sold as standard SKUs by Schneider Electric. On these battery solutions, the remaining runtime calculation has been tested and validated by Schneider Electric on the actual batteries.For batteries where the above is not the case, the accuracy must be +/-10%. In this case the runtime parameters have been calculated by Schneider Eletcric but no test and validation have been done on the actual batteries.For third-party batteries no accuracy is guaranteed.The +/-5% and +/-10% tolerances are related to the “initial guess” at a 100% SOC (State of Charge) and 100% SOH (State of Health). Once the discharge starts, the requirements are (constant power discharge assumed):- The countdown must not count faster than twice real time- The countdown must not count slower than half the real time- The counter should hit “0” when the UPS passes the shutdown voltage (+/-5 to 10 seconds)
The UPS must be able to post an alarm when a certain level of battery runtime is remaining. This level must be confgurable by the user.

Setup for which battery capacity calculation method is used to calculate the battery runtime. Possible values:1:           CA based runtime (CA = Capacity Ah)2:           CW based runtime (CW = Capacity Watt or WPC = Watt per Cell)3:           CA/CW based runtime for Lithium/NiCd batteries or other energi storage (future use) Default value: 1

Setup for the calculation value 1 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set) Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1 and 2: Scale Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429492: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 2 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set) Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1 and 2: Expo Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429492: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 3 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = Not set)Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1 and 2: SlopeRange check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429492: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

Setup for the calculation value 4 used in the battery runtime calculation formula. Range: Full 32 bit value, from 0 to 4,294,967,295Default value: 0, (0 = No set) Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:- Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method- Value use depends on Runtine Calculation Method. Method 1: Not used. Method 2: Energy (W/cell) Range check is depending on Runtine Calculation Method:1: CA based runtime -   Not relevant2: CW based runtime -  Range is limited to 0.00001 to 429493: CA/CW based runtime: TBD

A function must be available to test and calibrate the battery runtime.In this test the UPS transfers to Battery Operation and the batteries are discharged to 10% remaining capacity. Based on the elapsed time and information about the load, the battery capacity can be calculated and the estimated runtime calibrated.

To start the battery runtime calibration test the following conditions must be fulfilled:No battery test is running.Batteries must be 100% charged.No critical alarms present.The load percentage must be at least 10% and is not allowed to change more than 20% of the starting value during test. (Ex. if load was 30% when starting, it is allowed to vary between 24%-36%).The bypass supply and static bypass must be available (UPS must be able to transfer to requested static bypass).The UPS operation mode must be normal operation, ECO mode.The system operation mode must be inverter on, ECO mode.

The battery condition must be reported to the user. One of the following conditions must be reported depending on the measured voltage of the battery (see requirement for ""Battery condition estimation"" for more details):·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test status reporting
Description: The UPS must report the status of the battery runtime calibration test to the user in the event log (if the test is inactive, running, aborted, completed etc.).
It must be possible for the user to manually initiate and abort a battery runtime calibration test.

Requirement: User reset of battery aging factor
Description: It must be possible for the user to reset the aging factor calculated by the battery runtime calibration test function, for example in the case where old batteries are replaced by new.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test start command
Description: Command to start battery runtime calibration via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test start allowed
Description: Indicates if it is allowed to start a battery runtime calibration test.Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test abort command
Description: Command to abort battery runtime calibration via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test abort allowed
Description: Indicates if it is allowed to abort a battery runtime calibration test. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test aging factor reset
Description: Command to reset the aging factor calculated by the battery runtime calibration test function via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test is inactive.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test is running

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test has been aborted due to a critical alarm
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery runtime calibration test has been completed.

Requirement: Battery runtime calibration test activated by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: User has activated battery runtime calibration test function.

The UPS must be able to test that it can run in Battery Operation and that the batteries are OK, without any risk of load drop. So, in case the UPS is not able to support the load during battery self-test, it must return to normal operation, with a transfer over forced static bypass if required. During the battery self-test, the UPS transfers to battery operation for testing the capacity and status of the batteries, including fuses, and the battery operation mode in general.

To start the battery self-test the following conditions must be fulfilled:- No battery test is running.- The remaining runtime available must be more than 4 minutes.- Battery breakers are closed.- No critical alarms present.- The batteries must be 50% charged or more.- The bypass supply and static bypass must be available (UPS must be able to transfer to Requested Static Bypass).- The UPS operation mode must be Normal Operation, ECO Mode .- The system operation mode must be Inverter On, ECO Mode.

The battery condition must be reported to the user. One of the following conditions must be reported depending on the measured voltage of the battery (see requirement for ""Battery condition estimation"" for more details):·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.
The UPS must report the status of the battery self-test to the user in the event log (if the test is inactive, running, aborted, completed etc.).

It must be possible for the user to manually initiate and abort a battery self-test.Depending on the configuration done by the user, the manual battery self-test must exit either:- When the battery has been discharged by 10% of the total capacity (WAVE1) or- After a certain time or when a certain battery voltage has been reached, what ever comes first. (WAVE2)

It must be possible for the user to schedule a battery self-test.The user must be able to configure the interval, the start time and start day of the scheduled battery self-test.The scheduled battery self-test must discharge the batteries by 10% of the total capacity and then exit.

Requirement: User configurable battery self-test discharge time - wave2
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure how long time the manual battery self-test must run.

Requirement: User configurable battery self-test discharge voltage - wave2
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the battery discharge voltage limit for when the manual battery self-test must exit.
Command to start battery self-test via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Indicates if it is allowed to start a battery self-test. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.
Command to abort battery self-test via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.
Indicates if it is allowed to abort a battery self-test. Used to ""grey out"" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner.

The UPS must be able to estimate the battery condition during battery test (battery runtime calibration test and battery self-test) and report one of the following conditions as alarms and events, depending on the measured voltage of the battery:·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery capacity is above 75%
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery capacity is between 50% to 75%
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Batteries should be replaced.Description: Battery capacity is lower than 50%

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Perform a battery runtime calibration test.Description: The battery state is unknown. Either the battery is new or a battery runtime calibration test has been aborted.

To avoid deep discharging the batteries, the UPS must automatically trip the battery breakers after 2 weeks, if system is left with output off and no ability to charge the batteries.It must be possible to enable and disable this feature by the user.

To avoid deep discharging the batteries, when the system is left with output off and no ability to charge the batteries, the UPS must automatically trip the battery breakers, if the battery cell voltage reaches, or becomes below, the low battery shutdown level for 10 minutes.

Requirement: Energy storage automatic disconnect time accelerated test option
Description: It must be possible to speed up the time of the energy storage automatic disconnect for testing purposes.
Automatic battery disconnect function - avoid deep discharge of batteries during idle mode - system installed but no mains available Values: Yes/NoDefault value: Yes

Requirement: Energy storage automatic disconnect time accelerated test command
Description: Command to start/stop the accelerated energy storage automatic disconnect time.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Automatic battery disconnect - setting has been changed
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Close the battery breakers.Description: To prevent the batteries deep discharging, the battery breakers have been tripped by the system
The UPS must trip the battery breakers in case the battery voltage drops below a certain level. This is required to limit damages in case there is a flashover.
The under-voltage trip level must be at 0.625 x nominal cell voltage:Lead acid: 1.25 V/cellLi-ion: 2.38 V/cellNiCd: 0.75 V/cell

The energy storage under-voltage must have been present for minimum 10 ms and maximum 100 ms. before the battery breakers are tripped, to ensure that a short dip in the voltage does not cause a battery breaker trip .
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Close the battery breakers.Description: Battery voltage reached collapse level and the battery breakers have been tripped by the system
The UPS must be able to monitor the energy storage temperature.

Description: The user must be able to enable and disable the energy storage temperature monitoring.

Requirement: Number of energy storage temperature sensors must be configurable
Description: The user must be able configure which energy storage temperature sensors are used (enable/disable them individually).

Requirement: High and low energy storage temperature warning
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure a low and a high temperature level. The UPS must then warn the user via an alarm, if the energy storage temperature drops below the low temperature level, or rises above the high temperature level.

Setting to enable and disable battery temperature sensor 1Enable/disable.Default value: Enable
Setting to enable and disable battery temperature sensor 2Enable/disable.Default value: Disable

Requirement: Battery is disconnected - output relay setting
Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate battery is disconnected.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Battery is disconnected - output relay - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Battery is disconnected - output relay - setting has been changed

Requirement: Charge voltage when battery is disconnected
Description: When the battery is disconnected (breaker open or fuses cleared), the charge voltage must be set to a fixed value, to keep voltage on the terminals.The current limitation must be set to the minimum required for obtaining a voltage on the terminals.Levels and limits must be specified in a sub requirement for the product
The UPS must have a function that evaluates the battery voltage and compares it to the battery configuration, before the battery relays in the power modules are activated.

The battery voltage configuration check must evaluate the battery voltage the first time it is applied after a start-up. If the configuration is changed afterwards, the evaluation must only be done if control system is rebooted.

Whether or not a battery is present is determined by having a voltage of 250V (equals 1.3V/cell in a 32 block system).For lead acid the correct voltage for accepting the configuration :The battery voltage must be above 1.9V/cellThe battery voltage must be below 2.30V/cell

It must be possible for the user to acknowledge and override the warning, if the battery voltage is too high after start-up.Background:The battery voltage is checked, if it is above a threshold level, otherwise it is considered a wrong configuration. This works fine if the battery is in resting mode, or have been float charged just before a restart. If the battery was boost charged, and the unit rebooted, the voltage could be too high for a period, and blocking to accept the battery voltage. In this case it should be possible for the user,via the HMI to override the warning an proceed.

Requirement: Double confirmation for overriding battry blocking
Description: It must be confirmed twice before a overriding of the battery blocking is accepted

Requirement: Logging of the override function for blocking batteries
Description: It must be logged that the user accepted to override the blocking of batteries

Requirement: Battery voltage does not match battery configuration
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check and correct battery settingsDescription: Battery voltage does not match the battery configuration settings
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: Battery voltage matches the battery configuration settings

Requirement: Battery voltage configuration check override by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: User has accepted to manually override the battery voltage configuration check

The user must be able to configure the UPS for NiCd batteries.This means that the following basic parameters must be specifically adjusted in ranges and values to support NiCd: - Battery type configurable as NiCd (this is used by the UPS to choose the correct charging algorithm, and default values and allowed ranges of relevant settings etc.).- Number of cells in battery setting range and default value according to NiCd and UPS battery voltage range.- Number of batteries in series setting range and default value according to NiCd and UPS battery voltage range.

The charger for NiCd batteries must have three basic charge cycle steps:- Step 1: Constant current charge at a configurable current level. The charger must change to step 2 when the cell voltage reaches a given limit (the same configurable cell voltage level used for step 2).- Step 2: Constant voltage boost charge at a configurable cell voltage level. The duration of this cycle must be configurable, after which the charger must change to step 3.- Step 3: Float charge at a configurable cell voltage level.A boost charge cycle is required to reach 100% State Of Charge (SOC), but the boost charge cycle can cause battery water consumption. It must ensured that this state is not permanently active.{Image: 051A0CFB-E3E0-409C-8A96-E27FFBCCA0E4.bmp}

Requirement: Charge cycle after a battery discharge period
Description: If the UPS enters a battery discharge period (battery operation), the charger must have a certain behavior depending on which basic charge cycle step it is in, and how long the battery discharge period has been.Battery discharge during basic charge cycle step 1:- Stay in step 1.Battery discharge during basic charge cycle step 2:- If UPS enters battery operation for less than 30 seconds, continue in step 2.- If UPS enters battery operation for more than 30 seconds, restart the charge cycle (change to step 1).Battery discharge during basic charge cycle step 3:- If UPS enters battery operation for less than 30 seconds, continue in step 3- If UPS enters battery operation for more than 30 seconds, restart the charge cycle (change to step 1).TBD: A simple algorithm could be to applied to ensure a short boost charge cycle when the depth of discharge is small (for example only a 1-hour boost charge when SOC is > 95% after a discharge). The difficulty is to define these values and the best solution would be to define the values in cooperation with battery vendors.
It must be possible for the user to perform a manual equalization charge cycle of the NiCd battery at a configurable cell voltage and for a configurable time duration.

Requirement: Charge current rate must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the charge current rate (CA rate) according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Boost charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge voltage according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Boost charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the boost charge time according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Automatic boost charge must be permanently enabled
Description: The automatic boost charge function must be permanently enabled when battery type is configured to NiCd, as this is part of the basic NiCd charge cycle.This means that the user must not be able to disable the auto boost charge mode setting.

Requirement: Float charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the float charge voltage according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Equalization charge voltage must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the equalization charge voltage according to NiCd specific ranges.

Requirement: Equalization charge time must be configurable
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the equalization charge time according to NiCd specific ranges.
The temperature compensated charge voltage level must be adjusted according to NiCd battery type:NiCd: Float charge: -2.5 mV/cell pr. degree C
The battery high voltage warning level must be adjusted according to NiCd battery type:NiCd:1.8 V/cell

The UPS must provide a calculation of the estimated remaining runtime (remaining backup time) of the NiCd batteryThe remaining runtime must be shown while operating in normal operation and battery operation, and shall be displayed real-time, even under changing load conditions.
The cyclic charging mode must be disabled and not allowed for NiCd.

Requirement: Static low battery warning and shutdown levels
Description: The low battery voltage warning and shutdown levels must be static (fixed) for NiCd batteries and not dynamic as is the case for lead acid batteries.The values of the static levels must be configurable by the user according to NiCd specific ranges:Range: 0.5-1.1 V/cellDefault: 1.00V/cell
The battery voltage collapse level must be at 0.55 of the nominal voltage:NiCd: 1.2V/cell x 0.55 = 0.66V/cell. The battery voltage collapse clear condition level must be :NiCd: ??
Setting for low battery shutdown level setting in volt/cell.NiCd:Range: 0.5-1.1 V/cellDefault: 1.00V/cell

The extended support for the Li-ion solutions must include: Minimal I/O exchange to interface the UPS and lithium-ion battery including basic surveillance functions, remaining runtime calculation and warning before UPS shutdown.
The following Samsung Li-ion solutions must be supported:- SDI ELPM182
The following LG Li-ion solutions must be supported:- LG-JP3- LG-JP4

Requirement: Support for custom Li-ion battery solutions
Description: It must be possible to support custom Li-ion battery solutions, meaning the relevant parameters must be configurable by the user to comply with the given Li-ion solution.The following parameters must be configurable: SettingUnitsRangeNominal voltageV/cellCyclic charge tfloatminutes1 - 1440 minutesCyclic charge toff,maxminutes0 – 32767If 0 à Cycle charge cannot be usedCyclic charge Vfloat,minV/cell2.0 – 4.2Charging minimum battery temperature°C-10 – 30Charging maximum battery temperature°C30 – 70Temperature estimation-constant aKelvin/minuteTemperature estimation-constant bTemperature estimation-cooling constantsecondsBattery temperature shutdown threshold°C40 – 80Battery temperature shutdown delayseconds0 - 10If 0 à Surveillance is disabledCA discharge rate Level 11 – 50CA discharge rate Level 1 delayseconds0 – 60If 0 à Surveillance is disabledCA discharge rate Level 21 – 50CA discharge rate Level 2 delay[seconds]0 – 60If 0 à Surveillance is disabledCA discharge rate Level 31 – 50CA discharge rate Level 3 delay[seconds]0 – 60If 0 à Surveillance is disabledConstant K1 for curve based SOC calculation of LIBConstant K2 for curve based SOC calculation of LIBConstant K3 for curve based SOC calculation of LIBConstant K4 for curve based SOC calculation of LIBConstant K5 for curve based SOC calculation of LIB
For the Li-ion solution the nominal battery cell voltage must be as follows:- Samsung SDI ELPM182: 3.8V.- LG JP4: 3.7V.
When the UPS is configured to use a SKU based Li-ion solution, the battery configuration parameters listed below must be fixed to the shown values:{Image: 6E45EEF9-9EAA-4DD2-BB26-A16A7A4D9A3E.bmp}
For the Li-ion solution boost charging is not allowed and must be disabled.
For the Li-ion solution equalization charging is not allowed and must be disabled.

Requirement: No temperature compensation of charge voltage
Description: For the Li-ion solution the charge voltage must not be temperature compensated but instead fixed at the same value in the entire temperature range.

To avoid damaging the Li-ion battery during charging, the charge current must be reduced at low battery temperatures.The reduction of the charging current must start at the value set as “battery temperature reference”. The charge current must be gradually reduced, reaching zero Amps at the value set as “minimum charging battery temperature”.For SDI ELPM182 and LG JP4 the reduction must start at 16°C, and must reach zero Amps at 0 °C.
The UPS must be able to calculate the remaining runtime of the Li-ion battery.

Requirement: Static low battery warning and shutdown levels
Description: The low battery voltage warning and shutdown levels must be static (fixed) for Li-ion batteries and not dynamic as is the case for lead acid batteries.For custom LIB solutions the value of the static low battery shutdown must be configurable. For standard SKUs that value must be automatically selected. The value of the static low battery warning level must be calculated as a function of the low battery shutdown level and nominal voltage:Low battery warning level = Low battery shutdown level + 0.375 x (Nominal voltage – Low battery shutdown level) - Samsung SDI ELPM182: Nominal 3.80V/cell, shutdown level 3.00V/cell, warning level 3.3V/cell- LG JP4: Nominal 3.70V/cell, shutdown level 3.15V/cell, warning level 3.35V/cell
The battery high voltage warning level must be 1.5% higher than the float voltage.

The battery voltage collapse level must be at half of the nominal voltage The battery voltage collapse clear condition level must be shutdown voltage level + 0.15 x (Nominal voltage – Low battery shutdown level) - Samsung SDI ELPM182: Nominal 3.80V/cell, shutdown level 3.00V/cell, collapse level 1.90V/cell, collapse clear level 3.12V/cell- LG JP4: Nominal 3.70V/cell, shutdown level 3.15V/cell, collapse level 1.85V/cell, collapse clear level 3.23V/cell
The UPS must be able to calculate the charge level (state of charge) of the Li-ion battery.

Like for lead acid battery, the UPS must be able to estimate the Li-ion battery condition during battery test and report the conditions OK, weak and poor as alarms and events, depending on the measured voltage of the battery:·        Battery condition OK: Posted as an event if battery capacity is above 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition weak: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is between 50% and 75% of nominal.·        Battery condition poor: Shown as an alarm if battery capacity is below 50% of nominal.

The BMS of the Li-ion solution has an over-current protection which will open the battery breaker if an over-current is detected during a specific time duration.A surveillance function must exist in the UPS firmware which ensures that the UPS reacts to a discharge over-current (stops discharging) before the BMS decides to do so, to avoid that the BMS trips the battery breaker.

The BMS of the Li-ion solution has an internal battery temperature monitoring system which will shut down and disconnect the battery should the battery temperature rise above a certain limit.A surveillance function must exist in the UPS firmware which ensures that the UPS reacts to a battery over-temperature before the BMS does, to avoid that the BMS trips the battery breaker.

Requirement: User must be able to enable and disable internal surveillance functions
Description: It must be possible for the user (via UPS Tuner) to enable/disable the two internal surveillance functions for 'high battery current shutdown' and 'high battery temperature shutdown'.

For lithium-ion batteries the battery thermal runaway protection function must have different temperature levels compared to lead-acid batteries. The levels must depend on the specific LIB module. For custom LIB solutions the levels must be configurable. For standard SKUs that value must be automatically selected. - Samsung SDI ELPM182: Charger turned off if the battery temperature is 65 °C above for 60 seconds, and it is turned on again at 60°C (i.e, 0.92 x 65°C)- LG JP4: Charger turned off if the battery temperature is 40 °C above for 60 seconds, and it is turned on again at 37 °C (i.e, 0.92 x 40°C)

When Li-Ion battery systems are used, there could be large differences between the temperature provided by the battery temperature sensor (which is not in direct contact with the battery cell) and the actual cell temperature. A function must exist in the UPS firmware to estimate the cell temperature. The estimation must be made based on the cell load [W/cell], UPS operation mode [charging / discharging], battery model, and temperature provided by the sensor. All the firmware functionalities that make use of the battery temperature must use the estimated value, and that must the value that the HMI shows as battery temperature.

Requirement: User configurable maximum allowed string discharge current
Description: It must be possible for the user (via UPS Tuner) to configure the maximum allowed string discharge current and associated delays for Li-ion batteries.There must be three levels of discharge currents each with an associated delay.
For the Li-ion solution the maximum battery discharge CA-rate setting must be set to 7.98C.

Requirement: Input contact indicating external energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure a dry contact input to indicate that external energy storage monitoring has detected minor alarm.UPS must post a warning alarm if this dry contact input is active.

Requirement: Input contact indicating external energy storage monitoring detected major alarm
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure a dry contact input to indicate that external energy storage monitoring has detected major alarm.UPS must post a critical alarm and turn off the charger if this dry contact input is active.
It must be possible for the user to configure a dry contact input to turn off the charger if activated.

Requirement: Energy storage internal surveillance enable setting
Description: Setting to enable and disable the built-in energy storage surveillance functions in the UPS. These surveillance functions are only relevant for Li-ion batteries, so energy storage type must be set to Li-ion before the surveillance functions are actually active (enabled).

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm - input contact setting
Description: Setting to assign a configurable input contact to post an alarm in case of an external energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring detected major alarm - input contact setting
Description: Setting to assign a configurable input contact to post an alarm and turn off charger in case of an external energy storage monitoring detected major alarm.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Energy storage: Internal surveillance enable - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Energy storage internal surveillance enable - setting has been changed

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm - input contact - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: External energy storage monitoring detected minor alarm - input contact - setting has been changed

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring detected major alarm - input contact - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: External energy storage monitoring detected major alarm - input contact - setting has been changed

Requirement: External signal turns charger off - input contact - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: External signal turns charger off - input contact - setting has been changed

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring: Minor alarm
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Please contact Schneider ElectricDescription: Input contact indicates that the external energy storage monitoring has detected a minor alarm

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring: Minor alarm cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contact indicates that the external energy storage monitoring is no longer detecting a minor alarm

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring: Major alarm
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Please contact Schneider ElectricDescription: Input contact indicates that the external energy storage monitoring has detected a major alarm

Requirement: External energy storage monitoring: Major alarm cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contact indicates that the external energy storage monitoring is no longer detecting a major alarm

Requirement: External signal turns charger off: Activated
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contact for charger off is activated

Requirement: External signal turns charger off: Deactivated
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Input contact for charger off is deactivated
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The energy storage surveillance has detected a battery discharge current above shutdown limit

Requirement: High battery discharge current shutdown - cleared
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The energy storage surveillance high battery discharge current shutdown has been cleared
Type: EventSeverity: InformationCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The high battery temperature shutdown has been cleared
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text: Check the battery temperatureDescription: The energy storage surveillance has detected a battery temperature above shutdown limit

Requirement: Modular battery support - Agilis Bravo platform -not for Jedi
Description: The UPS must support a modular battery solution based on the Agilis Bravo platform (GVS product family).
This category summarizes the configuration rules for modular batteries

Requirement: Fixed basic battery settings for modular battery SKUs
Description: Below table illustrates the list of fixed basic battery settings, and how they must be configured automatically for each standard modular battery SKU:{Image: 527646EB-1A48-4F51-B110-047539CC9281.bmp}

Requirement: Settings to be available in a modular battery configuration
Description: Some battery settings must always be available for the user to configure, no matter if a modular battery configuration is selected:High battery temperature level settingLow battery temperature level settingBattery runtime low warning threshold setting Scheduled battery self-test interval setting Scheduled battery self-test time setting Scheduled battery self-test day of week settingAuto boost charge mode settingAuto cyclic charge mode setting
It must be possible for the user to configure if a classic or modular battery solution is connected to the UPS.

Requirement: Only show modular battery related data when configured for modular battery solution
Description: The UPS must only show modular battery related settings, status data and alarms/events on display, UPS Tuner and NMC when the battery solution is configued as modular.An other words, if UPS is configured for a classic battery solution all modular battery related settings, status data and alarms/events must not be shown to the user (on display, UPS Tuner and NMC).

Requirement: Warn if mixed battery solutions are detected
Description: It is not allowed to have both modular and classic batteries connected to the UPS at the same time.If the UPS is configured for classic batteries but detects that one or more modular battery modules are present in the system, the user must be warned via an alarm in the HMI and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Address ID numbering of Battery Monitor Controllers (BMCs)
Description: The address ID numbering of Battery Monitor Controllers (BMCs) must be as follows:- BMC internally in the UPS (if supported by the given product): Address ID 10- BMC in modular battery cabinet 1: Address ID 1- BMC in modular battery cabinet 2: Address ID 2- BMC in modular battery cabinet 3: Address ID 3- BMC in modular battery cabinet 4: Address ID 4- BMC in modular battery cabinet 5: Address ID 5

Requirement: Number of modular battery cabinets must be configurable by user
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure how many modular battery cabinets (ModBCs) are connected to the UPS.If the UPS has internal modular batteries it does not count as a modular battery cabinet.This setting must be used by the system to know how many Battery Monitor Controllers (BMCs) are expected to be present in the system. If the UPS has internal modular batteries one BMC must automatically be set as present independently of this setting.

Requirement: Warn if detected Battery Monitor Controllers (BMCs) do not match configuration
Description: The UPS must warn the user via an alarm if the number of BMCs, and/or the assigned address IDs of the BMCs detected on the Abus do not match the configured number of modular battery cabinets and the BMC address ID numbering rules.

It must be possible to detect if a modular battery module is present or not.  - Must be reported to the user both as a status and as an event in the event log.- Must be taken into account when calculating the total available battery capacity

It must be detected if a modular battery string is incomplete.In case one or more battery modules are present in a string but not all four of them, it must be reported to the user via an alarm. It must be indicated on string level and battery cabinet level.

Requirement: Mixed battery module vendors on string level surveillance
Description: If the battery modules in a string are a mix of different vendors it must be indicated to the user via an alarm. It must be indicated on string level and battery cabinet level.It is not allowed to mix different battery vendors in the same string

Requirement: Mixed battery module SKU numbers on system level surveillance
Description: If battery modules with different SKU numbers are installed in the modular battery system (both within the same battery string and between battery strings), it must be indicated to the user via an alarm.It is not allowed to mix battery modules with different SKU numbers as they are not compatible with each other when it comes to:- Capacity (7Ah vs. 9Ah) and/or- Type (long-life vs. "standard-life") and/or- Runtime calculation parametersIf it is detected that there is a mix of battery capacity on system level (7Ah battery modules together with 9Ah battery modules - only battery modules in complete strings must be taken into account), the capacity of all present battery modules must be set as 7Ah internally. This is done to avoid charging the actual 7Ah battery modules with too high a current compared to their capacity.The modular battery module SKU number is not directly available to be read by the FW, so the FW must check that the modular battery module vendors detected in the system are all on the same SKU. Vendors on each SKU are listed in the below table:IDVendorType/ModelCapacitySKU111CSBGP12727AhGVSBTU1001PanasonicUP-PW1245P1 (long life)9AhGVSBTHULL1111CSBHR1234W F29AhGVSBTHU
The battery module type must be detected and reported to the user. The module type indicates the battery vendor and the battery capacity.

Requirement: Modular battery module types and hardware IDs

Description: The temperature of each battery module must be monitored by the UPS, and must be available to the user.If the temperature of one or more battery modules in a cabinet drops below the user configured low temperature level, or rises above the user configured high temperature level, it must be reported via an alarm on cabinet level.If the temperature of one or more battery modules in a string rises above a certain level compared to the temperatures of the other battery modules in the same string (above a maximum allowed difference of 5 degrees C for 10 seconds), it must be reported via an alarm on string level.

The temperature of each modular battery string must be monitored by the UPS, and must be available to the user.The modular battery string temperature must be calculated from the temperatures measured in the battery cartridges present in the given string.Calculated as the highest battery cartridge temperature.

The temperature of each modular battery cabinet must be monitored by the UPS, and must be available to the user.The modular battery cabinet temperature must be calculated from the temperatures measured in the battery cartridges present in the given cabinet.Calculated as the highest battery cartridge temperature.

Requirement: Handling of faulty battery module temperature sensor
Description: It must be possible to detect if a battery module temperature sensor is not working correctly, and the reading from this sensor must be ignored, meaning not used for determining the battery temperature and not impacting the battery float voltage calculation and charger shutdown.The user must be notified via an alarm if any battery cartridge temperature sensors are not working correctly.Note:The hardware is not able to detect all modular battery module temperature sensor faults, so the firmware is only able to support the scenarios also supported by the hardware:- One of the two temperature sensors in a modular battery module is open: Not supported.- Both of the two temperature sensors in a modular battery module are open: Supported.- One of the two temperature sensors in a modular battery module is shorted: Supported.- Both of the two temperature sensors in a modular battery module are shorted: Supported.

Requirement: Battery Monitor Controller firmware version information
Description: The firmware version of the Battery Monitor Controller(s) in the system must be available to the user.

Requirement: Battery Monitor Controller serial number information
Description: The serial number of the Battery Monitor Controller(s) in the system must be available to the user.

Requirement: Battery Monitor Controller hardware version information
Description: The hardware version of the Battery Monitor Controller(s) in the system must be available to the user.
The SKU number(s) of the modular battery cabinet(s) in the system must be available to the user.
The serial number(s) of the modular battery cabinet(s) in the system must be available to the user.

Requirement: Configure modular battery cabinet SKU and serial number from UPS Tuner
Description: It must be possible to configure the modular battery cabinet SKU number and serial number from UPS Tuner in case a battery monitor controller of a modular battery cabinet is replaced during service.

Requirement: Firmware update of Battery Monitor Controller
Description: It must be possible to update the firmware of the Battery Monitor Controller(s) in the system via the standard product firmware update procedure.

Requirement: Battery Monitor Controller firmware version compatibility check
Description: The firmware version of the Battery Monitor Controller(s) in the system must be checked for compatibility with the system.

Requirement: Communication interface to Battery Monitor Controller
Description: The communication interface to the Battery Monitor Controller must be reused from 'Odin' project. Same Abus CAN communication interface and protocol.

Requirement: Surveillance of communication link to Battery Monitor Controller
Description: The communication status of each Battery Monitor Controller must be must be monitored by the UPS, and be available to the user via alarms/events.If the communication to a Battery Monitor Controller is lost, the battery capacity associated with this Battery Monitor Controller must be subtracted from the total available battery capacity of the system.

The battery breaker of a modular battery cabinet must be monitored and the status must be available to the user. Any change in the breaker status must be logged in the event log.If the battery breaker in a modular battery cabinet is open, the battery capacity of this cabinet must be subtracted from the total available battery capacity of the system.

Requirement: Combined battery breaker status for modular batteries
Description: For an UPS with modular batteries, the combined battery breaker status of the system must reflect the status of all the battery breakers in the MBCs and the modular battery DC relay in the UPS (if a such is present).Common BB is closed if the modular battery DC relay (if present) or one or more MBC battery breakers are closed.Common BB is open if the modular battery DC relay (if present) and all MBC battery breakers are open. If no MBCs are connected to the UPS (only the modular batteries internally in the UPS are used), the common BB status must be just indicate the status of the modular battery DC relay (if present).

The global fuse of a modular battery cabinet (ModBC) must be monitored and an alarm must be posted if the fuse is detected as blown.The total available battery capacity of the system must be adjusted automatically according to which ModBC fuse is detected as blown:- Fuse in ModBC 1 blown: All ModBC battery capacity is lost (only the battery capacity internally in the UPS is available).- Fuse in ModBC 2 blown: Only the battery capacity of ModBC 1 is available- Fuse in ModBC 3 blown: Only the battery capacity of ModBC 1 + 2 is available- Fuse in ModBC 4 blown: Only the battery capacity of ModBC 1 + 2 + 3 is available

To calculate the remaining runtime of the modular battery, the runtime calculation parameters defined for the given battery SKU number of the present battery modules must be used. If a mix of different modular battery module SKU numbers are detected on system level, the set of runtime calculation parameters for the SKU number of the majority of the mounted battery cartridges present in the system must be used.

The general status (not working correctly or OK) of each modular battery module in the system must be available.This status is needed to be able to indicate the general modular battery module status via colors/symbols in UPS Tuner. Cabinet number and module location inside cabinet must be indicated.Status details:Not working correctly:- Battery module has temperature out of tolerance OR- Battery module has a temperature sensor that is not working correctly OR- Battery module is an unknown type.OK:- None of the above conditions are present.

The general status (not working correctly or OK) of each modular battery string in the system must be available.This status is needed to be able to indicate the general modular battery string status via colors/symbols on the HMI. Cabinet number and string location inside cabinet must be indicated.Status details:Not working correctly:- One or more battery modules in the string has temperature out of tolerance OR- One or more battery modules in the string has a temperature sensor that is not working correctly OR- Battery string is incomplete OR- Battery string contains battery cartridges of different vendors OR- One or more battery modules in the string are of an unknown type. OK:- None of the above conditions are present.

Requirement: Modular battery string status indication via LEDs in ModBC
Description: The general status of each modular battery string in the system must be used to indicate the general modular battery string status via a LEDs in the ModBC(s).LED off:                  Unpowered, or no modular battery modules present in the string, or battery string is OKLED constant red:    Battery string is incompleteLED flashing red:     Battery string is complete but not working correctly (conditions are listed in HOW35623).

The general status (not present, not working correctly, OK) of each modular battery cabinet (including UPS frame if it has internal modular batteries) in the system must be available.This status is needed to be able to indicate the general modular battery cabinet status via colors/symbols on the HMI.Status details:Not present:- Modular battery cabinet is supposed to be present but communication is lost to it. Not working correctly:- Modular battery cabinet has one or more battery strings that are not working correctly OR- Modular battery cabinet fuse is blown OR- Modular battery cabinet has an unknown SKU number.OK:- None of the above conditions are present.

Requirement: Warn if a modular battery cabinet with an unknown SKU number is detected
Description: If a modular battery cabinet with an unknown SKU number is detected by the UPS, the user must be warned via an alarm.The given modular battery cabinet must still be taken into account so that any battery modules installed in it are part of the total available battery capacity.

Requirement: Warn if a modular battery module of an unknown type is detected
Description: If a battery module of an unknown type is detected by the UPS, the user must be warned via an alarm.The given battery module must not be taken into account as part of the total available battery capacity.

Requirement: Number of modular battery cabinets setting
Description: Setting to configure the number of modular battery cabinets (ModBCs) connected to the UPS.Range: 0 to 5Default value: 0

Requirement: Modular battery cabinet SKU number setting
Description: Setting to configure the SKU number of the modular battery cabinet (only ModBCs).Modular battery cabinet number must be indicated.

Requirement: Modular battery cabinet serial number setting
Description: Setting to configure the serial number of the modular battery cabinet (only ModBCs).Modular battery cabinet number must be indicated.

Status that indicates if a modular battery module is present or not.Range: Present / not presentCabinet number and module location inside cabinet must be indicated. Up to 36 battery modules per cabinet must be supported.
Status that indicates the modular battery module type.Range: Defined by product specific requirementsCabinet number and module location inside cabinet must be indicated.
Status of the breaker in the modular battery cabinet (only ModBCs).Range: Open/closedDefault value: OpenCabinet number must be indicated.

Measurement of the temperature of a modular battery module.Unit: C/FPrecision: 0 decimalsCabinet number and module location inside cabinet must be indicated. Up to 36 battery modules per cabinet must be supported.

Requirement: Limit maximum charge voltage - !How to define-?
Description: It shall be possible - as part of commissioning - to setup the system in a way so charge voltage will never exceed 600V.Background info:The setting is needed to support point 2 below:1. Support 40-48 blocks/string without midpoint (WHAT36406). Maximum charge voltage is 720V (WHAT36422). For voltages higher than 600V, 750V cables and 750V breaker must be applied (WHAT40597). This enable plug&play replacement with G7K2. Voltage limiter set by UPS tuner to max 600V to support 40, 42 or 44 blocks/string installed with standard 600V cables & 600V rated breaker. With 44 blocks/ string, boost charge mode is impossible.

Requirement: Boost charging mode - !MKT delete floating chg mode
Description: Boost charge mode gives the user a possibility to conduct a fast charge in order to quickly restore a discharged battery. For boost charge to be available boost charge mode must be enabled by the user.In boost charge mode the charge voltage level is set at the defined boost charge level and the boost charge is time limited.
Define all the requirements related to : * Display, RMS, Transverse communication boards, dry contacts, mimic display, On/Off button, Service Port, status LED, ...

Requirement: Spot Mode - Normal SPot is needed in wave1
Description: Spot mode shall be supported as standard for the AC power path

The UPS must provide a green burn-in mode also called Smart Power Test (SPoT), where it is possible to test the main power components like PFC, inverter, charger and static bypass switch under full load by recycling power from the output to the input of the UPS, thereby limiting the actual power consumption required during the test to a minimum.

It must be possible to turn on the inverter while the UPS is in requested static bypass operation.The output power from the inverter must then be recycled via the static bypass switch to input mains. The power consumption equals the system losses in the inverter and PFC.Requires the output to be connected via bypass to the input mains.{Image: 135F09A6-AF44-432E-8B01-F8DFB83FD89A.bmp}

It must be possible to turn on the inverter while the UPS is in requested static bypass operation. The output power from the inverter must then be recycled via the static bypass switch and supply an external DC supply. The power consumption equals the system losses in the inverter, PFC the external DC supply.Requires the output to be connected via bypass to an external DC supply.{Image: 600ECE4A-3072-4C52-B3B4-461F4ABF1CEF.bmp}
When in SPoT in normal operation or battery operation, the output power of the UPS must be adjustable by the user.

Requirement: Conditions to allow SPoT in normal or battery operation
Description: Conditions to allow transfer to SPoT in normal operation:- UOB open- UPS in requested static bypass- UIB closed- Input voltage within tolerance- BB(s) open- All inverters and PFCs are operable

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: SPoT in normal or battery operation power - setting changed

It must be possible to turn on the charger while in battery operation. The charge power must then be recycled via the PFC back to the DC bus. The power consumption equals the system loss only in the charger and PFC.Requires the UPS to be in Battery Operation (UIB breaker open).{Image: BF45A930-3B26-4683-AE95-BE3B0A89365C.bmp}
When in charger SPoT, the charge power of the UPS must be adjustable by the user.

It must be possible to perform a battery discharge test when running in SPoT mode. In this mode power must be taken from the battery and supplied back to the input power grid through the inverter and the static bypass switch.
When in battery discharge SPoT, the UPS must perform a battery runtime calibration test and adjust the estimated runtime accordingly.
When in battery discharge SPoT, the output power of the UPS and hence the power drawn from the battery, must be adjustable by the user (customer and FSR) in steps of 5%.
When in battery discharge SPoT, the battery discharge level % for when to exit the SPoT mode, must be adjustable by the user (customer and FSR).

It must be possible for the FSR to enable and disable if battery discharge SPoT is allowed.When enabled and allowed, it must possible for the customer to perform a battery discharge SPoT. The FSR must always be able to perform the battery discharge SPoT no matter the value of this setting.
It must be possible for the user to manually initiate and abort a battery discharge SPoT.

The UPS must indicate to the user (display / UPS Tuner) if it is currently allowed or not to start a battery discharge SPoT.The following conditions must be fulfilled to be able to start a battery discharge SPoT: * UOB open  * UPS in requested static bypass  * Battery breakers closed  * UIB open (UPS input not connected to mains, PFC in battery operation)

The time an active SPoT test has been running. Unit: hh:mm
An input for external synchronisation shall be available

The UPS must synchronize its inverter output to the following sources with the given priority: 1. Parallel master (if the UPS is slave in a parallel UPS system). - wave 2  2. External synchronization source (if external sync is enabled and force external sync is activated)  - wave2  3. Bypass input  4. Mains input  5. Free runningNote: If UPS is configured as frequency converter it must never sync to bypass input and mains input.
The UPS must check if a synchronization source is valid and only use it if it is within the defined tolerances.The exact tolerances must be defined for each product separately.

The UPS must determine if a given synchronize source is within tolerance and the inverter PLL is allowed to synchronize to it, based on the table below. Data detail need to be confirmed in JEDIRequirementSettingSettingSettingSettingSettingSettingControllerDetection functionalityDetection input data(AC/DC)Detection levelLimit direction(Upper / Lower)Hysteresis (% of nominal value)Alarm on delay [ms]Alarm off delay [ms]Execution frequency [Hz]PLL validity detect3-phase RMSMainsPh-Neu365VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/IMMainsPh-Neu55VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/IMBypassPh-Neu orPh-Ph365Vrms630VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzIMBypassPh-Neu orPh-Ph55Vrms95VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzIMOutputPh-Neu orPh-Ph365Vrms630VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/IMOutputPh-Neu orPh-Ph55Vrms95VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzPMC/IMExt SyncPh-Neu365VrmsUpper+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzIMExt SyncPh-Neu55VrmsLower+/- 1 %200 ms200 ms1 KHzIM

Requirement: Info about selected synchronization source must be available to user
Description: The UPS must inform the user about which synchronization source is currently used by the inverter via events in the event log.

Requirement: User must be notified if UPS synchronization is free running
Description: The UPS must inform the user via an alarm in display, UPS Tuner and HTML interface and an event in event log, if the UPS synchronization is in free running mode.Note: If UPS is configured as frequency converter this alarm must not be posted.
When the UPS inverter output is free running (synchronized to its own internal reference), the inverter output frequency must be equal to the configured UPS system frequency (normally 50 or 60 Hz).
The speed of which the inverter output is able to change frequency to synchronize to a source (slew rate) must be configurable by the user.

Requirement: Synchronization to external source -TBD at  wave 2
Basic UPS Synchronization to a fixed voltage source
Description: It must be possible for the UPS to synchronize its output voltage to an external voltage sources, like for example a generator.The goal is to enable a STS to shift between the UPS and the generator with a minimum output voltage break time.

The UPS must include the platform feature ""3N sync without external box"".Detailed requirements for this feature can be found under the Feature Brick platform requirements.Paralleled fram synchronization

Requirement: Voltage quality detection on external sync voltage
Description: The UPS must be able to monitor the external synchronization voltage connected to the UPS, and detect if it is not within the defined tolerances. The following parameters must be monitored:- Voltage - RMS for each phase L1, L2 and L3- Voltage - waveform for each phase L1, L2 and L3- Frequency- Phase sequence- Phase missing

The UPS must temporarily stop synchronizing to the external fixed voltage source if it cannot track and lock its PLL to this source within a maximum time of 60 seconds.An alarm must be posted if external sync is temporarily disabled.To make the UPS start synchronizing to the external fixed voltage source again after it has been temporarily disabled, the force synchronization to external source must be disabled/deactivated and enabled/activated again (setting or input relay).

Sets the mode of the external synchronization feature. Possible values: ""Disable"" or ""Fixed Voltage Source Sync"" or ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"".Default value: DisableRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Force synchronization to external source setting
Description: This setting controls if the UPS is forced to sync to the external source over Mains 2 (always use external source if it is available). Possible values: Enable/disable.Default value: Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Fixed Voltage Source Sync"".

Requirement: UPS is preferred External Sync Source setting
Description: Used in connection with the ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"" external sync function.Sets whether the given UPS is the preferred sync source if both UPS units are equally suited as external sync master. Only one UPS is allowed to be set as preferred sync source. Selectable values: Yes/NoDefault value: No Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"". Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Static Bypass Standby function enable setting
Description: Enable/disable the Static Bypass Standby function used in a dual UPS setup like shown below...  {Image: 1DFA1506-F63A-48A1-8600-702FF11AF940.bmp} The Static Bypass Standby function is used if UPS A or UPS B detects a fault and needs to enter static bypass. If the other UPS can supply the load from its inverter the faulty UPS will not be allowed to enter static bypass but instead change to Static Bypass Standby and turn off its output.This way the STS will be forced to select the UPS in inverter operation as output source to the load. Also if a dual feed load is connected it will only be supplied with power from the UPS running in inverter operation.Only if both UPS A and UPS B can no longer supply power via their inverters it will be allowed to enter static bypass and supply the load with power from Mains 2. Selectable values: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"". Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: UPS is fixed external sync. master setting
Description: Enable/disable a UPS in each block to be assigned to be fixed external sync. master. It is therefore sufficient to only wire the sync status connection signals to one of the parallel UPS units in each block as illustrated below…{Image: 79F13A70-219D-4AEE-A1CF-C5E7E7A47AAF.bmp}The above illustrated setup does not provide any redundancy when it comes to external synchronization. If the fixed external sync master UPS breaks down the external sync feature is lost.This might not be any problem if the paralleling is done for power and not redundancy. The automated parallel master UPS selection procedure will always ensure that the UPS connected to the external sync source signals is prioritized highest as master. The slave UPS(s) will use the Pbus to sync to the master. Selectable values: Enable/disable (only one UPS in a bitfield)Default value: DisableRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Only valid if External Sync Mode is set as ""Advanced Dual UPS Sync"".
