Setting for the UPS output frequency in Hz. Range: 50Hz and 60Hz.Default value: 50Hz.Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting is only configurable when the UPS AND the System are in Off Operation or Maintenance Bypass. Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Setting for the output synchronization speed (slew rate) in Hz/second. Possible values: 0.25; 0.5; 1; 2; 4; 6 Hz/secondDefault value: 1 Hz/second. Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Setting for output frequency tolerance in +/-Hz. Selectable from 1.0Hz, 3.0Hz and 10.0HzDefault +/-10Hz Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.Setting must be changeable in Inverter operation, as it must be possible to change the frequency tolerance in a scenario where the UPS is not synchronized to bypass due to a frequency out of tolerance, and the user wants to extend the frequency tolerance to allow the UPS to become sync again without having to go to forced static bypass operation with a break.

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is synchronized to the internal source.Note: This event is intended to be used in frequency converter mode instead of HOW31202 'Synchronization unavailable - system is freerunning'

Requirement: Inverter output is not in phase with bypass input
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS inverter output is not in phase with the bypass input.
There are 5 dry contactors and 4 wet contactors in Jedi design.

9 Dry contacts ( 4In + 5 Out),The dry contacts offer should ensure consistency and optimal re-use with our existing products in terms of behaviour, configurability etc.The inputs should be customisable with configurable warning or alarms to be picked in generic listThe outputs dry contacts should be customisable with configurable states, warnings or alarms to be picked in generic list. The product needs to offer both NO (normally open) and NC (normally closed) dry contacts for every inputs & outputs.If possible, additional IO Dry Contacts can be offered through an optional NMC (dry contacts board)  Background from GVX/GVM: Service RequirementWhen products are installed in a dedicated electrical room, it may be the single product installed in the room. A customer may add some device to monitor the installation and it may be nice to use the product to manage few alarms. Wish :Input dry contacts can be customized and configured by the operator writing his own message.It is then managed in all communication options that are available on the product (display, web,.....) Examples of alarms that can be monitored :---

The UPS shall have dry contactor input for indicating that it is on generator and this input is configurable by the user to limit the charge and battery powerAdaptive ramp in shall be available for smooth transition from battery operation to generator.Dry contactor output and wet contactor input?

Requirement: HOW - Dry contacts - Delay before activation
Description: Service RequirementOn some site, the output dry contacts are connected to a monitoring system that activates "on duty" activities.This is a simple signaling report to a guardroom - no GTC firmware treatment. The customer must be able to select a separate delay for each output relay (0 to 60 seconds). The delay is only used when activating the relay, not when deactivating it. The delay time is started as soon as the UPS reports the event which is associated to the given relay active .  The delaying will be configurable with the display and UPS Tuner. Selectable values: 0 to 60 secondsDefault value: 0 seconds. {Image: 5C78D7A6-DB27-4160-B58A-B5D7FAFDEA32.bmp}
SH Reason why: Jesper will add a general requirement for delays for all alarms.

For GVL, the external fault dry contact output must be activated if one or more of the following conditions are true: * Overload or short circuit on UPS  * Input voltage out of tolerance  * Input frequency out of tolerance  * Input phase missing  * Input phase sequence incorrect  * Neutral displacement detected  * Bypass voltage out of tolerance  * Bypass frequency out of tolerance  * Bypass phase missing  * Bypass phase sequence incorrect  * External battery monitoring detected fault  * Battery room ventilation inoperable  * Ground fault detected  * Ambient temperature high  * Ambient temperature out of tolerance  * EPO switch activated  * External sync voltage out of tolerance  * External sync frequency out of tolerance  * External sync phase missing  * External sync phase sequence incorrect
UOB is open on the given UPS.

Requirement: Output relay reaction time - time define by HW
Description: When a given function is configured to an output relay, the time from when the function is activated to when the output relay is activated, must be maximum 5 seconds.

The user must be able to configure a separate delay for each relay output (0 to 60 seconds).The delay must only be used when activating the output relay, not when deactivating it.The delay time must be started as soon as the UPS reports the event which is associated to the given output relay.  The delay must be configurable from display and UPS Tuner.  {Image: FBAF16C8-28AE-4B83-BD47-F4E3EF2F03CD.bmp}

It must be possible to configure, if a configurable output relay must be in energized check mode (failsafe mode), meaning the output relay is activated when the events associated with the output relay are not present (normally activated).This configuration must be individual for each output relay via a setting for each output relay.This way, it can be detected if the power supply to the output relays is lost, as all output relays will deactivate and the events associated with the output relays will be indicated as present.

If a critical event occurs, information about UPS voltages and currents contributes to a faster determination of the root cause of a given scenario or event at a customer site. Waveform capturing is therefore useful for diagnosing issues, getting even more detailed information about what might be the cause of a given event, and the reason behind the reaction pattern of the UPS.
A waveform capture must be triggered automatically by a number of predefined events.There must be a link between the waveform capture and which event in the event log that has triggered the capture.
It must be possible for the user to trigger a waveform capture manually.

Generally, the sample rate of the waveforms must be high enough to provide sufficient insight into why the event had occurred and to do failure and root-cause analysis.The sampling rate may differ depending on the source of the measurement. UPS input, output, bypass and DC bus voltages and currents must be sampled with a high frequency equal to the actual sampling frequency of the ADC used for the voltage quality detection, whereas measurements like temperatures can be sampled with a much lower rate.

The waveform capture length must be adequate to provide sufficient insight into why the event had occurred and to do failure and root-cause analysis.For UPS input, output, bypass voltages and currents a waveform capture must as a minimum consist of raw sampled measurement data from one period before, to one period after the event that has triggered the capture (minimum 60 ms. in total, with 30 ms. before and 30 ms. after the event that triggered the capture).
The waveform capture data and related information must be stored as files in non-volatile memory
The captured waveforms must be available to the user as a curve with a value (voltage, current etc) shown over time.
The child requirements lists the possible waveform sources to be captured. Depending on the product all waveforms may not be supported.
Input voltage, all 3 phases
Bypass voltage, all 3 phases
Output voltage, all 3 phases
Output current, all 3 phases
Battery voltage. If split battery, both positive and negative voltage.
DC bus voltage. Depending on the topology, there might be several DC bus voltages.
Ground voltage.The voltage between Neutral and Ground, measured in the UPS. Normally there is no voltage. Only in error scenarios, there would be voltages to capture.
The child requirements lists the possible events that must trigger a waveform capture. Depending on the product all events may not be supported.

The following event related to 'input voltage out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Input voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L1- Input voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L1- Input voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L2- Input voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L2- Input voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L3- Input voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L3- Input voltage waveform out of tolerance, L1- Input voltage waveform out of tolerance, L2- Input voltage waveform out of tolerance, L3
The following event related to 'input frequency out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Input frequency out of tolerance, high frequency- Input frequency out of tolerance, low frequency

The following event related to 'bypass voltage out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L1- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L1- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L2- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L2- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L3- Bypass voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L3- Bypass voltage waveform out of tolerance, L1- Bypass voltage waveform out of tolerance, L2- Bypass voltage waveform out of tolerance, L3

The following event related to 'bypass frequency out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Bypass frequency out of tolerance, high frequency- Bypass frequency out of tolerance, low frequency

The following event related to 'output voltage out of tolerance' must trigger a waveform capture:- Output voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L1- Output voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L1- Output voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L2- Output voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L2- Output voltage out of tolerance, high voltage L3- Output voltage out of tolerance, low voltage L3- Output voltage waveform out of tolerance, L1- Output voltage waveform out of tolerance, L2- Output voltage waveform out of tolerance, L3- DC voltage detected on output

UPS must provide the user with guided step-by-step sequences in the UPS display and UPS Tuner, which interactively helps the user to startup and shutdown an individual UPS or a complete parallel system. Guided seq in Jedi could be quite different from Agilis1. breakers ?2. no parallel in wave 13. no ECOnversion mode4. new seq for cold start5. seq for SBSC broken

Requirement: Startup Sequence - System startup from maintenance bypass (MBB)
Description: This sequence is valid for a complete system startup from maintenance bypass (load is supplied from Mains 2 via the MBB breaker).1.    Close breaker UIB (if present).2.    Close breaker SSIB (if present).3.    Close bypass backfeed breaker (if present).4.    Close battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by closed manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.5.    Initiate transfer to requested static bypass via button on the UPS touch screen display.6.    Close UOB breaker (if present).7.    Repeat step 1 to 5 for other parallel UPS units before continuing.8.    Close breaker SIB (if present).9.    Open breaker MBB.10.    Transfer load to normal operation via mechanical On button or button on the UPS touch screen display. (UPS will perform this step automatically and transfer to normal operation if nothing is preventing the inverter from turning on. If the inverter has been turned off manually by the user, this step must be performed manually).In a single UPS system step 7 will not be present.

The Startup Sequence - System startup from maintenance bypass (MBB) must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - MBB configured as present.- MBB is closed.- UPS operation mode is not Inverter Standby- UPS operation mode is not Static Bypass Standby

Requirement: Startup Sequence - Startup of an UPS into a parallel system already supplying the load - wave2
Description: This sequence is valid for startup of an UPS into a parallel system already supplying the load with conditioned power. 1.    Close breaker UIB (if present).2.    Close breaker SSIB (if present).3.    Close bypass backfeed breaker (if present).4.    Close battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by closed manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.5.    Close UOB breaker (if present).6.    Turn on inverter via on button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical on button.Repeat step 1 to 6 for other parallel UPS units.

Startup Sequence - Startup of an UPS into a parallel system already supplying the load must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - Parallel system with 2 or more UPS units- MBB configured as present.- MBB is open.- System operation mode is Inverter Operation or Wait Off Operation- UPS operation mode is Off Operation or Static Bypass Standby

Requirement: Startup Sequence - Frequency converter UPS - wave2
Description: This sequence is valid for starting up a single frequency converter UPS, startup of a parallel system of UPS units working as frequency converters (no bypass), and starting up a single frequency converter UPS into a running parallel system of UPS units working as frequency converters (no bypass). 1.    Close breaker UIB (if present).2.    Close battery breakers (only if present). Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by closed manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.3.    Close UOB breaker (if present).4.     Close breaker SIB (if present).5.    Turn on inverter via on button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical on button.
Startup Sequence - Frequency converter UPS must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled:

Requirement: Shutdown Sequence - Complete system shutdown from inverter operation (MBB)
Description: This sequence is valid for a complete system shutdown from inverter operation ending up with supplying the load from Mains 2 via the MBB breaker. 1.    Initiate transfer to static bypass via a button on the UPS touch screen display.2.    Close breaker MBB.3.    Open breaker SIB (if present).4.    Open breaker UOB (if present).5.    Turn UPS into Forced Static Bypass via off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button (if UOB and SIB are not present, this step will not be present as the UPS will automatically stay in static bypass).6.    Open breaker SSIB  (if present and MBB present).7.    Open battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by opened manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.8.    Open breaker UIB (if present).Repeat step 4 to 8 for other parallel UPS units.

The Shutdown Sequence - Complete system shutdown from inverter operation (MBB) must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - MBB configured as present.- UPS operation mode is Battery Operation or Normal Operation or Maintenance Bypass or Requested Static Bypass or Forced Static Bypass ** It is allowed to start the guided sequence even if some of the conditions/steps in the guide are already fulfilled. That is why the UPS operation modes Maintenance Bypass or Requested Static Bypass or Forced Static Bypass are also included in the allowed list.

Requirement: Shutdown sequence - Complete parallel system shutdown from inverter operation (MBB and common input breakers) - wave2
Description: This sequence is valid for a complete parallel system (with common input breakers) shutdown from inverter operation ending up with supplying the load from Mains 2 via the MBB breaker. 1.    Initiate transfer to static bypass via a button on the UPS touch screen display.2.    Close breaker MBB.3.    Open breaker SIB (if present).4.    Open breaker UOB (if present).5.    Turn UPS into Forced Static Bypass via off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button (if UOB and SIB are not present, this step will not be present as the UPS will automatically stay in static bypass).6.    Repeat step 4 and 5 for other parallel UPS units.7.    Open breaker SSIB  (if present and MBB present).8.    Open battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by opened manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.9.    Repeat step 8 for other parallel UPS units.10.  Open breaker UIB (if present).

The Shutdown sequence - Complete parallel system shutdown from inverter operation (MBB and common input breakers) must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - MBB configured as present.- Parallel system configured to have common input breaker(s)- UPS operation mode is Battery Operation or Normal Operation or Maintenance Bypass or Requested Static Bypass or Forced Static Bypass ** It is allowed to start the guided sequence even if some of the conditions/steps in the guide are already fulfilled. That is why the UPS operation modes Maintenance Bypass or Requested Static Bypass or Forced Static Bypass are also included in the allowed list.

Requirement: Shutdown Sequence - Shutdown of one UPS in a parallel system already supplying the load with power in inverter operation - wave2
Description: This sequence is valid for shutdown of one UPS in a parallel system already supplying the load with power in inverter operation. 1.    Turn off UPS via off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button.2.    Open breaker UOB (if present).3.    Open breaker SSIB (if present).4.    Open battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by opened manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.5.   Open breaker UIB (if present).

The "Shutdown Sequence - Shutdown of one UPS in a parallel system already supplying the load with power in inverter operation" must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - Parallel system with 2 or more UPS units- System operation mode is Inverter Operation- Another UPS is powering the load (is in Normal Operation, Battery Operation or Requested Static Bypass, and its UOB is closed) - UPS operation mode is Battery Operation or Normal Operation or Static Bypass Standby or Inverter Standby or Requested Static Bypass or the UOB of the UPS is open

Requirement: Shutdown Sequence - Shutdown of one UPS working as frequency converter - wave 2
Description: This sequence is valid for shutdown of one UPS working as frequency converter (no bypass). 1.    Turn off UPS via off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button.2.    Open breaker UOB (if present).3.    Open battery breakers (only if present). Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by opened manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.4.   Open breaker UIB (if present).If a parallel system, steps 1 to 4 must be repeated on all parallel UPS units. If a SIB is present, it must be opened after the guide has been completed on all parallel UPS units.

Requirement: Shutdown Sequence - Complete system shutdown from High Efficiency Mode (MBB)
Description: This sequence is valid for a complete system shutdown from High Efficiency Mode (ECO Mode) ending up with supplying the load from Mains 2 via the MBB breaker. 1.    Turn on inverter via on button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical on button.2.    Initiate transfer to static bypass via a button on the UPS touch screen display.3.    Close breaker MBB.4.    Open breaker SIB (if present).5.    Open breaker UOB (if present).6.    Turn UPS into Forced Static Bypass via off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button (if UOB and SIB are not present, this step will not be present as the UPS will automatically stay in static bypass).7.    Open breaker SSIB (if present).8.    Open battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by opened manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.9.    Open breaker UIB (if present).Repeat step 5 to 9 for other parallel UPS units.

Requirement: Prevent transfer to high efficiency mode while shutdown guided sequence is active
Description: To avoid that the UPS system automatically and suddenly transfers to high efficiency mode while the user is in the middle of a guided sequence, any transfers to high efficiency mode must be temporarily disabled while the guided sequence is active.

The Shutdown Sequence - Complete system shutdown from High Efficiency Mode (MBB) must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - MBB configured as present.- UPS operation mode is ECO Mode or ECOnversion

Requirement: Shutdown Sequence - Shutdown of one UPS in a parallel system already supplying the load with power in High Efficiency Mode - w2
Description: This sequence is valid for shutdown of one UPS in a parallel system already supplying the load with power in High Efficiency Mode (ECO Mode/ECOnversion). 1.  Turn on inverter via on button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical on button.2.    Turn off UPS via off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button.3.    Open breaker UOB (if present).4.    Open breaker SSIB (if present).5.    Open battery breakers. Depending on the system configuration the battery breakers must either by opened manually or automatically via a button or menu point in the UPS display.6.   Open breaker UIB (if present).

The "Shutdown Sequence - Shutdown of one UPS in a parallel system already supplying the load with power in High Efficiency Mode" must only be made available if certain conditions are fulfilled: - Parallel system with 2 or more UPS units- System operation mode is ECO Mode or ECOnversion Mode- Another UPS is powering the load (is in Requested Static Bypass (ECO Mode or ECOnversion Mode), and its UOB is closed) - UPS operation mode is Static Bypass Standby or Requested Static Bypass (ECO Mode or ECOnversion Mode) or the UOB of the UPS is open

Monitors wearing parts like fans and batteries, and reminds the customer when a technical check of the product is recommended. The customer can also be reminded to use certified Schneider Electric personnel to startup the product, and when the warranty is about to expire.

Requirement: User access level of LCM data
Description: The primary user of the LCM functionality is the FSR (Schneider Electric). The information obtained via the LCM can then be used to advice and support the customer.Warranty reminder:Must be shown directly to the customer in the HMI, but the settings associated to this reminder must only be configurable by the FSR through UPS TunerBattery technical check reminder and LCM:The settings associated to this reminder must only be configurable by the FSR through UPS Tuner. The reminder must also only be shown in UPS Tuner. If the technical check battery reminder is active, the general technical reminder must be shown to the customer in the HMI. This is the case no matter if the UPS has a SKU based or custom battery solution. Fans technical check reminder and LCM:The settings associated to this reminder must only be configurable by the FSR through UPS Tuner. The reminder must also only be shown in UPS Tuner. If the technical check fans reminder is active, the general technical reminder must be shown to the customer in the HMI. Air filter technical check reminder and LCM:The settings associated to this reminder must be configurable by both the customer via the HMI and by the FSR through UPS Tuner. The reminder must also be shown both in the HMI and in UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Air filter technical check reminder and LCM user interface on display
Description: The customer must be able to configure and get the status of the air filter reminder and LCM in a simple and easy understandable way. The following air filter LCM information must be shown to the customer in the display:- Air filter reminder enable setting [R/W]                              - Air filter expected lifetime settings: Fixed value (1 month / 3 months / 6 months / 1 year) [R/W]  - Remaining component life time (reminder remaining time status) [R] - Command to tell that the filter has been changed (Restart air filter service life duration command) [W]
An active reminder must be shown as a pop-up screen on the display and UPS Tuner, and as an active informational alarm.

It must be possible for the user to acknowledge a reminder or to select to be reminded later, via two buttons shown on the reminder pop-up screen.- If the reminder is acknowledged by the user, it must not be shown again.- If the user chooses to be reminded later, the reminder must be shown again after a certain time (configurable).- The reminder must only be shown a certain number of times (configurable) if the user continues to choose to be reminded later. After that, it must not be shown again.

Requirement: User configurable time interval between reminders
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the time interval between when two consecutive reminders are signalled.

Requirement: User configurable number of times to show a reminder
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the number of times a given reminder is shown if the user continues to select the ""remind me later"" option.

Requirement: User configurable time of day interval to show reminders
Description: To avoid disturbing the user with reminders in the middle of the night for example, it must be possible to configure a time of day interval where reminders are allowed to be signalled.
It must be possible for the user to enable and disable all the reminder signalling on a global level.
It must be possible for the user to enable and disable the reminder signalling individually for each of the available reminders.

In general, the UPS must provide reminders for each of the global component types that are monitored by a LCM and are replaceable on-site by the user (customer or FSR) on-site, like fans, air filters, batteries etc.There must also be reminders available for LMC functions that are not component specific like start-up, warranty etc.The child requirements of this requirement lists the reminders that must be available. The list may differ from product to product depending on for example which components are actually available in the UPS.

The UPS must provide a start-up reminder reminding customers that a good quality level is reached if the product is started up by Schneider Electric. Reminder must be displayed after the UPS has been powered on without interruption for 5 consecutive days. The reminder mustbe displayed 3 times maximum if start-up is not performed by Schneider Electric. It must be possible to disable reminder when doing the start up and using UPS Tuner. In case of UPS Tuner connection before the end of the 5 days, the start-up reminder must be automatically disabled by the firmware to avoid any confusing or annoying situation with our customer.{Image: 51BB808D-A8CB-4B46-BA7A-6AE7BB38D0E1.bmp}
The UPS must provide a warranty reminder, that reminds the customer when the warranty is about to expire.

If any of the components in the UPS monitored by the LCM function have reached end of life, the UPS must show a general technical check reminder in the display and UPS Tuner.This general technical check reminder is used for the customer if the details about which component has reached its end of life is hidden for the customer.

If the batteries of the UPS monitored by the LCM function have reached end of life, the UPS must show a technical check battery reminder in UPS Tuner (and in the display if customer is allowed to see the battery reminder in the given product).

If the fans of the UPS monitored by the LCM function have reached end of life, the UPS must show a technical check fans reminder in UPS Tuner (and in the display if customer is allowed to see the fans reminder in the given product)..

If the air filter of the UPS monitored by the LCM function have reached end of life, the UPS must show a technical check air filter reminder in UPS Tuner (and in the display if customer is allowed to see the battery reminder in the given product)..
It must be possible for the user to read the expected lifetime of each of the LCM monitored components in the UPS..

Generally, it must be possible for the user to configure the expected lifetime of each of the LCM monitored components in the UPS.It is however allowed that the expected lifetime of certain components are not user configable. This has to be evaluated for each product. For example, a power module might include several components that are monitored by LCM functions, but these components are not user replacable, so it is not required for the user to be able to configure the expected lifetime values.
It must be possible for the user to read the elapsed lifetime of each of the LCM monitored components in the UPS.

Generally, it must be possible for the user to configure the elapsed lifetime of each of the LCM monitored components in the UPS.It is however allowed that the elapsed lifetime of certain components are not user configable. This has to be evaluated for each product.For example, a power module might include several components that are monitored by LCM functions, but these components are not user replacable, so it is not required for the user to be able to configure the elapsed lifetime values.

Requirement: Components to be monitored by the technical check LCM
Description: The components of the UPS that must be monitored by the LCM functionality are listed as child requirements of this requirement. The list may differ from product to product depending on for example which components are actually available in the UPS.
All replaceable batteries connected to the product must be monitored by the LCM functionality.
All replaceable air filters in the product must be monitored by the LCM functionality.
All replaceable fans in the product must be monitored by the LCM functionality.
The fans in the power module must be monitored by a LCM function.All fans in the power module must be treated as one component and monitored  by one LCM.
The fans in the SBS module must be monitored by a LCM function.All fans in the SBS module must be treated as one component and monitored  by one LCM.
The fans in the UPS frame must be monitored by a LCM function.All fans in the UPS frame must be treated as one component and monitored by one LCM.
It must be possible to speed up the LCM counters for testing purposes.

Yes/No Default value : Yes. When this setting has the value "No", no reminders except "startup" and "technical check product revitalization" are displayed to the customer (if these are available in the given product), but the LCM mechanism is still running and available in UPS Tuner.

The UPS must include an event log with time stamped events to enable the user to track the behavior and status of the system and environment. The event log must enable the user (both customer and FSR) to do both general and failure diagnostics.It must be possible to have certain events act as alarms, meaning they are shown directly to the user in an alarm list if they are active.
The UPS event log must have differentiated levels for customer, service and R&D.

Requirement: Customer alarms vs service alarms - Global alarm
Description: Even if certain alarms are for service only, there must always exist a corresponding global alarm that is displayed to the customer.It must not be possible to have an active service alarm in the UPS without showing any alarm to the customer. Customer must know that an action is needed, even if it is just calling Schneider Electric for further assistance.

Requirement: Event if event log is cleared by user
Description: If the user clears the event log it must be logged in the event log after it has been cleared.

Requirement: Inverter on/off buttons - FW & HMI & Tuner
Description: The inverter on/off button functionality may also be made available for the user in the display and UPS Tuner. The exact UPS behavior in respons to these buttons is described in the "Sequences and behavior" requirement section.It must be logged in the event log if either of these buttons are activated by the user,It must also be alarmed and logged in the event log if the inverter is off due to the off button has been pushed by the user.

The conditions for being allowed to use inverter on button:- UPS is not already in inverter operation (battery operation or normal operation).- UPS is not self-test mode or SPoT modeThe conditions for being allowed to use inverter off button:- UPS is in inverter operation (battery operation or normal operation).The allowed conditions can be used to "grey out" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner, if a transfer is not allowed.

Requirement: User requested transfer in and out of requested static bypass
Description: It must be possible for the user to transfer the UPS between inverter operation and requested static bypass operation via buttons in the user interface (HMI, UPS Tuner). The exact UPS behavior in respons to these transfers is described in the "Sequences and behavior" requirement section.It must be logged in the event log if either of these buttons are activated by the user,

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The user has requested a transfer from inverter operation to bypass operation

Requirement: Out of bypass has been requested by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The user has requested a transfer from bypass operation to inverter operation

The conditions for being allowed to transfer UPS/system from Normal Operation to Requested Static Bypass:- System in Normal operation, Battery operation, Off operation or Requested Static Bypass- UPS is not in Static Standby operation- Bypass input voltage within tolerance- Inverter synchronized to bypass source- SBS is fully operational (self-test passed, no surveillance detected faults etc.)The conditions for being allowed to transfer UPS/system from Requested Static Bypass to Normal Operation:- System and UPS are in Requested Static Bypass operationThe allowed conditions can be used to "grey out" button on the display touch screen and UPS Tuner, if a transfer is not allowed.

The UPS must include a LED mimic diagram with 5 LEDs indicating the global operation and status of the following major parts/functions of the UPS:- Input (UIB, mains input, PFC)- Battery (battery, battery breaker)- Inverter- Output (output voltage, UOB)- Bypass (SSIB, bypass input, static bypass switch)Green LED must indicate function OK and in operation / on.Red LED must indicate function out of tolerance / faulty.LED off must indicate function OK and off.

Requirement: LED mimic diagram layout - Simple version
Description: The LED mimic diagram layout must be a simple compact version with five LEDs in a single row:{Image: D0E457FD-3ED8-44C5-8BF4-5883E5B41255.bmp}

Input LED Red:- Mains input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- UIB open or- PFC inoperable/shutdown or- PFC is off and UPS is not in ECOnversion modeGreen:- If not red and- PFC is in normal operationOff:- If not red or green (PFC is off)Bypass LED Red:- Bypass input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- SSIB or BF2** open or- SBS inoperable or- SBS is activated with a faultGreen:- If not red and- SBS is activatedOff:- if not red or green (SBS deactivated)Battery LED Red:- Battery inoperable* or- All battery breakers open / battery not connectedGreen:- If not red and- PFC in battery operationOff:- if not red or greenInverter LED Red:- Inverter inoperable/shutdownGreen:- If not red and- Inverter onOff:- if not red or green (inverter off)Output LED Red:- Load disconnected (UOB/SIB open) while UPS is not in off operation or- Output voltage out of tolerance while load is connected and UPS is not in off operationGreen:- If not red and- UPS is not in off operationOff:- if not red or green (UPS off operation)*Battery inoperable means one or more of the following conditions are true: - Battery voltage out of tolerance (high and low)- Battery voltage collapse- Battery configuration invalid- Battery capacity is below minimum acceptable level- Battery room ventilation inoperable- External battery monitoring detected fault- Battery fuse blown or battery relay is not working correctly- Battery not connected**Only if a BF2 actually exists and is present.

Requirement: LED mimic operation mode coloring scheme
Description: Off Operation{Image: FD383BC6-F81E-4F67-87D1-140E30057000.bmp}Input LED is shown as green, but can also be red or off in this operation mode.Normal Operation{Image: D7A61D13-C6D5-4651-905A-461124AE9229.bmp}Battery Operation{Image: 94249948-4A81-467E-9394-4063EAB7A9F9.bmp}Forced Static Bypass Operation{Image: B886FD33-6042-43A1-A6DE-E99BC2A163A8.bmp}Input LED is shown as green, and battery and inverter LEDs as off, but any of these LEDs can also be red in this operation mode.Requested Static Bypass Operation{Image: 72AA6E46-E690-4399-89CB-03D930CDD74F.bmp}ECO Mode{Image: 716BC225-6CC7-4DF7-84BD-A879DE2C8FCF.bmp}ECOnversion Mode{Image: E4EF024D-6760-468A-9CEC-35419C919EC6.bmp}

Requirement: Power flow and status mimic diagram
Description: The UPS must include a power flow and status mimic diagram on the display (may also be included on other interfaces like UPS Tuner).

Requirement: UPS power flow and status mimic diagram
Description: The UPS power flow and status mimic diagram must provide a general overview of the status and power flow of the UPS. The exact requirements are listed as child requirements.Below is an example of how a power flow and status mimic diagram can look like:{Image: 61961545-D085-4A7C-8D3A-8D70EC2D60E3.bmp}
The general power flow to the load, indicated by the colors black and green.

Requirement: Power flow to and from the battery
Description: The general power flow to and from the battery, indicated by the colors black and green, must be shown in bothHMI and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Status of the main components of the UPS
Description: The general status of the main components of the UPS (PFC, inverter, battery/charger, static bypass switch), indicated by the colors green (in operation and OK), red (inoperable) and black (not in operaion but operable).

Requirement: Status of the input, bypass and output sources
Description: The general status of the input, bypass and output sources, indicated by the colors green (within tolerance), red (out of tolerance) and black.

Requirement: Status of the switch gear breakers
Description: The status of the switch gear breakers (open or closed).

Requirement: Operation mode of the UPS and the system
Description: The operation mode of the UPS and the system.

Requirement: Main component status pictogram coloring scheme
Description: PFC pictogram  Red:- PFC inoperable/shutdownGreen:- If not red and- PFC is in normal operationOff:- If not red or green (PFC is off)SBS pictogram  Red:- SBS inoperable or- SBS is activated with a faultGreen:- If not red and- SBS is activated with no faultOff:- If not red or green (SBS deactivated) Battery pictogram  Red:- Battery inoperable or- All battery breakers open / battery not connectedGreen:- If not red and- PFC in battery operationOff:- If not red or green or- If UPS is configured to have no energy storageInverter pictogram  Red:- Inverter inoperable/shutdownGreen:- If not red and- Inverter onOff:- If not red or green (inverter off)

Input pictogram Red:- Mains input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- UIB openGreen:- If not redOff:- If not red or greenBypass pictogram  Red:- Bypass input out of tolerance (frequency, voltage) or- SSIB open or- Inverter is not able to synchronize to bypassGreen:- If not redOff:- If not red or green or- If transfer to static bypass is disabled by userOutput pictogram  Red:- Load disconnected (UOB/SIB open) while UPS is not in off operation or- Output voltage out of tolerance while load is connected and UPS is not in off operationGreen:- If not red and- UPS is not in off operationOff:- If not red or green (UPS off operation)

Requirement: Parallel system power flow and status mimic diagram - wave2
Description: In case the UPS is configured as part of a parallel UPS system, a parallel system power flow and status mimic diagram must be available, to provide a general overview of the status and power flow of the parallel system. The exact requirements are listed as child requirementsBelow is an example of how a parallel power flow and status mimic diagram can look like:{Image: 5 ups dual in_inverter_alarms in UPS}
The general power flow to the load, indicated by the colors black and green.

Requirement: Status of the switch gear breakers
Description: The status of the switch gear breakers (open or closed).
The operation mode of the system.

Requirement: Global alarm status of each parallel UPS
Description: The global alarm status of each parallel UPS (no alarm, informational alarm, warning alarm, critical alarm or communication lost).
The power flow and status mimic must take into account which breakers are configured as present, and only show the status of these.

Requirement: Take into account single/dual mains configuration
Description: The power flow and status mimic must take into account if the system is configured for single or dual mains, and draw the mimic accordingly.

Requirement: Take into account energy storage configuration
Description: The power flow and status mimic must take into account how the energy storage is configured (battery, flywheel, or no energy storage, depending on what is available in the given product), and draw the mimic accordingly.

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Out of tolerance (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Inoperable (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Inoperable (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Inoperable (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Out of tolerance (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Out of tolerance (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

Indicates general status to be used for coloring of the corresponding pictogram in the display mimic diagram. Status can be: * Inoperable (red).  * In operation and OK (green).  * None of the above (black).

The global alarm status of each parallel UPS.Five different values are possible:- No alarm present- Informational alarm(s) present- Warning alarm(s) present- Critical alarm(s) present- Communication lostThe highest severity alarm status must be the one shown. A communication lost has the highest severity.

If a module (power module, static switch, DC-DC converter etc.) has a status LED on the front the behavior and meaning should be as defined below.If multiple conditions exist - the one with lowest number will have priority.Example: If a module has a fault and is being updated, FW update indication has priority. 1. LED off - System unpowered.           No system functionality at all.2. Green fast flashing (4Hz) - System fw update ongoing.           Limited functionality or minor faults might be present3. Red slow flashing (2Hz) - System fault present.           Minor or major system fault present.4. Red - Fw-update failed.           Limited functionality might be present.5. Green slow flashing (2Hz) - System self test ongoing.           Limited functionality and not yet detected minor and major faults might be present.6. Green - System fully operational without errors.            No fw update is ongoing and no minor or major faults have been detected.

Definition of red slow flashing (2Hz) - System fault present.If one or more of the following conditions are true the power module status LED must be red slow flashing:- Charger shutdown active- Inverter shutdown active- PFC shutdown active- PM self-test did not pass- Lost communication to UC- Inverter self-test

Requirement: IM controller box enable switch status must be available to the user
Description: The current status of the IM controller box enable switch must be available to the user, and it must be logged in the event log when the IM controller box is enabled and disabled.

Requirement: Inverter on button status when UC controller box is disabled
Description: When the UC controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter, hence the inverter on button shown in display and UPS Tuner must be "grayed out" to make this clear for the user.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions-Post conditions- Main success scenario1. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass.2. Bypass is available (bypass voltage within tolerance, inverter sync to bypass, SBS ready)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to emergency static bypass.5. Controller box can be removed. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to emergency static bypass.5. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is not sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass with a break.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass).Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass voltage is out of tolerance (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is not allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 41. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. Bypass is not available3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 5NAAlternative scenario 61. UPS is in off operation.2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.3. The UPS stays in off operation.4. Controller box can be removed.Alternative scenario 71. UPS is in maintenance bypass.2. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.3. The UPS stays in maintenance bypass.4. Controller box can be removed.- For the main success scenario and alternative scenarios 1 and 2: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will return to inverter operation if possible.- For the alternative scenarios 3, 4 and 6: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in off operation.- For the alternative scenario 7: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in maintenance bypass.- While the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter (inverter on button will have no action).Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions  Post conditions. Main success scenario1. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. Controller box is inserted.3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.5. UPS transfers from forced static bypass to inverter operation. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. Controller box is inserted.3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass.5. UPS is not able to operate in inverter operation due to some reason.6. UPS stays in forced static bypass. Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in emergency static bypass2. MBB is closed.3. Controller box is inserted.4. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.5. UPS transfers to maintenance bypass.6. UPS stays in maintenance bypass.Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in off operation2. Controller box is inserted.3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'enable'.4. UPS stays in off operationSpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: UC controller box enable switch status
Description: Status of the UC controller box enable switch.Possible values: Enabled/disabled
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UC controller box has been enabled by user
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UC controller box has been disabled by user

The SBS module  must have an enable switch which controls if the SBS module must be enabled or disabled. - Before the SBS module is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the SBS module.- When the SBS module has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the SBS module.

Requirement: SBS module enable switch status must be available to the user
Description: The current status of the SBS module enable switch must be available to the user, and it must be logged in the event log when the SBS module is enabled and disabled.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions-Post conditions- Main success scenario1. UPS is in off, battery operation, normal operation or maintenance bypass.2. User sets the SBS module enable switch to 'disable'.3. SBS module powers off, opens the bypass backfeed contactor and becomes inoperable.4. UPS stays in the same operation mode.5. SBS module can be removed. Alternative scenario 11. UPS is in requested static bypass, ECO mode or ECOnversion mode.2. User sets the SBS module enable switch to 'disable'.3. SBS module powers off, turns off the SCRs, opens the bypass backfeed contactor and becomes inoperable.4. UPS transfers to inverter operation (normal or battery operation).5. SBS module can be removed.Alternative scenario 21. UPS is in forced static bypass.2. User sets the SBS module enable switch to 'disable'.3.SBS module powers off, turns off the SCRs, opens the bypass backfeed contactor and becomes inoperable.4. UPS transfers off operation and drops the load.5. SBS module can be removed.Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in emergency static bypass.2. User sets the SBS module enable switch to 'disable'.3. SBS module powers off, turns off the SCRs, opens the bypass backfeed contactor and becomes inoperable (load is dropped).4. SBS module can be removed.Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUPS              :     Pre conditions  Post conditions. Main success scenario1. UPS is in any operation mode2. SBS module is inserted.3. User sets the SBS module enable switch to 'enable'.4. SBS module powers on, transfers to ready mode, closes the bypass backfeed contactor and becomes operable if possible (the standard conditions of the SBS for changing operation mode and closing the bypass backfeed contactor determine which operation mode the SBS transfers to, and if the backfeed contactor is closed, after it has been enabled).5. UPS stays in the same operation mode. Alternative scenario 1NASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA
Status of the SBS module enable switch.Possible values: Enabled/disabled
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The SBS module has been enabled by user
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The SBS module has been disabled by user

The power module  must have an enable switch which controls if the power module must be enabled or disabled. - Before the power module is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the power module.- When the power module has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the power module.

When a power module is disabled, the power supply to the power module is turned off by hardware and the power module is powered down. This is not controlled by firmware.- Disabling a power module corresponds to a power module shutdown, and the UPS firmware must be able to handle this according to the requirements listed under 'Power module fault tolerance'.- Enabling a power module corresponds to powering up a power module, however the UPS firmware must be able to handle this according to the requirements listed under 'Power module hot swap' (disabling and enabling a power module corresponds to a power module swap).

The controller box must have an enable switch which controls if the controller (UC and SLC) must be enabled or disabled. - Before the controller box is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the controller.- When the controller box has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the controller.

Requirement: Controller box enable switch status must be available to the user
Description: The current status of the controller box enable switch must be available to the user, and it must be logged in the event log when the controller box is enabled and disabled.

Requirement: Inverter on button status when controller box is disabled
Description: When the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter, hence the inverter on button shown in display and UPS Tuner must be "grayed out" to make this clear for the user.

Bypass voltage is out of tolerance and inverter is sync to bypass (transfer to static bypass with bypass out of tolerance is allowed)3. User sets the controller enable switch to 'disable'.4. UPS transfers to forced static bypass with a break.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will transfer to emergency static bypass).Alternative scenario 31. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. UPS transfers to off operation.5. Controller box can be removed (when controller box is removed UPS will stay in off).Alternative scenario 41. UPS is in any operation mode except off operation and maintenance bypass..2. The UPS stays in maintenance bypass.4. Controller box can be removed.- For the main success scenario and alternative scenarios 1 and 2: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will return to inverter operation if possible.- For the alternative scenarios 3, 4 and 6: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in off operation.- For the alternative scenario 7: If controller box is disabled but not removed, and then enabled again, the UPS will stay in maintenance bypass.- While the controller box is disabled it is not possible to turn on the inverter (inverter on button will have no action).Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

There must be indicator lights available on the switch gear breakers/switches to guide the user to whether the switches/breakers can be operated safely with no risk of load drop.The following breakers/switches must have indicator lights available:- SSIB- UOB- MBB- SIB- IMB (if present in the product)- BF2 (if present in the product)

The user must be able to initiate a test of the switch gear indicator lights, which turns on and off all the indicator lamps in the switch gear with an interval of 2 seconds for a time of 20 seconds, making it possible to verify that the indicator lights are working correctly.
The HSSIB indicator lamp must be turned on/off according to the selection tree shown below: {Image: 32E1E8BE-21B9-471F-8F67-B8F68E0FAEBF.bmp}
The HUOB indicator lamp must be turned on/off according to the selection tree shown below: {Image: 2FCAD533-61AA-4815-97DC-DE5D4BDEAB3D.bmp}
The HMBB indicator lamp must be turned on/off according to the selection tree shown below: {Image: 628CC422-F5B0-4804-8192-AB08B103EDED.bmp}
The HSIB indicator lamp must be turned on/off according to the selection tree shown below: {Image: 54C3B150-05B7-4CA5-B94B-B2A56B9A26DF.bmp}
The HBF2 indicator lamp must be turned on/off according to the selection tree shown below: {Image: D8C3EF42-A3D0-4030-A813-A890E6BC927A.bmp}

Requirement: Switch gear indicator light test activate command
Description: Activate switch gear indicator light test via button on the display touch screen and/or a command from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Switch gear indicator light test activated by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Switch gear indicator light test activated has been activated by user.
The UPS must be able to monitor the status (open/closed) of the breakers/switches connected to the UPS.

Requirement: Switch gear breakers/switches to be monitored in a parallel UPS system TBD in wave2
Description: In a parallel UPS system, the status of the following switch gear breakers/switches (if present) on each individual UPS must be available to all the parallel UPS units:- UIB- SSIB- UOB- MBB- SIBThe current status of the present individual breakers/switches UIB, SSIB, UOB and IMB on each parallel UPS must be visible to the user.The current status of the common breakers/switches MBB and SIB reported by each parallel UPS must be used to determine the global status of the given breaker/switch.- The MBB must be determined as closed by the parallel system, if one or more parallel UPS report(s) MBB as closed.- The MBB must be determined as open by the parallel system, when all parallel UPS units report MBB as open.- The SIB must be determined as closed by the parallel system, if one or more parallel UPS report(s) SIB as closed.- The SIB must be determined as open by the parallel system, when all parallel UPS units report SIB as open.

Requirement: Possible to configure which switch gear breakers/switches are present
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure which switch gear breakers/switches are present in the UPS system. A configuration change must be logged in the event log.

Requirement: Configuration of which switch gear breakers/switches are present in a parallel system  - wave 2
Description: The configuration of which of the individual breakers/switches are present on each UPS must be distributed to all UPS units in a parallel system. It must only be possible for the user to configure which of the individual breakers are present for each parallel UPS locally from the given UPS where they are connected. The configuration of which of the common breakers/switches (MBB and SIB) are present must be distributed and kept the same on all UPS units in a parallel system. It must be possible for the user to configure which of the common  breakers are present from all the parallel UPS units..

Requirement: Possible to configure if parallel system has common input breaker(s) - wave 2
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if the parallel system has common input breaker(s).Common input breaker(s) means that the parallel system has one UIB and/or one SSIB (depending on which of these two breakers are configured as present).If system includes a parallel power flow and status mimic in the display, this must be drawn according to the value of this setting.

Requirement: Alarm if status of common breakers are not the same on all parallel UPS units - wave 2
Description: The status of common breakers (MBB and SIB) in a parallel system are detected by each individual parallel UPS. Under normal circumstances all UPS units should detect the same status of these breakers. If this is not the case an alarm must be posted to the user.If the parallel system is configured to have common input breaker(s) an alarm must also be posted if the common UIB and/or SSIB are not detected to have the same status on all parallel UPS units.

If a breaker has redundany monitoring (two AUX contacts), the following rules must be followed:The breaker is considered closed if this is reported by at least one AUX contact.The breaker is considered open if this is reported by both AUX contacts.If the two redundant AUX contacts on a breaker do not report the same status, the user must be notified via an alarm and an event in the event log.

Requirement: Redundant breaker monitoring of MBB and UOB
Description: The UPS must have redundant (two AUX contacts) monitoring of MBB and UOB.

Requirement: Possible to configure if UOB has redundant monitoring
Description: It must be possible to configure if the UPS must use the redundant UOB monitoring input or not via a setting in UPS Tuner.This is to enable using the UPS in an existing installation (replacing an old product) with non-redundant UOB monitoring.
Setting for whether circuit breaker UIB, is present or not. Range: Yes/NoDefault value: Yes
Setting for whether circuit breaker SSIB, is present or not. Range: Yes/NoDefault value: Yes
Setting for whether circuit breaker UOB, is present or not. Range: Yes/NoDefault value: Yes

Setting for whether circuit breaker MBB, is present or not. Range: Yes/NoDefault value: YesRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Sets whether or not a SIB is present. Range: Yes / NoDefault value: Yes Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Common input breaker present in parallel system setting - wave2
Description: Setting to indicate if the parallel system has common input breaker(s) (UIB and SSIB) or not. Range: Yes / NoDefault value: NoRequired check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.
Setting to indicate if the UPS must use redundant UOB status monitoring or not.Range: Yes / NoDefault value: Yes

Status of the breakers in the switch gear.Possible values: Open/closed The possible breakers are (depending on the product): UIB, UOB, MBB, SIB, SSIB and IMB (same as MBB but located internally in the UPS) {Image: 8024F508-01B6-4645-A6CF-AC30ABBBBA2D.bmp} {Image: 03A3F0A2-30C1-43C0-8238-2CD9AE061110.bmp} In a parallel setup the status of all breakers in the system must be available/shown on all parallel UPS units.

Requirement: Reject__Kirk key interlock (SKRU - Solenoid Key Release Unit)
Description: only for UL certification productNot designed in Jedi productThe UPS must support a Kirk key interlock system (SKRU- Solenoid Key Release Unit) on the switchgear, as described in Scheme 39 shown here below:{Image: 460B58A6-F133-4D24-BF30-73AB7EE2122A.bmp}

The UPS must include an output relay for the Kirk key interlock system, which is activated if the UPS is in static bypass, so that the key can be released to close the MBB and transfer the UPS to maintenance bypass.An event must be stored in the event log when the status of the SKRU output relay changes.

The UPS must include an input contact for the Kirk key interlock system to indicate that the UPS must stay locked in static bypass.If the UPS enters (or is already in) requested static bypass or forced static bypass, it must stay in static bypass as long as this input contact is active, even if all other conditions for being in requested static bypass or forced static bypass are no longer present. Just activating this input contact while the UPS is not in static bypass must not force the UPS to transfer to static bypass.An alarm must be shown to the user when the SKRU input contact is active and the UPS is locked in static bypass.

Requirement: Transfer from inverter to maintenance bypass sequence with SKRU
Description: Below is a sequence describing how to transfer the UPS from inverter to maintenance bypass using a Kirk key interlock (SKRU) system. Steps in italic are performed by the system and not by the user:1.     Initiate transfer to requested static bypass via a button on the UPS touch screen display.2.     - UPS activates the SKRU output relay (key A in SKRU interlock can be removed) -3.     Turn and remove key A from SKRU interlock.4.     - SKRU input contact is activated -5.     Insert key A in MBB interlock and turn it6.     Close breaker MBB.7.     - Key A is now held in MBB interlock -8.     Open breaker UOB9.     Turn and remove key B from UOB interlock10.   Insert key B in SKRU interlock and turn it11.   - Key B is now held in SKRU interlock -12.   - SKRU input contact is deactivated -13.   - UPS transfers to inverter operation as SKRU input contact is no longer active - 14.   - UPS deactivates the SKRU output relay -15.   Transfer UPS into forced static bypass via inverter off button on the UPS touch screen display or via mechanical off button16.   Open breaker SSIB17.   Open battery breakers.18.   Open breaker UIB.

Requirement: Transfer from maintenance bypass to inverter sequence with SKRU
Description: Below is a sequence describing how to transfer the UPS from maintenance bypass to inverter using a Kirk key interlock (SKRU) system. Steps in italic are performed by the system and not by the user:1.     Close UIB2.     Close SSIB3.     Close battery breakers4.     Initiate transfer to requested static bypass via a button on the UPS touch screen display.5.     - UPS activates the SKRU output relay (key B in SKRU interlock can be removed) -6.     Turn and remove key B from SKRU interlock7.     - SKRU input contact is activated -8.     Insert key B in UOB interlock and turn it9.     Close UOB10.     - Key B is now held in UOB interlock -11.   Open MBB12.   - UPS stays in forced static bypass as SKRU input contact is active -13.   Turn and remove key A from MBB interlock14.   Insert key A in SKRU interlock and turn it15.   - SKRU input contact is deactivated -16.   - UPS returns to inverter operation -17.   - UPS deactivates the SKRU output relay (key A in SKRU interlock cannot be removed) -

Requirement: User configurable if Kirk key interlock (SKRU) is present or not
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure if a Kirk key interlock system (SKRU) is present and used, or not.

Requirement: Kirk key interlock in a parallel UPS system
Description: Kirk key interlock must be supported in a parallel UPS system.If the SKRU input contact is activated on one or more of the parallel UPS units that has UOB closed (no matter if it is a parallel master or slave), and the parallel system enters (or is already in) requested static bypass or forced static bypass, it must stay in static bypass as long as the SKRU input contact is active on any of parallel UPS units

Requirement: Guided sequences support for Kirk key interlock (SKRU)
Description: When Kirk key interlock support is enabled, the guided sequences must take this into account by adding the necessary steps to guide the user through start-up and shutdown of the system using the Kirk key interlock system.

Requirement: Assembly on site / scaleable solutions - FW
Description: Assembly on site - i.e. power module shipped separately to be installed by installer during installation

Requirement: Removal of power module after insertion into frame
Description: Do not ask to remove the power modules from frame after taken out from packaging box and inserted into frame. Exceptions (i.e. repair/replace activities on deep embedded PCBA's with low failure rate) must be accepted by services representative.

Requirement: self detection and self diagnosis during start-up
Description: UPS should detect the power modules by itself and do the self diagnosis during start-up and avoid any iterations at site

Requirement: Means to validate & Ensure factory level of quality
Description: Means (i.e. SPOT test) to validate & Ensure factory level of quality on commissioned system when frame and modules are shipped separately

Requirement: Sequences and behavior - FW - Grooming during implemention
Description: In this category, we describe the behavior for 3 phases (3PP) UPS. These behaviors are generic and must be applied on all 3PP UPSs The behavior descriptions are devided into sections depending on what affects the system to respond with a given behavior.Each behavior scenario is described in a standardized format, a so-called Use Case. The format of the Use Cases is as follows... Primary Actor(s)Lists the primary actor(s) of this use case. This can for example be a user (FSE, customer etc.) or the UPS itself.Stakeholders and InterestsLists all the stakeholders of this use case there special interests.Pre conditionsLists any conditions that must be fulfilled before the main success and alternative scenarios can take place.Post conditionsLists any conditions that are fulfulled after the main success and/or alternative scenarios has been completed.Main success scenarioDescribes the main scenario of this use case. This is the "normal" behavior under the expected conditions.The scenario is described in list form where each point in the list is a action or reaction. Alternative scenariosLists any alternative scenarios to the main success scenario.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. Single UPS system with internal bypass static switch.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.      The UPS is in inverter on and supplies the load.2.      The Mains 2 is within limits.3.      User pushes the off button on the UPS.4.      The UPS enters forced static bypass operation without break.5.      The UPS indicates via an alarm that inverter is Off due to a request by the user. Alternative scenariosScenario 1a:1.      The UPS is in inverter on and supplies the load.2.      The Mains 2  is out of tolerance and output synchronized to bypass3.      User pushes the off button on the UPS.4.      The UPS displays a warning and requires user to confirm action.5.      User confirms the action via a button on the display.6.   UPS enters forced static bypass operation without break7.      The UPS indicates via an alarm that inverter is Off due to a request by the user. Scenario 1b:1.    The UPS is in inverter on and supplies the load.2.    The Mains 2  is out of tolerance and output not synchronized to bypass3.    User pushes the off button on the UPS.4.    The UPS displays a warning and requires user to confirm action.5.    User confirms the action via a button on the display.6.   UPS enters forced static bypass operation with break7.      The UPS indicates via an alarm that inverter is Off due to a request by the user. Scenario 2:1.      The UPS is in inverter on and supplies the load.2.      The bypass static switch  is not available3.      User pushes the off button on the UPS.4.      The UPS displays a warning and requires user to confirm action.5.      User confirms the action via a button on the display.6.   UPS enters off operation Scenario 3:1.      The UPS is in inverter on and supplies the load.2.      The Mains 2  is out of tolerance or the bypass static switch  is not available3.      User pushes the off button on the UPS.4.      The UPS displays a warning and requires user to confirm action.5.      User does not confirm the action via a button on the display.6.   UPS stays in inverter on operation.   1. “Push off button” means pressing the button for more than 3 seconds. Technology and data variations listNAOpen issues  Special requirements

Primary Actor(s)UserStakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. The UOB is open.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.    The UPS is in off operation.2.    The system is in off operation, in inverter operation, requested static bypass operation or forced static bypass operation.3.    The UOB is closed.4.    The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode and continues in the same operation mode (off operation).Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.    The UPS is in off operation, inverter operation, requested static bypass operation or forced static bypass operation.2.    The system is in maintenance bypass.3.    The UOB is closed.4.    The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode.5.    The UPS enters the same operation mode as the system (maintenance bypass). Scenario 2a:1.    Other UPS with UOB closed present in the system  2.    The UPS is in inverter operation, requested static bypass operation or forced static bypass operation.3.    The system is in inverter operation or in off operation.4.    The UOB is closed.5.    The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode.6.    The UPS enters off operation. Scenario 2b:1. No other UPS with UOB closed present in the system2. The UPS is in inverter operation, requested static bypass operation or forced static bypass operation.3. The system is off operation (UOB open).4. The UOB is closed.5. The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode6. The UPS continues in the same operation mode and the system enters the same operation mode as the UPS. Scenario 3:1.    The UPS is in inverter operation, requested static bypass operation or forced static bypass operation.2.    The system is in forced static bypass operation.3.    The UOB is closed.4.    The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode.5.    The UPS enters the same operation mode as the system (forced static bypass operation).6.     If possible the system returns to normal operation. Scenario 4:1.    The UPS is in inverter operation2.    The UPS has a faulty static bypass switch3.    The system is in forced static bypass operation.4.    The UOB is closed.5.    The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode.6.    The UPS enters static bypass standby operation. Scenario 5:1. The UPS is in requested static bypass operation.2. The system is in requested static bypass operation.3. The UOB is closed.4. The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode.5. The UPS enters the same operation mode as the system (requested static bypass operation). Scenario 6:1. The UPS is in inverter operation or forced static bypass operation.2. The system is in requested static bypass operation.3. The UOB is closed.4. The UPS goes out of Maintenance Mode.5. The UPS enters off operation.  Special requirements                                                 NATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNASpecial requirements

Behavior scenarios specific to electrical changes in the installation surrounding the UPS.

Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Behavior when mains voltage is below nominal valuePre conditionsThe UPS is in normal operation and batteries are connected. Load is at 100% or below.Post conditionsUPS is in normal operation, battery operation or bypass operation supplying the load from inverter if possible otherwise from Mains 2.Main success scenarioScenario 1: 1. Mains 1 voltage level is decreased below nominal voltage level.  2. When the mains 1 input current limit (refer to ???) has been reached the UPS will decrease battery charge power abilities gradual to zero charging herby avoiding mains overload.  3. When charger power has reached zero the UPS will start to draw power from batteries if further power is needed or continues operating in input overload mode.  4. In this state the UPS will transfer to battery operation either caused by input current limitation or input overload state timeout (refer to ???).Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Mains 1 voltage level is increased above maximum voltage level (refer to ???) on a single or dual feed system.  2. The UPS will transfer to battery operation.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Behavior when Mains 2 voltage is below nominal valuePre conditionsThe UPS is in normal or bypass operation and batteries are connected. UPS is in forced static bypass operation supplying the load from Mains 2.  2. Mains 2 out of tolerance (drops below limit) (refer to ???).  3. UPS continues in forced static bypass operation Scenario 3: 1. UPS is in forced static bypass operation supplying the load from Mains 2.  2. Mains 2 not available (refer to ???).  3. Bypass is turned off and load is dropped Alternative scenariosNA Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA
