Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Behavior when battery voltage is below nominal valuePre conditionsThe UPS is in battery operation and batteries are connected. Load is at 100% or below.Post conditionsLoad is being supplied from inverter if possible otherwise from Mains 2.Main success scenarioScenario 1: 1. Mains 2 within tolerance and bypass switch available  2. If battery voltage level is below shutdown limit (refer to product specification) the UPS is transferred to forced static bypass operation. In a split battery system the lowest measured value is used.  3. After a given time and voltage conditions, battery breaker will be tripped Scenario 2a: 1. Mains 2 out of tolerance, output not synchronized to bypass and bypass switch available  2. If battery voltage level is below shutdown limit (refer to product specification) the UPS is transferred to forced static bypass operation with break.   3. After a given time and voltage conditions, battery breaker will be tripped Scenario 2b: 1. Mains 2 out of tolerance, output synchronized to bypass and bypass switch available  2. If battery voltage level is below shutdown limit (refer to product specification) the UPS is transferred to forced static bypass operation.  3. After a given time and voltage conditions, battery breaker will be trippedScenario 3: 1. Mains 2 not available or bypass switch not available  2. If battery voltage level is below shutdown limit (refer to product specification) the UPS is turned OFF  3. After a given time and voltage conditions, battery breaker will be tripped Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Behavior when battery voltage is above nominal valuePre conditionsThe UPS is in normal, bypass or battery operation and batteries are connected. UPS in requested static bypass operation  2. Downstream short between two or more output phases.  3. UPS in forced static bypass operation, short is cleared.  4. UPS will turn off as soon as it exceeds time limit and drop the load. Scenario 3: 1. UPS in forced static bypass operation (inverter not available)  2. Downstream short between two or more output phases.  3. UPS stays in forced static bypass operation, short is cleared.  4. UPS continue in forced static bypass operation Scenario 4: 1. UPS in forced static bypass operation (inverter not available)  2. Downstream short between two or more output phases.  3. UPS stays in forced static bypass operation, short not cleared.  4. Mains 2 fuse or upstream/downstream circuit protection fault.  5. UPS will turn off as soon as it exceeds time limit and drop the load.  Special requirementsAn event must be logged in the UPS event log if a high current is detected (due to output short) while in requested static bypass.Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: High current detection while in requested static bypass operation
Description: If an output short-circuit takes place while the UPS is in requested static bypass, the UPS must transfer directly to forced static bypass to try and clear the short.In the same time, it is required that the UPS transfers from requested static bypass to inverter operation if an output voltage error is detected, which would also be the case if the output is short-circuited.So, to ensure that the UPS transfers from requested static bypass to forced static bypass in case of an output short, the current flowing in bypass (output current) must be measured in this scenario and if it is 3 times the nominal current or the current has reached the maximum measurable limit, the UPS must transfer to forced static bypass instead of inverter operation.

Requirement: High current detected while in static bypass
High current in static bypass operation no longer detected
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: A high current is no longer detected in static bypass operation.

Requirement: High current in static bypass operation detected
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Reduce load on system or check for output short circuit.Description: A high current has been detected when in static bypass operation. This can be caused by an overload or a short circuit downstream

Primary Actor(s)-          User.-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to have the load protected and be informed of any errors in the system.UPS              : Wants to avoid damaging the load.Pre conditionsThe UPS is powered on.Post conditionsThe load is protected from damage due to a DC voltage.Main success scenario 1. UPS is running in inverter operation.  2. Mains 2 within tolerance.  3. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  4. System transfers to forced static bypass operation.  5. UPS alarms the user about the error. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. UPS is running in inverter operation.  2. Mains 2 not available or static bypass swich faulty.  3. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  4. System turns off and drops the load.  5. UPS alarms the user about the error Scenario 2: 1. UPS is running in requested static bypass operation.  2. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  3. UPS transfers to inverter operation.  4. UPS alarms the user about the error Scenario 3: 1. UPS is running in forced or emergency static bypass operation.  2. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  3. UPS turns off and drops the load.  4. UPS alarms the user about the error Scenario 4: 1. UPS is running in inverter operation.  2. Mains 2 out of tolerance.  3. UPS detects a DC voltage on the output.  4. System transfers to forced static bypass operation.  5. UPS alarms the user about the error.   Special requirementsDC voltage means voltage coming from shorted power circuit causing DC bus voltage on output or half wave due to one thyristor not conductingTechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Transfer to Forced Static Bypass with Mains 2 Out of Tolerance
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsLoad, UPS              : Avoid sudden phase shifts in output voltage when transferring to forced static bypass.Pre conditionsThe UPS is in inverter operation and batteries are connected.Post conditions.Main success scenario 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. A fault is detected which requires the UPS to transfer to forced static bypass.  3. UPS is able to transfer to forced static bypass without a break in the output voltage (UPS synchronized to Mains 2).  4. UPS turns off inverter and activates bypass static switch immediately.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. A fault is detected which requires the UPS to transfer to forced static bypass.  3. UPS is not able to transfer to forced static bypass without a break in the output voltage (UPS not synchronized to Mains 2).  4. UPS turns off inverter and activates bypass static switch after a given period (creates a break in the output voltage).  Scenario 2: 1. UPS is in inverter operation.  2. A user requests the UPS to transfer to forced static bypass (for example via the off button).  3. UPS is not able to transfer to forced static bypass without a break in the output voltage (UPS not synchronized to Mains 2 and/or Mains 2 voltage is out of tolerance).  4. UPS asks the user to confirm transfer to forced static bypass with a possible break in the output voltage.  5. User confirms transfer.  6. If UPS synchronization to Mains 2 succeeds UPS turns off inverter and activates bypass static switch immediately else the bypass static switch activates after a given period (creates a break in the output voltage). Special requirementsThe output voltage break time may differ from product to product and may be configurable. Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Handling of ""Transfer to Static Bypass with Mains 2 Out of Tolerance"" Setting
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsLoad, UPS              : If setting is set as "No" then avoid transferring to forced static bypass if Mains 2 is out of tolerance.Pre conditionsThe setting for "Transfer to Static Bypass with Mains 2 out of tolerance" is set to No.The default value of this setting must be Yes, so that per default the load will be supplied as long as possible. It must be an active choice taken by the customer/FSE to differ from this.Post conditions.Main success scenario 1. UPS is in inverter operation and Mains 2 is within tolerance.  2. A fault is detected which requires the UPS to transfer to forced static bypass operation.  3. UPS transfers to forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. UPS is in inverter operation and Mains 2 is out of tolerance.  2. A fault is detected which requires the UPS to transfer to forced static bypass operation.  3. UPS do NOT transfer to forced static bypass operation but instead turns off the output and drops the load. Scenario 2: 1. UPS is in forced static bypass operation and Mains 2 is within tolerance.    2. Mains 2 becomes out of tolerance.  3. UPS stays in forced static bypass operation.

Requirement: Transfer Back From Forced Static Bypass
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsLoad, UPS              : Ensure conditioned power to load whenever possible.Pre conditionsThe UPS is in forced static bypass due to some fault.Post conditions.Main success scenario 1. Fault is classified as recoverable.  2. Fault disappears.  3. UPS is able to transfer from forced static bypass without a break in the output voltage (phase difference between Mains 2 and UPS output voltage is less than 13 degrees (UPS synchronized to Mains 2)).  4. UPS returns to inverter operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. Fault is classified as non-recoverable.  2. Fault disappears.  3. UPS stays in forced static bypass operation.  Special requirementsThe classification of recoverable and non-recoverable faults may differ from product to product depending on topology.Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: General Forced Static Bypass Behavior Principle
Description: Static switch thermal protectionStandard configurationUPS should work as long as it is possible in Forced Static Bypass (also Emergency Static Bypass) even with thermal overload. Thermal overload must be reported to the user.
The UPS must support transformers on the input and output when operating as a single UPS system.

It must be possible for the user to compensate for a downstream transformer and balance the output voltage drop.The output transformer voltage compensation must work without having the UPS to measure the voltage on the secondary side of the transformer.At 0% load the user must measure the voltage at the secondary side of the transformer, and the output voltage of the UPS is then manually adjusted via a setting to offset compensate if necessary (this setting is described under ther "Adjustable output voltage compensation" requirement).Then load must be applied on the UPS. The voltage at the secondary side of the transformer must be measured again by the user, and the output voltage of the UPS is adjusted via a setting to compensate for the voltage drop in the transformer.The voltage compensation required at the specific load is used to make an automatic linear output voltage adjustment on the UPS according to the output load percentage.

Requirement: Output voltage compensation with loaded transformer setting
Description: Setting for adjusting the output voltage to compensate for load dependant transformer voltage drop. Default value: 0%Range: 0%, 1%, 2% and 3% When compensation is set to 0 the output transformer voltage compensation will be disabled.Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchronized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup if transformer on output is allowed for parallel setup in the product.

Requirement: Output voltage compensation with loaded transformer - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Output voltage compensation with loaded transformer - setting has been changed.
It must be possible fo the user to configure if an input transformer is present or not
It must be possible for the user to configure if an output transformer is present or not

Requirement: Transformers in power flow and status mimic in HMI
Description: The HMI must show if an input or output transformer is present via a symbol in the single UPS power flow and status mimic diagram.Example from GVX: {Image: F07DEF86-21EE-4F1A-852C-FBAF30438972.bmp}{Image: CCF85937-3E65-4F58-8826-F5899D95D59A.bmp}

There must be a configurable dry contact input available, where the user can choose to connect the temperature switch from the auxiliary transformers. When the input is configured, and activated, an alarm must be shown in the active alarm list.If only one input is available and both input and output transformers are present, the 2 temperature switches must be connected in series.

Setting to tell if a transformer is present on the input, output of the UPS, or not present.Possible values: 'No transformer present', 'input transformer present', 'output transformer present', 'input and output transformer present'. Default value: No transformer present

Requirement: Voltage quality detection -- all item detail need to confirm during implemention
Description: The UPS must be able to monitor the mains input, the bypass input, and the output of the UPS, and detect if these are not within the defined tolerances. The following parameters must be monitored:- Voltage - RMS for each phase L1, L2 and L3 of  mains input, bypass input and UPS output- Voltage - waveform for each phase L1, L2 and L3 of  mains input, bypass input and UPS output- Frequency of  mains input, bypass input and UPS output- Phase missing for mains input and bypass input- Neutral displacement- DC on output- Waveform for DC bus- DC bus low shutdown- DC bus collapse

Requirement: Out of tolerance detection limits must be user configurable
Description: The user must be able to configure the limits for when a voltage is detected as being out of tolerance,

Requirement: Out of tolerance detection must be logged
Description: The user must be notified via events in the event log and alarms in the alarm list, if a voltage is detected as being out of tolerance by the voltage quality detection.

Requirement: Output relay indicating if input is out of tolerance
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if the input is out of tolerance.This covers:- Input voltage out of tolerace (waveform and/or RMS)- Input frequency out of tolerance- Input phase sequence incorrect- Input phase missing

Requirement: Output relay indicating if bypass is out of tolerance
Description: It must also be possible for the user to configure an output relay to activate if bypass is out of tolerance.This covers:- Bypass voltage out of tolerace (waveform and/or RMS)- Bypass frequency out of tolerance- Bypass phase sequence incorrect- Bypass phase missing

Setting for the output voltage tolerance levelRange: +/-3 to +/-10 %Default value: +/-10% Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Setting for the output frequency tolerance in +/-Hz. Range: 1.0Hz, 3.0Hz and 10.0HzDefault value: +/-10Hz Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.Setting must be changeable in Inverter operation, as it must be possible to change the frequency tolerance in a scenario where the UPS is not synchronized to bypass due to a frequency out of tolerance, and the user wants to extend the frequency tolerance to allow the UPS to become sync again without having to go to forced static bypass operation with a break.

Requirement: Input out of tolerance - output relay setting
Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate that input is out of tolerance.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Bypass out of tolerance - output relay setting
Description: Setting to configure an output relay to indicate that bypass is out of tolerance.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: Disable

Requirement: Reset to factory default settings only allowed from UPS Tuner
Description: It is only allowed to do a reset of settings to factory default from UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Settings not allowed to be reset
Description: The following settings must not be reset to default by a reset settings to factory default command:- Serial number of UPS- Frame type- Product Registration status- LCM counter

Requirement: Reset to factory default settings allowed
Description: The function reset to factory settings can only be done when the UPS is in initialize state, off operation or in maintenance bypass. If the UPS is in any other operation mode, the command should be rejected.

Requirement: Reset to factory default settings warning
Description: When user chooses to command a reset of settings to factory default, a warning must be shown and user must confirm the action. The user must also be notified that a reboot (complete power down and power up) of the UPS is required.

Requirement: Reset settings to factory default command
Description: Command to reset the UPS settings to the factory default values.

Requirement: Settings reset to factory default by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS settings have been reset to factory default by the user.
The UPS must provide a means to update the UPS firmwareNeed to update new FWU seq details in Jedi

Requirement: Firmware update of all controllers from one port
Description: The firmware of all intelligent boards and controllers in the UPS must be updatable from the service port using UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Firmware release in one complete package
Description: The firmware must be released three packagesPackage 1. containing internal firmware images for each controller in the UPS.(IM/PMC/SBSC/SMC)Package 2. HMIPackage 3. NMC

Requirement: Progress and status of firmware update available to user
Description: The progress and status of the firmware update procedure must shown in Tuner and UPS display.All three packages fwu status should be displayed.

Requirement: Firmware update of a parallel system - wave2
Description: For a parallel redundant UPS system, it must be possible to firmware update each UPS separately while the load is supplied from inverter (no need to turn off or transfer the load to Maintenance Bypass) as long as the new firmware is compatible with the old one present in the system.If the parallel system is not redundant, it is allowed that the load must be off or in Maintenance Bypass to complete the firmware update, if the controller architecture of the system does not allow otherwise.

Requirement: User notification of when to transfer to maintenance bypass during firmware update
Description: If the firmware update procedure requires the system to be off or in maintenance bypass to complete, the user must be notified, when a transfer to off or maintenance bypass is required.
The firmware package must be signed to ensure that only genuine firmware from Schneider Electric can used for the UPS.

Requirement: Abort a firmware update - no need in wave1
Description: It must be possible for the user to abort a firmware update in progress but only during download of the firmware package.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The firmware update procedure has been completed successfully.

A category for collecting the requirements for updating a complete system
The firmware update of the system at customers must only be allowed through the service port using UPS Tuner.HMI package update through HMINMC package ???

The SMC??? must check the system firmware package for a correct signing, and discard the file if it is not signed correctly.An event must be logged.If it is signing is correct the installation procedure is allowed to be started.An event must be logged.Sub modules do not have a firmware signing check
Firmware update is only allowed in maintenance bypass operation, off operation or initialize state.

When a system firmware update is performed, only be the modules that have a different firmware version than the new firmware update package must be updated. If a module has the same version as is in the firmware update package it must not be updated.

Requirement: Single UPS vs parallel UPS firmware update - wave2
Description: It is not a requirement to be able to update a parallel system from a single connection point. Each individual UPS in a parallel system must be firmware updated separately.
This category is a collection of the FW update requirements for sparepart situations
In order to be able to upgrade automatically when a part is replaced, the SMC must store the firmware images for each controller.For IM it must be the route package containing PMC and SBSC images.
When the UPS boots, it must check the firmware version of the different modules. If a module has been replaced, it must be firmware updated automatically without the need for user intervention.

Requirement: Setting for disabling automatic firmware updates
Description: A setting to disabled the automatic update function in the system must be available, to avoid annoyance during development.
If the automatic firmware update function has determined to upgrade a module, and the file is not available, the system must alarm this, and the module must be prevented from starting up.

Requirement: Validation of compatibility -- remove to high level folder
Description: It must be the responsibility of the superior controller to validate the compatibility of the underlying modules.SMC decides if it is compatible withIM, NMC, HMIIM decides if it is compatible withPMCSBSC

When validating version number on a sub module the following rules applymajor.minor.deviation.buildMajor numbermust be the same as the parent controller, or "1" (indicating it is a pure platform module)Minor numbermust be identical to the expected number on the parent. It does not have to match the parents numberDeviation numbermust be identical to the expected number on the parent. It does not have to match the parents number. Exception: if the deviation number is 200-255 it is an engineering version and per definition compatibleBuild numberDoes not have to match

Requirement: Automatic sparepart firmware update - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Automatic sparepart firmware update - setting has been changed
A category for specific device requirements in relation to FW update
Controllers for power flow control (IMC, SMC, PMC and SBSC) must have dual image for firmware storage, so one bank is updated while the other is in operation.
When a power flow controller (IM, SMC, PMC and SBSC) is rebooted after flashing a new firmware image, and it does not boot correctly, it must reboot again on the previous firmware image.

When a new firmware file is pushed to a device, the device must validate the file before accepting it.If the file is discarded it must be logged.Validation parameters are:It has the correct 0P-number.It has the correct target chip.

Requirement: Firmware update of non-critical components while UPS is in inverter operation -- rejected
Description: It must be possible to firmware update non-critical components in the UPS with having to transfer to off or bypass, so that the load is still supplied via the inverter (normal/battery operation).
Will be defined as part of platform feature requirements.
* The UPS must include an authentication procedure when connecting to UPS Tuner, to ensure that it is only possible to connect a valid version of UPS Tuner version to the UPS.

When a cable is connected to the service port, it must be required by the user to confirm that he/she is physically present at the UPS (proximity check).The user must go to a dedicated menu in the display and press a button, before UPS Tuner is able to connect to the UPS.The proximity confirmation must be done by the user within 30 seconds after the cable has been connected, else the connection must be rejected.A connection between UPS Tuner and the UPS must have been established within 10 minutes after the proximity check has completed, else the connection is rejected by the UPS.

A password check must be done between the UPS and UPS Tuner to verify that only a valid version of UPS Tuner providing the right password is allowed to connect to, and communicate with, the UPS.If the authentication fails, UPS Tuner must be disconnected by the UPS.

* If the cable is disconnected from the service port the connection to UPS Tuner must be closed right away .  *   * A new connection to the service port must not be allowed within 5 seconds after a time-out, disconnection or failed authentication of UPS Tuner.
To be able to trace who is connected via Tuner, the License number of Tuner must be stored in the service log at connection.
Alarms and event for the UPS Tuner authentication feature

Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS Tuner is connected to the product.Event data must include the license number of the UPS Tuner software connected to the product.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS Tuner is no longer connected to the product.

Requirement: Data dump to USB memory key - wave2

Description: It must be possible to do a backup of the settings of the UPS and restore them again both via display and UPS Tuner.

Requirement: Request a dump of settings to USB-key from HMI - wave2
Description: It must be possible for the user to request a dump of all settings in the UPS from the HMI.

Requirement: Import settings from USB-key from HMI --- wave2
Description: It must be possible for the user to import the settings from a USB key

The file must be validated if it fits the unit. This is done by comparing the serial number the file was generated from, with the serial number of the UPS importing.It must also validate the integrity of the file

When importing from a USB key file, it is not allowed to set the following parametersSerial number of UPSModel number of UPSRFID Serial numberApparent Power rating3:3 or 3:1 configurationVoltage range (208/400/480)3 or 4 wire configurationN+1 configuration (Bravo only)

Requirement: UPS tuner compatibility for setting file - wave2

Description: Tuner must have the capability to read a file a customer has stored via USB key

Requirement: Modify and store setting dump file
Description: UPS Tuner must have the capability to modify and store a file, that can be imported into the UPS
The file must contain a checksum or hash value, for verification of the contend is not corrupted or modified by third party.

Requirement: Alarming if file is not valid
Description: It must be indicated by an alarm if the file the system tries to import is not valid.The alarm is reset again when the USB key is removed, or a new file import is started

Requirement: Command to store settings on USB key
Description: Command to start dumping the settings to a file on the USB key
Command to start importing the settings from file on  USB key
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: The settings were imported from USB
Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Use another fileDescription: The settings file is not valid or not intended for this UPS
Type: EventSeverity: informationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: The setting file import alarm is cleared

Requirement: User request to export UPS report
Description: It must be possible for the user to request the UPS to generate an UPS report and store it on a USB key, via a button on the display.

The UPS report must contain enough information to enable remote diagnostics in a customer care center.The following data/information must be collected in the CCC report:- Full UPS event log.- All UPS settings and configuration data.- Waveform capture files.- Statistics data.- LCM data.- All measurement values and status data which are also available in the display and UPS Tuner.- Active alarm list

Requirement: User request to abort UPS report export in progress
Description: It must be possible for the user to abort an UPS report export that is in progress.
While exporting the UPS report the UPS must show the status/progress to the user in the display.

Requirement: Navigate away from UPS report export display screen
Description: While the UPS is exporting the UPS report it must be possible for the user to navigate away from the UPS report export screen in the display and back again.

Requirement: Import UPS report in UPS Tuner
Description: It must be possible to open a UPS report in UPS Tuner and to view all the information contained in the report.
Command to genrate and dump the UPS report on the USB key.
Command to abort a UPS report export that is in progress.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: UPS report was exported to USB

Requirement: UPS report export requested by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: UPS report export to USB requested by user

Requirement: UPS report export aborted by user
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: N/ADescription: UPS report export to USB aborted by user
It is allowed to do hot swap of power modules, meaning the power modules are allowed to be replaced while the UPS is in inverter operation (in addtion to off operation or maintenance bypass).

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsPower module firmware version should be compatibility with system firmware version.Post conditionsUPS must ensure that an inserted module is allowed to actively operate in the system.Main success scenario1.      UPS in inverter operation2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up.4.      The IMC checks for compatibility5.    The IMC performs a self-test.5.    The IMC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted power module becomes operable and participates actively in the system (transfers to inverter operation). Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      UPS in off operation or maintenance bypass.2.      A power module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.      The power module boots up.4.      The IMC checks for compatibility and performs a self-test.5.      The IMC allows the inserted power module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted power module becomes operable.7.    The user transfers the UPS back to inverter operation and the inserted power module participates actively in the system. Scenario 2:1.      UPS in inverter operation2.      A power module is rebooted (there are two or more power modules in the UPS).3.      The power module boots up.4.      The IMC checks for compatibility and performs a self-test.5.      The IMC allows the booted power module to actively operate in the system.6.    The booted power module becomes operable.7.    The booted power module participates actively in the system (transfers to inverter operation). Scenario 3:1.      UPS in inverter operation2.      A power module is rebooted (there are two or more power modules in the UPS).3.      The power module boots up.4.      The IMC checks for compatibility5.    If compatibility not pass, post a alarm.6.    Power module won't be participates actively in the system .
It must be allowed to do hot swap of the SBS module, meaning the SBS module is allowed to be replaced while the UPS is in inverter operation (in addition to off operation or maintenance bypass).

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsPost conditionsUPS must ensure that an inserted module is allowed to actively operate in the system.Main success scenario1.    UPS in inverter operation2.    A SBS module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.    The SBS module boots up.4.    The IM checks for compatibility then performs a self-test.5.    The IM now allows the inserted SBS module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted SBS module becomes operable.7.    UPS stays in inverter operation from step 1 to 6. Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      UPS in off operation.2.    A SBS module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.    The SBS module boots up.4.    The IM checks for compatibility then performs a self-test.5.    The IM now allows the inserted SBS module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted SBS module becomes operable.7.    UPS stays in off operation from step 1 to 6.Scenario 2:1.      UPS in maintenance bypass.2.    A SBS module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.    The SBS module boots up.4.    The IM checks for compatibility then performs a self-test.5.    The IM now allows the inserted SBS module to actively operate in the system.6.    The inserted SBS module becomes operable and activates the static bypass switch.7.    UPS stays in maintenance bypass from step 1 to 6.Scenario 3:1.      UPS in off operation.2.    A SBS module is inserted and the enable switch is engaged.3.    The SBS module boots up.4.    The IM checks for compatibility.5.    If the compatibilty not pass, post a alarm6.    The inserted SBS module becomes inoperable

Requirement: Notify user if temperature or humidity is above or below the configured thresholds
Description: The user must be notified via alarms in display and UPS Tuner if the temperature or humidity is above or below the user configured thresholds (warning low, critical low, warning high, critical high).

Requirement: Notify user about probe communication status
Description: The user must be notified via an alarm in display and UPS Tuner if the communication is lost to a probe.

The following probe information must be available in the display:- If there is a probe attached to the NMC.- Which type of probe is connected to the NMC (temperature probe or temperature/humidity probe).- The name given to the probe by the customer.
The temperature and/or humidity measured by the probes must be available in the display.

The temperature reported by the probe in degree's Celsius, to a precision of 0.1. Unit: CPrecision: 1 decimalTemperature accuracy ±3ºF (±2ºC), from 32 to 104ºF (0 to 40ºC)Sensor operating temperature 14 to 159ºF (–10 to 70ºC)Measurement must be available for each probe connected.

The percentage humidity reported by the probe if supported by the probe type. Unit: %Precision: 0 decimalsHumidity accuracy ±4% RH, 20 to 90% RH, at 77ºF (25ºC) ±8% RH, 30 to 80% RH, from 59 to 95ºF (15 to 30ºC)Measurement must be available for each probe connected.

The UPS must not require the user (customer/FSR) to do a product registration (like done in GVS) and never show any reminder to register the product.

UPS must display a product registration reminder pop-up screen in the display at first startup to remind to register the product.Product registration must be done by FSR using UPS Tuner.It must be possible to "snooze" the reminder.If product is registered, no more reminders must be shown.If snoozed, the reminder must be shown again after a period of 1 week.If snoozed again, it must be shown again after 1 month.If snoozed again, it must be shown again after 3 months.If snoozed again, the reminder must not be shown anymore.{Image: CC55EBE6-0B0F-417D-A04D-E01219BA83CD.bmp}For testing purposes, it must be possible shorten the reminder interval.
Settings used for product registration
This setting tells the UPS if the product has been registered or not, and must only be visible and configurable via UPS Tuner.Range: True or falseDefault value: False
Alarms and event for the Product registration feature
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: Please register your product.Description: Your UPS is not registered
Type: AlarmSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: .Description: Product registration has been completed successfully

At power-up, the UPS must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts (like power modules, controllers etc.) to ensure the UPS is operational before it is connected to the load.Steps performed during the startup self-test are:- Check of hardware configuration and revisions.- Check of internal communication busses- Check of firmware revisions vs. hardware- Check of source voltages.- Check of DC voltages.- Check of PFC state- Check of surveillance status.- Perform an inverter selftest, generating output voltage locally on the inverter(s).- Check of memory(nice to have) The progress and status of the startup self-test must be available to the user via active alarms and events in the event log.

At power-up, the power module must perform an automatic self-test with the following steps... - Check that power module has initialized correctly.- Check that the power module hardware configuration is correct.- Check that the input voltage sources (mains input and battery) are within tolerance.- Check that precharge has completed.- Start PFC.- Check that DC bus voltages are within tolerance.- Start inverter and check that it operates correctly.- Start fans and check that they operate correctly.- Check if any surveillance detected faults are present.

Requirement: PMC HW and FW compatibility - wave2
Description: At boot up the FW must validate the current HW version is the expected and is compatible with the FW version.The check should contain the 0P number of the HW, and if present version number via pins on the HW.If the FW is not compatible with the Hardware, it should stop the execution, and stop triggering the Watchdog.
The power module must indicate its self-test status via a LED on the power module.Self-test running: LED flashing greenSelf-test passed: LED solid greenSelf-test failed: LED flashing red

Requirement: SBS startup self-test --- need to re-defined
Description: At power-up, the SBS must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts to ensure it is operational before it is connected to the load.Steps performed during the startup self-test are (Wukong will use same procedure and steps as shown for Alpha & Bravo):{Image: FE602F76-950F-480E-8272-439B6A1E0C2B.bmp} The global status of the self-test must be available to the user via active alarms and events in the event log.

Requirement: SBS HW and FW compatibility - wave2?
Description: At boot up the FW must validate the current HW version is the expected and is compatible with the FW version.This check must compare the SBS model number against the hardware revision of the SBS (via pins on the HW).If the FW is not compatible with the hardware, it must stop the execution (stay in self-test step).
The SBS must indicate its self-test status via a LED on the SBS module.Self-test running: LED flashing greenSelf-test passed: LED solid greenSelf-test failed: LED flashing red

Description: At power-up, the SMC must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts to ensure it is operational:

Requirement: Hold back test until configuration is complete --- need to be define by FW
Description: When powering up, the modules should not perform selftest until the settings from the system has been shared, to avoid selftest failing, due to wrong settings.If the system is not configured the first time yet the selftest of modules must be hold back until the correct settings are distributed from these sources.Comments:   Setting database is put in NAND-FLASH by SMC.

The UPS name must be formatted as follows:[Product name] [UPS power rating]where:- [Product name] is ""Galaxy VM""- [UPS power rating] is the nominal power rating of the UPS. For a non-scalable UPS this must be the value of the UPS power rating setting. For a scalable UPS this value must be based on the actual number of power modules populated in the UPS.
The UPS name must be shown to the user on the display, web interface and in UPS Tuner.
The UPS name must be configurable by user via the display (and UPS Tuner) if the user want to name the UPS differently than the default UPS name.
UPS name setting.Range: String of 22 charactersDefault value: The default UPS name defined as: Galaxy VM [UPS power rating]
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS name - setting has been changed

Requirement: UPS product family name  - wave X
Description: The UPS product family name must be available to UPS Tuner and NMC to be able to determine which product family it is connected to

Requirement: User configurable UPS product family name
Description: The UPS product family name must be configurable via UPS Tuner. In case SLC is replaced by a spare part it must be possible to set the correct UPS product family name.
UPS product family name setting.Range: String of 22 charactersDefault value: The default UPS name defined as: Galaxy VM

Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: UPS product family name - setting has been changed

Requirement: Redundant UOB input - ?why need redundant UOB input
Description: To ensure we are not backfeeding in SPOT mode redundandant UOB Input shall be implemented.When system runs in SPOT mode and wrap around bypass is enabled, UOB cannot be closed as this will backfeed to the grid.

- Remote display - Alpha4 must be compatibile with the 4 existing remote display solutions that are already developed for GVX.For GVX, 4 QSKU versions exist: QSMA16867, QSMA36791, QJCA14326  and QMSH33297

Requirement: Input contact reaction time - time define by HW
Description: When a given function is configured to an input contact, the time from when the input contact is activated to when the function is activated, must be maximum 5 seconds.

Requirement: User configurable input contacts and output relays - !time define by HW
Description: A number of configurable input contacts and output relays must be available to the user. The input contacts must be configurable to indicate a given event which is selectable from a pick list.  The output relays must beconfigurable to activate on one or more events which is selectable from a pick list.

Requirement: Tolerance of measurements - ???need to be define
Description: The tolerance of the standard measurements must be what is listed below:Voltage tolerance: Offset +/- 0.5V, reading +/- 1%Current tolerance: Offset +/- 1.5A, reading +/- 3%  of rated current at 415V inputPower tolerance: Offset +/- 0.2kVA, reading +/- 3%  250kW at 415V inputFrequency tolerance: Reading +/- 0.3 HzPower Factor (PF): Reading +/-6% (PF must never be shown as higher than 1)(*) Tolerance at loads (and charge current/power) higher than 20% of configured system size (>20% load). Below 20% load the reading is allowed to be >3%.

Requirement: NMC temperature and humidity probes - need to be confirmed by NMC team
Description: UPS must support connecting temperature and humidity probes to the NMC.- Temperature probe AP9335T.- Temperature/Humidity probe AP9335TH.

Requirement: Limit the time required to be in maintenance bypass during firmware update - need to be define
Description: If the firmware update procedure requires the system to be in maintenance bypass to complete, the time required to be in maintenance bypass must be minimized.

The IM controller box must have an enable switch which controls if the IM must be enabled or disabled. - Before the controller box is removed, the enable switch must be set to 'disabled' to shut down the controller.- When the controller box has been inserted, the enable switch must be set to 'enabled' to start up the controller.The IM controller box enable switch directly controls the 24V power to the UC.
HMI need to wake up if alarm??? during sleepNo alarm after 10min(can be set from 1min, 5min or 10min), HMI step into sleep mode.Wake up screen and beep if alarm.20210611:  move to Screen saver

There must be a surveillance function available to detect inoperable PSUs and report it to the user. Only PSU voltages that are actually monitored by either a dedicated voltage monitoring HW circuit or via an ADC, must be monitored and status reported by the firmware. The firmware cannot monitor individual voltages if it gets no information about the status from the HW or has no ADC input to monitor the voltage.
Surveillance detected fault must be set at 70% > 24V > 120% at 2 samples with a sample speed of 1khz. At fault the PFC, charger and inverter is shutdown.
Surveillance detected fault must be set at 70% > 15V > 120% at 2 samples with a sample speed of 1khz. At fault the PFC, charger and inverter is shutdown.
Surveillance detected fault must be set at 70% > -15V > 120% at 2 samples with a sample speed of 1khz. At fault the PFC, charger and inverter is shutdown.
Surveillance detected fault must be set if this input is active for 2 samples with a sample speed of 1khz. At fault the PFC, charger and inverter is shutdown.
Surveillance detected fault must be set if this input is active for 2 samples with a sample speed of 1khz. At fault the PFC, charger and inverter is shutdown.

Requirement: Surveillance of communication link to SBS
Description: The communication link between SBSC and IM must be monitored, and the user must be notified via alarms/events if the communication is lost.

The local temperature of the SBS (heatsink) must be monitored, and the user must be notified via alarms/events if the temperature arises above a certain limit:- High fault threshold: 90 degrees C.- High warning threshold: 65 degrees C.- High recovery threshold: 50 degress C.Degree need to be confirmed...
The SCRs of the SBS must be monitored, and the user must be notified via alarms/events if a SCR is detected as shorted or permanently open.
The local PSUs on the SBS must be monitored and the user must be notified via alarms/events if a PSU is detected as inoperable.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Static bypass switch temperature OK

Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Check cooling..Description: Static bypass switch temperature has been detected as too high.

Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: Replace static bypass switchDescription: At least one of the static bypass switch SCRs are not firing correctly.  Needs replacement immediately.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The SBSC internal PSU is OK
Type: AlarmSeverity: CriticalCorrective Action Text:Description: The SBSC internal PSU is inoperable
There must be a surveillance function available to detect overheating, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect peak currents limits, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.

Requirement: Surveillance of high DC bus voltages
Description: There must be a surveillance function available to detect for high DC bus voltages, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.

Requirement: Surveillance of currents deviating from reference
Description: There must be a surveillance function available to detect if the actual measured current deviates too much from the reference current, shut down the relevant converters, and report it to the user.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect differences between voltage measurements, and report it to the user via alarms and events in the event log.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect if ADCs are not working correctly, and report it to the user via alarms and events in the event log.
There must be a surveillance function available to detect if ADCs are not working correctly, and report it to the user via alarms and events in the event log.

The system must give an alarm if the output voltage sense circuit is measuring wrong. The RMS output voltage form the IM must be compared to either a SBS measurement or a PM measurement and post an alarm if they deviate more than 15%.The measurement must be conditioned of having communication between the modules, and the time these need to deviate must be 500 ms. for error and 600 ms. for OK statement.There must be one comparison for each phase, and they must have same reference.

Requirement: Output voltage sensing not working correctly
Description: Type: AlarmSeverity: WarningCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Output voltage sensing circuit is not working correctly on IM or PMC
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Output voltage sensing circuit is OK
