Requirement: Time handling -- remove to WHAT - FW
Description: This category contains the requirements for time handling and synchronization on the different devices.
Epoch reference is the 1 January 2000.The traditional epoch from 1970 is not used in this system.
The RTC master is the IM

In a parallel system, the parallel master is also the RTC master. Parallel slaves will have to adjust their internal RTC to the parallel masters RTC.In the unit, it is still the UC that is the RTC master for all another devices.

Requirement: Precision of the sync of time
Description: The parallel UC's must sync time within 5ms precision
The RTC master sends out the actual time with a fixed update rate, and upon request from a device.The update rate is 1 hour

The devices can request a time and date changes, through a time setting datagram. The RTC master will change the time and date, and distribute this through another datagram.It must be logged if the time and date was adjusted.
Command to the RTC master to tell the actual time.The RTC master will update the Time datagram, with time and date
Setting to adjust the date and time on the RTC master. This setting datagram should not be stored like other settings.The setting change must be logged

Requirement: RTC time and date has been adjusted
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: RTC time and date has been changed

The CAN bus is a part of the external and internal communication interface on the Intelligence Module (IM) and the external communication on the Power Module (PMC)/Static Bypass Switch(SBSC).Non-real time communication is flowing to the PMC from the Intelligence Module (IM) and vice versa on the redundant Communication bus – CBus1 to CBus on the MIM and CBus2 to the CBus on the RIM. Additional communication to external devices flows to/from the IM’s though the Auxiliary bus (Abus), Micro Link bus (ML2bus) and the redundant Parallel bus (PBus1/2). The system will use the extended CAN bus identifier (29 bits) which will result in a total CAN header of at least 67 bits (not counting bit-stuffing).The system will use CAN-Bus 2.0B, which has the following packet format – bit-stuffing[1] not included:SOFArbitration Field *Control FieldData Field *CRC FieldACK FieldEOFIntermission Field1 bit32 bits (29 effective)6 bits0 – 64 bits16 bits2 bits7 bits3 bitsTable 3.1 CAN Bus 2.0B Frame FormatNote: SOF: Start Of Frame, EOF: End Of Frame.* Bits that can be set by an application.This will result in a minimum frame size of 67 bits + 8N data bits; 0 <= N <= 8.[1]Bit-stuffing are done by inserting a bit of opposite polarity if five consecutive bits have the same polarity (including any previous bit-stuffing).
Up to operate up to 5 units in parallel (max 4+1)
Reuse GVX Parallel Comunications Kit (Option) that permits to build a parallel system.
Maximum supported distance between 2 UPS must be 15 meters.
It must be possible to connect more UPS units in parallel to supply the same load

Requirement: Parallel address number for each UPS
Description: The user must be able to configure an unique parallel address number for each UPS, and an event must logged if the setting is changed.

Requirement: UPS units present in the parallel system
Description: The user must be able to configure which UPS units are present in the parallel system, and an event must be logged if the setting is changed. This way individual parallel UPS units can be disabled if taken out for service, avoiding having a permanent communication alarm to the UPS taken out for service.

If more than one parallel UPS has wrongly been configured to the same unique parallel address number, it must be detected by the system and the user must be notified via an alarm.If an UPS is powered up into an already running parallel system, and it has the same unique parallel address number as another UPS in the already running parallel system, the UPS powered up must not interfere with the running parallel system and it must not be able to participate in the parallel system (must remain in off operation).

The parallel UPS units must communicate with each other via two fully redundant point-to-point communication busses.If one parallel communication bus is detected as faulty by any of the parallel UPS units, the given UPS must automatically use the other parallel communication bus without impacting the operation of the parallel system.
The communication status of the two parallel busses must be monitored by of each of the parallel UPS units, and be available to the user via alarms/events.

Each UPS in the parallel system must check that its firmware is compatible with the other UPS units in the parallel system.If the is detected as not compatible when the UPS powers up, it must be indicated to the user via an alarm, and the UPS must not be able to participate actively in the parallel system.If the firmware versions of the parallel UPS units are compatible but not same, the user must be notified via an alarm.

Each UPS in the parallel system must check that its nominal power rating is the same as the other UPS units in the parallel system.If the is detected as different when the UPS powers up, it must be indicated to the user via an alarm, and the UPS must not be able to participate actively in the parallel system.

The parallel system must have a floating master.The parallel master UPS must be responsible for controlling the global operation mode of the parallel system, selecting the synchronization source of the parallel system, and the global inverter control and regulation. If the current parallel master UPS is no longer able to act as master (master breakdown) another parallel UPS must be able to become parallel master without impacting the system.It must be evaluated continuesly which UPS is best suited as being parallel master based on conditions like UOB status, UPS operation mode, synchronization source availability and static bypass switch status. If the current master UPS in the parallel system is no longer the best suited as master another UPS must become master without any impact on the system.For example: * An UPS that has UOB open must never become parallel master.  * An UPS that is in inverter operation or static bypass operation must have higher parallel master priority than an UPS that is in off operation.  * An UPS that is able to synchronize to the bypass source must have higher parallel master priority than an UPS that is free running.

Requirement: Detection of more parallel master UPS units (master collision)
Description: If it is detected on the parallel communication bus that more than one parallel master is active at the same time, the user must be notified via an alarm, and the parallel UPS units that are currently acting as masters must jump off the communication line so that a new master selection procedure can be carried out.

Requirement: Notification of no parallel master detected
Description: The user must be notified via an alarm if no master is detected in the parallel system.
The user nust be notified via an event if the parallel master has changed from one UPS to another.

Requirement: Indication of which UPS is parallel master
Description: The user must be be able to see which UPS (UPS number) is currently parallel master via UPS Tuner.
Parallel UPS units must share the output load equally within 3% or better.
It must be possible to parallel UPS units for capacity.
It must be possible to parallel UPS units for redundancy.

It must be possible for the user to configure how many parallel UPS units are used for redundancy (N+0, N+1, N+2, N+3, N+4 etc.).If the output load exceeds the level where the parallel UPS redundancy is lost, it must be alarmed to the user, but the system must not change operation mode or current limit the output, unless an overload condition occurs.

Requirement: Number of redundant parallel UPS units
Description: A value for the current number of redundant parallel UPS units must be made available to the user.

Settings that are required to be the same on all parallel UPS units must automatically be synchronized and kept the same by the system. * At parallel system power-up the parallel master must automatically distribute these settings to all the the other parallel UPS units. The user must be notified via an alarm/event if the parallel settings synchronization at system power-up was completed successfully or not.  * If one or more of these settings are changed by the user on one parallel UPS, the settings must automatically be distributed to the other parallel UPS units.

Requirement: Minimum number of parallel UPS required to supply load
Description: It must be possible for the user to configure the minimum number of parallel UPS units that are required to supply the load. This feature is used to avoid turning on UPS inverter(s) into a load that is bigger than what the inverter(s) can supply without entering overload.The parallel system must not transfer from off to inverter operation before the configured minimum number of parallel UPS units are ready to turn onThe user must be notified via an alarm if there are not enough UPS units which are ready to turn on. . For example, if the minimum number of parallel UPS required to supply load is configured to 2, and the parallel system is in off operation, then when the user must pushes the inverter on button on the first UPS, the system must stay off and an alarm must indicate that there are not enough UPS units ready to turn on. When the user pushes the inverter on button on the second UPS the system must transfer to inverter operation and the alarm must be cleared. More details can be found in the "On button pushed" requirement under parallel "Sequences and behavior".

Requirement: Indication of mixed UPS operation mode in a parallel system
Description: The user must be notified via an alarm if one or more parallel UPS units are operating in battery operation, while others are operating in normal operation

Requirement: Global customer alarm for parallel events
Description: There must be a global customer alarm/event available, which covers the parallel operation related alarms/events which are only shown for service.The following service alarms/events must also post the global parallel customer alarm/event: * UPS parallel address configuration number incorrect  * Parallel master not detected.  * Parallel unit not present.  * Settings not synchronized between parallel UPS units  * Parallel unit is incompatible.

Requirement: Alarm user if IMB is closed in parallel system with MBB
Description: The IMB(s) must not be operated in a parallel system with MBB, however in case one or more IMBs are closed, the system must react accordingly and post an alarm to the user.

Allows transferring a parallel UPS in battery operation into a standby state, if the remaining parallel UPS units in normal operation can supply the load.If an UPS in a parallel system enters battery operation while the other UPS units are in normal operation it shall be put it into a so called "inverter standby" mode if the remaining UPS units can supply the load. This way the batteries of the given UPS will not be drained unnecessarily.An UPS in "inverter standby" must be able to start up and supply the load again if needed due to an increased load, loss of redundancy, or the shutdown of one or more UPS units. The shift out of "inverter standby" must be done without any influence on the load.

Requirement: Into inverter standby due to battery operation
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (avoid unnecessary draining of batteries).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units are in normal operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit shifts to battery operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The N+x criteria set will still be met if one UPS is turned off.  5. The given UPS enters inverter standby operation after 15 seconds in battery operation.  6. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All UPS units are in normal operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit shifts to battery operation.   1. The total load on the parallel system is above what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply or the N+x criteria set will not be met if one UPS is turned off.   2. The given UPS stays in battery operation. 3. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. More than one UPS is in normal operation, one UPS is in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit shifts from normal operation to battery operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The N+x criteria set will still be met if the given UPS is turned off.  5. The given UPS enters inverter standby operation after 15 seconds in battery operation.  6. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation. Scenario 3: 1. All UPS units are in normal operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. Two UPS units shift to battery operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The N+x criteria set will still be met if two UPS units are turned off.  5. The first UPS of the two in battery operation enters inverter standby operation after 15 seconds in battery operation.  6. The second UPS of the two in battery operation enters inverter standby operation 15 seconds after the first UPS unit entered inverter standby operation  7. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Out of inverter standby due to battery operation
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (avoid unnecessary draining of batteries).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. At least one UPS is in normal operation, one UPS is in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. The UPS in inverter standby operation is able to return to normal operation.  3. The UPS in inverter standby operation changes to normal operation after 10 seconds.  4. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. At least one UPS is in normal operation, one UPS is in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.   1. The total load on the parallel system increases above what the UPS unit(s) in normal operation can supply or the N+x criteria set is no longer met.   2. The UPS in inverter standby operation changes to battery operation right away. 2. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. At least one UPS unit is in normal operation, two or more UPS units are in inverter standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.   1. The total load on the parallel system increases above what the UPS unit(s) in normal operation can supply or the N+x criteria set is no longer met.   2. All UPS units in inverter standby operation change to battery operation right away. 2. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Setting to enable and disable the Advanced Battery Operation Management feature. Possible values:Enable / Disable Default value:Enable Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Advanced battery operation management - setting changed
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: Advanced battery operation management - setting has been changed

Primary Actor(s)-          User. Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to turn on a parallel system that is off and supply the load with UPS backup. Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units. Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system. Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in off mode  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  4. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  5. The UPS turns output on. If Mains 2 is available the UPS unit enters forced static bypass operation and then enters inverter operation. If Mains 2 is not available it enters inverter operation.    Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in off mode  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load. (The minimum number of UPS units required is a setting).  4. The minimum number of UPS units are not available.  5. The system stays off. System indicates that not enough UPS units are available.  6. User pushes the on button on the second UPS.  7. System checks if the minimum number of UPS units are available - ready to turn on and supply the load.  8. The minimum number of UPS units are available.  9. The UPS units turn output on. If Mains 2 is available the UPS units enter forced static bypass operation and then enter inverter operation. If Mains 2 is not available they enter inverter operation. Depending on the setting of the minimum required UPS units the user might have to repeat step 3 to 5 several times. Scenario 2: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the first UPS alone can supply the load.  4. The first UPS can supply the load.  5. The parallel system and the first UPS enter inverter operation. Scenario 3: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. System checks if the first UPS alone can supply the load.  4. The first UPS cannot supply the load alone. System indicates that not enough UPS units are available.  5. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system stay in forced static bypass operation.  6. User pushes the on button on the second UPS.   7. System checks if the UPS units with on button pushed can supply the load.  8. The UPS units with on button pushed can supply the load.  9. The parallel system and UPS units with on button pushed enter inverter operation. Scenario 4: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in requested static bypass operation.  2. User pushes the on button on the first UPS.  3. The parallel system and all UPS units enter inverter operation.     Special requirementsNA Technology and data variations listNA Open issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to turn off a parallel system that is on.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is either supplied through the bypass (Mains 2) or off.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. User pushes the off button on the first UPS.  3. The first UPS turns off inverter and no longer supplies the load.  4. User pushes the off button on the second UPS.  5. The second UPS turns off inverter and no longer supplies the load.  6. User pushes the off button on the last UPS.   1. if bypass within tolerance, the parallel system and all UPS units enter forced static bypass operation without break or   2. if not sync to bypass, the parallel system and all UPS units enter forced static bypass operation with a break if user acknowledges it or   3. if bypass not available, the parallel system and all UPS units enter off operation if user ackowledges it.  Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. User pushes the off button on the first UPS.  3. The total load on the parallel system will be larger than what the remaining UPS units still on can supply.  4. If user acknowledges this...   1. if bypass within tolerance, the parallel system and all UPS units enter forced static bypass operation without break or   2. if not sync to bypass, the parallel system and all UPS units enter forced static bypass operation with a break if user acknowledges it or   3. if bypass not available, the given UPS turns off and the the parallel system and the remaining UPS units will stay in inverter operation untill overload. 5. If user does not acknowledge this all parallel UPS units and the parallel system continiues in inverter operation Scenario 2: 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. User pushes the off button on the first UPS.  3. The parallel UPS redundancy will be lost.  4. If user acknowledges this...   1. The given UPS turns off and the the parallel system and the remaining UPS units will stay in inverter operation. 5. If user does not acknowledge this all parallel UPS units and the parallel system continiues in inverter operation “Push off button” means pressing the button for more than 3 seconds. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesBehavior described in alternative scenario 1 is currently not followed in GVX (and maybe also not GVM). Must be checked if requirement or GVX firmware must be updated/corrected.

Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to turn a parallel system into requested static bypass.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units. Bypass is available and within tolerances to allow shift to requested static bypass.Post conditionsThe parallel UPS system is in requested static bypass and still supplies the load.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of any of the parallel UPS units.  3. All UPS units and the parallel system change to requested static bypass operation. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are off.  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of any UPS.  3. Only the UPS commanded in to requested static bypass operation changes to requested static bypass operation. Other UPS's will stay in off operation. Scenario 2a: 1. The first UPS is off and the second UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of the UPS in off operation UPS.  3. Both UPS units changes to requested static bypass operation. Scenario 2b: 1. The first UPS is off and the second UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display of the UPS in inverter operation UPS.  3. Only the UPS in inverter operation changes to requested static bypass operation. The UPS in off operation other statys in off operation Scenario 3a: 1. The first UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the other UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display on the UPS in inverter operation.  3. The UPS in inverter operation changes to requested static bypass operation. The UPS in static bypass standby operation stays in static bypass standby operation Scenario 3b: 1. The first UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the other UPS in inverter operation  2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The user is not allowed to make a request to go into reqested static on a UPS in static bypass standby operation. Scenario 3c: 1. The first UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the UPS has SSIB is open. The other UPS in inverter operation and bypass is available on this UPS.   2. User selects “UPS into requested bypass” in the display on the UPS in inverter operation.  3. The UPS in inverter operation changes to requested static bypass operation. The UPS in static bypass standby operation stays in static bypass standby operation Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: System out of requested static bypass
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : Wants to return a parallel system from requested static bypass to inverter on.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units and the parallel system are in requested static bypass operation.  2. User selects “UPS out of requested bypass” in the display of any of the parallel UPS units.  3. The parallel system and all UPS units enter inverter operation. Alternative scenarios  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-       User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. The MBB is closed and all UOB are closed.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.    All UPS units are in maintenance bypass.2.    The system is in maintenance bypass.3.    The MBB is detected as opened on all UPS units in a parallel setup.4.    The UPS units enter forced static bypass operation.5.    The system enters forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.    All UPS units are in maintenance bypass.2.    The system is in maintenance bypass.3.    The MBB is detected as opened on one or more but not all UPS units in a parallel setup.4.    The UPS unit(s) that detect(s) MBB as open enter(s) forced static bypass.5.    The system continues in maintenance bypass. Special requirements                                                 NATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issues

Primary Actor(s)-       User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser              : .Pre conditionsUPS system must be supplied with power. The MBB is open.Post conditionsNAMain success scenario1.      The SIB is closed and all UOB are closed.2.      All UPS units are in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.3.      The system is in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.4.      The MBB is detected as closed on all UPS units in a parallel setup.5.      The UPS units enters maintenance bypass and activates the static bypass switches.6.      The system enters maintenance bypass.Alternative scenariosScenario 1:1.      The SIB is closed and all UOB are closed.2.      All UPS units are in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.3.      The system is in any operation mode except maintenance bypass.4.      The MBB is detected as closed on one or more but not all UPS units in a parallel setup.5.      The UPS unit(s) that detect(s) MBB as closed enter(s) maintenance bypass and activates the static bypass switches.6.    The UPS units(s) that do not detect MBB as closed enter forced static bypass.7.      The system enters maintenance bypass.Special requirements                                                 NATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Into forced static bypass due to output voltage out of tolerance
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure a stable supply of power to the load.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system via Mains 2.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. One or more UPS units detect(s) an output voltage error.  3. All UPS units and the parallel system change to forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure a stable supply of power to the load.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is still supplied with power.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit detects a fault (not an output voltage fault) and needs to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is larger than what the remaining UPS units can supply.  4. All UPS units and the parallel system change to forced static bypass operation.Alternative scenarios Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure a stable supply of power to the load.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. The fault forcing the forced static bypass operation is no longer present.  3. All UPS units and the parallel system return to inverter operation.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (stay in inverter on mode).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in inverter operation.  2. One UPS unit detects a fault (not an output voltage fault) and needs to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. The total load on the parallel system is within what the remaining UPS unit(s) can supply.  4. The given UPS enters static bypass standby operation.  5. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system continue in inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in requested static bypass operation.  2. One UPS unit detects a fault (not an output voltage fault) and needs to enter forced static bypass operation..  3. The given UPS enters static bypass standby operation.  4. The remaining UPS units and the parallel system return to inverter operation. Scenario 2: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. One UPS unit has a fault (not an output voltage fault) which has forced the system to be in forced static bypass operation..  3. The total  load on the parallel system decreases to what the UPS units with no fault can supply..  4. The UPS units with no fault and the parallel system return to inverter operation.  5. The UPS with the fault enters static bypass standby operation. Scenario 3: 1. All UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. One UPS unit has a static bypass switch fault.  3. The given UPS enters static bypass standby operation. Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Load.-          UPSStakeholders and InterestsLoad              : Wants a stable supply of power.UPS              : Wants to ensure UPS backup as long as possible (stay in inverter operation).Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsThe load is supplied by the parallel UPS system.Main success scenario 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. The fault forcing the UPS unit(s) in static bypass standby operation is no longer present.  3. The given UPS unit(s) returns from static bypass standby operation to inverter operation.Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. A fault is detected which requires the parallel system to enter forced static bypass operation.  3. All UPS units (including the one in static bypass standby operation) and the parallel system enter forced static bypass operation. Scenario 2: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. MBB is closed.  3. All UPS units (including the one in static bypass standby operation) and the parallel system enter maintenance bypass. Scenario 3: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. Off button pushed on UPS in static bypass standby operation..  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation enters off operation. Scenario 4: 1. One UPS unit has a static bypass switch fault or Mains 2 out of tolerance and is in static bypass standby operation. All the other UPS units and the parallel system are in forced static bypass operation.  2. The UPS unit in static static bypass standby operation no longer has a static bypass switch fault or Mains 2 out of tolerance.  3. The given UPS enters forced static bypass operation. Scenario 5: 1. At least one UPS is in inverter operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system is in inverter operation.  2. Inverter On button is pushed on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation changes to inverter operation. Scenario 6a: 1. At least one UPS is in requested static bypass operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation (due to inverter off button pushed) and the parallel system is in requested static bypass operation .  2. Inverter On button is pushed on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system changes to inverter operation. Scenario 6b: 1. At least one UPS is in requested static bypass operation, at least one UPS is in static bypass standby operation (due to inverter shutdown) and the parallel system is in requested static bypass operation .  2. Inverter On button is pushed on the UPS in static bypass standby operation.  3. The UPS in static bypass standby operation stays in static bypass standby operation and the parallel system changes to inverter operation.  Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Parallel system.Stakeholders and InterestsParallel system: Wants to ensure that basic parallel settings are handled correctly.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditions.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all) and all have the default values for 'parallel UPS address number setting' and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting'.  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (UOB open on all UPS units)  3. The parallel UPS units check for consistency of the basic parallel settings and detects that they are not consitent  4. The user is notifed about the inconsistency via the alarms 'UPS parallel address configuration number incorrect' and 'General parallel system event'  5. The parallel system cannot start before this is corrected by the user.  6. User configures each UPS to a valid 'parallel UPS address number setting' and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting'  7. The alarms are cleared in all parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. A parallel system consisting of two parallel UPS units is in inverter operation (with 'parallel UPS address number setting' 1 and 2, and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting' with UPS1-3 enabled).   2. A third UPS with default values for 'parallel UPS address number setting' and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting' is powered up (UOB open)  3. The parallel system checks for consistency of the basic parallel settings and detects that the third UPS is not consistent  4. The user is notifed about the inconsistency via the alarms 'UPS parallel address configuration number incorrect' and 'General parallel system event'  5. The parallel system continues in inverter operation and the third UPS cannot be transferred out of off operation.  6. The user configures the 'parallel UPS address number setting' to 3 and the 'parallel UPS units enabled/present setting' to UPS1-3 enabled on the third UPS.  7.  The alarms are cleared.  8. The user closes the UOB of the third UPS and presses the inverter on button.  9. The third UPS transfers to normal operation and the parallel system stays in inverter operation.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Parallel settings synchronization by parallel master at UPS power-up
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Master UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsMaster UPS  : Wants to ensure that all settings related to parallel operation are the same in all parallel UPS units after power-up.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsAll parallel related settings are the same for all parallel UPS units in the system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  3. UOB is closed on one UPS and this UPS becomes master.  4. The parallel settings of the parallel master UPS are automatically distributed to all the other parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. One UPS is completely off and the other parallel UPS units and the parallel system are up and running (powered and configured).  2. One UPS is powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. The parallel settings of the parallel master UPS are automatically distributed to the UPS powered up.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Parallel settings synchronization of settings changed by user
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          User.Stakeholders and InterestsUser  : Wants to ensure that all settings related to parallel operation are the same in all parallel UPS unitsPre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsAll parallel related settings are the same for all parallel UPS units in the system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. A parallel setting that must be kept the same on all parallel UPS units is changed by the user on any of the parallel UPS units.  4. The setting is automatically synchronized and changed on all the other parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  3. UOB is closed on one UPS and this UPS becones parallel master  4. A parallel setting that must be kept the same on all parallel UPS units is changed by the user on any of the parallel UPS units.  5. The setting is automatically synchronized and changed on all the other parallel UPS units.Scenario 2: 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  3. A parallel setting that must be kept the same on all parallel UPS units is changed by the user on any of the parallel UPS units.  4. The setting is only changed on the given UPS and not synchronized to the other parallel UPS units.  5. The UOB is closed on the given UPS and this UPS becones parallel master  6. The setting is automatically synchronized and changed on all the other parallel UPS units.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Parallel settings synchronization depending on UPS operation mode
Description: Primary Actor(s)-          Parallel system.Stakeholders and InterestsParallel system: Wants to ensure that all settings related to parallel operation are the same in all parallel UPS units.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsAll parallel related settings are the same for all parallel UPS units in the system.Main success scenario 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. User pushes the inverter on button on all parallel UPS units .  4. The parallel UPS units transfer to normal operation.  5. User tries to change the settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency on any parallel UPS.  6. The settings are not changed on any of the parallel UPS units. Alternative scenariosScenario 1: 1. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  2. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB).  3. User pushes the inverter on button on all parallel UPS units except one.  4. The parallel UPS units on which the inverter on button has been pushed transfer to normal operation.  5. User tries to change the settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency on the UPS that is in off operation.  6. The settings are not changed on any of the parallel UPS units.Scenario 2: 1. One UPS is configured differently than the others with regards to nominal system voltage and system frequency.  2. All parallel UPS units are completely off (not powered at all).  3. All the parallel UPS units are powered up (all breakers closed except MBB/IMB and UOB).  4. The inverter on button is pushed on the parallel UPS which is configured differently than the others with regards to nominal system voltage and system frequency, and the UPS transfers to normal operation.  5. The UOB is closed on all parallel UPS units except the one that is in normal operation.  6. The settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency are not synchronized and changed automatically on the parallel UPS that is in normal operation   7. The UOB is closed on the parallel UPS in normal operation and the UPS transfers to off operation  8. The settings for nominal system voltage and system frequency are now synchronized and changed automatically on the parallel UPS that transferred to off operation.Special requirementsNATechnology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Primary Actor(s)-          Master UPS.Stakeholders and InterestsMaster UPS  :.Pre conditionsThe parallel system consists of at least two UPS units.Post conditionsParallel master has changed with any impact on the current operation of the parallel system.Main success scenario 1. The current parallel master is no longer able to act as master.  2. The parallel slave UPS with the highest priority jumps in as master.Alternative scenariosNASpecial requirementsThis requirement is only valid for a parallel system with a Master functionality.Technology and data variations listNAOpen issuesNA

Requirement: Number of redundant parallel UPS units status
Description: The current number of redundant parallel UPS units (based on the load and operational conditions of the parallel system).
The master status of each UPS must be available to the user (in UPS Tuner).

Setting for the UPS number in a parallel configuration Default value: 1Range: Depends on the product, please see product specific requirement.Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: * Every UPS must have a unique number (more than one UPS cannot have the same number).  * The unique UPS number must only be configurable when the UPS is in off operation or maintenance bypass operation  * The unique UPS number must only be configurable to a UPS number which has has been enabled via the "Parallel UPS units enabled/present setting".

Requirement: Parallel UPS address number setting range
Description: Maximum number of parallel UPS units in GVL is 5, meaning the parallel UPS address number setting range is:  Range: 1 to 5.

Setting for which parallel UPS units are present in the system. Each UPS unit can be selected as present or not present. Default value: UPS 1 enabledRange: Depends on the product, please see product specific requirement. Example (UPS 1, 2 and 4 are present. UPS 3 and 5 are not present): {Image: E8F5EDFB-E70C-4113-B588-E6F1ED0435CC.bmp} Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: * Setting must be kept synchronized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.  * It must only be allowed to disable a parallel UPS if there is no communication with it (example: it is completely off or parallel cables are disconnected), and if the UPS number to be disabled differs from the UPS units own unique number.  * There are no restrictions when it comes to enabling a parallel UPS.

Requirement: Parallel UPS address number setting range
Description: Maximum number of parallel UPS units in GVL is 5, meaning the parallel UPS units enabled/present setting range is:  Range: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 present

Setting for the parallel UPS redundancy.Default value: N+0Range: N+0, N+1, N+2, N+3, N+4 etc, depends on the product, please see product specific requirement.Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies:Maximum parallel redundancy that can be set must depend on the number of parallel UPS units.Number of parallel UPS units vs maximum parallel redundancy:1:           N+02:           N+13:           N+24:           N+35:           N+4etc.Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

Requirement: Parallel UPS units enabled/present setting range
Description: Setting for the parallel UPS redundancy. Maximum number of parallel UPS units in GVL is 5, meaning the maximum allowed redundant UPS units must be 4.Default value: N+0Range: N+0, N+1, N+2, N+3, N+4N+0 is only allowed for a parallel system of 4 UPS units or below (5 parallel UPS units for power is not allowed).

Requirement: Minimum number of parallel UPS required to supply load setting
Description: Setting for the minimum number of UPS units required to supply the load.This number is used in a parallel system to determine when enough UPS units is ready to turn on the output and supply the full load. Range Depends on the product, please see product specific requirement.Default value: 1 Required check of setting and/or configuration dependencies: Maximum settable value depends on the number of UPS units in parallel for capacity. Setting must be kept synchonized (the same) between UPS units in a parallel setup.

There must be a surveillance function available to detect blown fuses and report it to the user.

At start-up self-test the IM must check if any surveillance detected faults are present, and if so, fail the self-test.The surveillance detected faults include:- IM internal PSU inoperable- IM ADC is not working correctly

Requirement: IM startup self-test - need to re-defined
Description: At power-up, the IM must perform an automatic self-test of the main parts to ensure it is operational:{Image: 05D0B947-8F39-4806-9E9B-F0A36F57BD42.bmp}
Current in A as numeric value (per phase). Maximum value of the last 30 days. Unit: APrecision: 0 decimals
Numeric value in % per phase (for 3:1 single phase only L1 is used). Unit: %Precision: 1 decimal.
UPS efficiency in %. Unit: %Precision: 1 decimal.
Bypass UTHD per phase Unit: %Precision: 0 decimals.

Requirement: Fan inoperable - dry contact output setting
Description: Setting to assign a customer configurable dry contact output to indicate that one or more fans in the UPS are inoperable.Range: Enable/disableDefault value: DisableIt is not designed in Jedi.

Requirement: Input Voltage for full load operation  - !HW Product quick spic

Description: Supported battery typesonly for classic battery at the first stageother requirement would be update by new requirement

Setting for the battery discharge voltage limit for when the manual battery self-test must exit. Range (Lead-acid): 1.70V/cell to 2.3V/cellDefault value (Lead-acid): 2.0V/cell Range (Li-ion): 2.1V/cell to 4.2V/cellDefault value (Li-ion): 3.5V/cellRange (NiCd): 0.6V/cell to 1.7V/cellDefault value (NiCd): 1.1V/cellonly support Lead-acid in Jedi
The UPS must be able to support NiCd batteries as energy storage.

Requirement: Li-ion support - not supported in Jedi
Description: The UPS must be able to support Li-ion batteries as energy storage.

Requirement: External Breakers (Bypass) monitoring --- IO board diagram
Description: Redundant to WHAT39224/WHAT39235The UPS shall be able to monitor the position of input, output (and Bypass) switches/breakers when using an external bypass.Breakers monitored are:Still the UPS should also be able work with a 'minimal' bypass that has no lights and is not monitored.Break NameDescriptionCommentSSIBUOB serial for parallelDifferrent UPS output paralleled breakerStatus CheckSIBBypass breaker statusStatus CheckMBBMaitenance checkStatus CheckUOBOutput breakerStatus CheckBB1There are 5 BBOnly BB can be controled and checkedControl and status feedbackBB2 Control and status feedbackBB3 Status CheckBB4 Status CheckUIBUIB_AUX_INPUT MBBExternal MBB IMB  RIMBRedundance MBB1+1For simplified 1+1UOB_RedundantNot in use now

Requirement: Switch gear breakers/switches to be monitored
Description: The UPS must be able to monitor the status (open/closed) of the following switch gear breakers/switches (if present):Break ListDescriptionSSIBM2 input voltageSIBSystem isolation breakerParalleled output common point connect to loadMBBOutter Maitenance checkUOBOutput breakerBB1Battery breaker for string1Only BB can be controled and checkedBB2Battery breaker for string2BB3Battery breaker for string3BB4Battery breaker for string4UIBM1 Input breakerMBBRExternal MBBIMBInner maitennanceRIMBRedundance MBBUOB_RedundantNot in use nowThe current status of the present breakers/switches must be visible to the user, and a breaker/switch status change must be logged in the event log.

Any FW incompatibility between power modules & UPS frame should be automatically managed by UPS without FSR intervention  - PLUG & PLAYThe bootloader file should be saved in NAND-FLASH in SMC level, so the SM would update the IM?RIM?PM or SBS when the FW version is incompatability.

Requirement: Self detection of power modules and details
Description: UPS should self detect the power modules & report the details like Serial number , Hardware and FW revisions on to TUNER and MAINT for customer reportingIn Jedi, the hardware version and firmware version should be collected and report to TUNRE and HMI? no MAINT

Requirement: Charging from inverter when in static bypass
Description: The UPS must be able to charge the batteries when in static bypass with no mains input available.If the PFC/mains input is not available, the power must be drawn from bypass input through inverter to the DC bus. From the DC bus the charger is then able to transfer the power to the batteries.Nice to have for wave1  and wave2.

Requirement: Advanced dual UPS sync with floating sync master and static bypass standby___TBD in wave2
Description: It must be possible to syncronize the output voltages between two intelligent sources (UPS units) without the need of using an external synchronization box. The UPS best suited as synchronization source must automatically be selected based on the given circumstances.The goal is to enable a STS to shift between the two UPS units with a minimum output voltage break time.Further more, if the circumstances allow it, the STS must automatically be forced to select an UPS in normal/battery operation over an UPS in static bypass as the output source to the load.
The battery high voltage shutdown level must be a fixed value at 750 V or 2.6V/cell for lead-acid
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text: NADescription: The UPS is charging the batteries or batteries are resting.

Requirement: Reset of settings to factory default - FW
Description: It must be possible for the user to do a factory reset of all configurable settings of the UPS, so that these settings return to the defined default values.The factory reset of settings must not reset certain settings like serial and model numbers.The factory reset of settings must not reset certain settings like serial, model numbers, calibration parameters.A factory reset must also clear the customer view of the UPS and NMC event logs.

Requirement: Invalid firmware update product ID detected by IM
Description: Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: The IM has detected that the product ID of the firmware update package is invalid.
At boot up the UC must perform memory integrity check.
Different parallel configurations and all requirements linked to parallel system.

Requirement: High efficiency mode in parallel operation
Description: The high efficiency modes must be available in a parallel UPS setup.

Requirement: User configurable if high efficiency mode can be disabled by system
Description: It must be possible for the use to configure if high efficiency mode can be disabled by the system or not.This way the user can force the system to keep going back into high efficiency mode no matter how many times it has transfered in and out high efficiency mode within 24 hours.
The input current could be set by Tunor.
Type: EventSeverity: InformationalCorrective Action Text:Description: Input current limit has been set
